PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 8 October 1996, on motion by Senator Kemp:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in general support of the Legislative Instruments Bill 1996 , for in many ways the bill that we are discussing this morning is a bill which Labor, believe it or not, introduced in the previous parliament. Two years down the track we are still dealing with the legislation of the previous Labor government.
—It was 1994, actually.

—It was 1994, in fact, so we have only been three years in deliberations on this particular concept. As the minister representing the Attorney‐General pointed out in her second reading speech in this place, this bill arose from a report of the Administrative Review Council, a report entitled Rule Making by Commonwealth Agencies .

BREAK.PARA: When in government Labor responded to that report by introducing our bill, as Senator Harradine said, in 1994. There was consultation on it. It was referred to a number of parliamentary committees, including the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. As a result, a number of amendments were made to the 1994 bill. That bill lapsed and now, of course, we have this particular bill, which in many respects is little different from the 1994 bill. If anyone wants evidence to that effect, they can compare the second reading speech of this Attorney‐General with the second reading speech attached to the bill in 1994.

As I said, we will give general support to this legislation, but we have some concerns about it. There are some differences between the 1994 bill and the 1996 bill. We have some concerns about this particular bill, and we will be moving some amendments.

The first concern is in respect to the definition of a legislative instrument—what constitutes a legislative instrument. The 1996 bill adopts an inclusive definition. The 1994 bill provided an exhaustive definition. By being inclusive, the 1996 bill generally encompasses instruments that come within the scope of the 1994 bill. However, the 1996 bill requires those instruments to have a `legislative character', whereas the 1994 bill merely required them to be `binding in their application'.

Whilst the 1996 bill is less precise in its application, the definition is, as I said, broadly consistent with the intent of the 1994 bill and, to the extent that there is a discrepancy between the bills, the 1996 bill is likely to capture a broader range of instruments than the former one.

We have some concerns that this broader and less precise definition may give rise to potentially extensive and expensive litigation as to what is or what is not a legislative instrument. As many senators would know, the legal textbooks are littered with cases that have sought to clarify this often very fine and technical distinction.

We do not wish to see necessary dedicated legislation frustrated as a result of such litigation. Further, the costs of such litigation will be borne not only by government but by those that the government claims it wants to assist, and particularly small business.

We are concerned about this, and this particular extension to the definition, but we do say at this stage that this matter is one that will be monitored by us and will be highlighted as a key issue for examination when the bill is reviewed in three years time.

I will now move to the first of our amendments, which goes to the question of Attorney‐General's certificates. The 1996 bill picks up a provision of the 1994 bill which allows the Attorney to issue a certificate to the effect that an instrument is not legislative in character. The 1994 bill provided for parliamentary review and disallowance of decisions by the Attorney‐General so certifying. It excluded review, including under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977. The 1996 bill removes the ability for parliament to review the decision but makes it subject to judicial review under the AD(JR) Act.

The report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on the 1994 bill recommended that parliamentary review be maintained. This report and recommendation has been supported by some government backbenchers, including Senator O'Chee, who was then Chair of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances.

Given the difficult legal issues surrounding whether an instrument is legislative in character, the Labor Party believes that it would be inappropriate to leave these matters for judicial review alone. We believe this because, firstly, what we are concerned about here is an expression by parliament as to the character of an instrument having force in its own right. We recognise that the history of the legislative executive distinction is as much one of practice as it is of settled law, and that to remove the legislature from this evolving process is to ignore the history of the development of common law in this area. We think the parliament does have a role to play in the actual characterisation of the instruments that we are talking about and, as a consequence, that it should maintain an interest and role in the process.

Secondly, we recognise that judicial review of a decision by the Attorney may be costly. It will be inaccessible, and will become even more costly and inaccessible, particularly for ordinary Australians to pursue a particular decision. Parliamentary review, of course, provides another avenue for consideration of this decision and, more often than not, it is a less costly one.

The Attorney has argued that parliamentary review may be inappropriate as the issue is ultimately one for judicial determination. But, let's face it, a lot of the decisions that we are taking here could ultimately be ones for judicial determination, but the parliament does not resile from having a role to play in respect of so many decisions that could and do ultimately flow on to the judicial parts of our system.

Under our proposal, it is likely that it would be the Attorney of the day and not an individual citizen who would be most likely to challenge such a determination by the parliament. For practical or political reasons, the Attorney might elect not to do so. An Attorney, of course, would want to be reasonably sure of his or her prospects of success before incurring the cost of such a legal challenge. We think it is better if such a dispute be resolved wherever possible between the arms of government rather than having ordinary citizens put to the expense of a legal challenge.

I note, in this context, that the 1994 bill expressly excluded judicial review of a certificate issued by the Attorney. The House of Representatives standing committee review of the legislation rightly pointed out the anomaly that, whilst the review of the AD(JR) Act was not available, the bill did not exclude review of a decision to issue a certificate pursuant to a prerogative writ under the original jurisdiction of the High Court or section 39B of the Judiciary Act.

In retrospect, we did have an unsatisfactory situation in the 1994 bill, and it was a situation which acted as an unnecessary barrier to the legitimate challenge to the validity of these certificates. As I have said, we are moving these amendments today not only to support the inclusion of the ADJR review but also to maintain parliamentary review of an Attorney‐General's decision.

I now move on to consultation coverage. The 1996 bill extends the range of instruments upon which consultation must be sought so as to include not only those legislative instruments which directly affect business but also those which have a significant indirect effect on business.

I note that the 1994 bill limited the application of the consultation mechanism to legislative instruments that had a direct effect. The limitation was proposed so that time could be given to assess the effectiveness of consultation mechanisms before consideration was actually given to extending the range of legislative instruments to which they apply. The 1996 bill is not inconsistent with that approach, although it is undoubtedly more adventurous, and we support these changes.

In respect of the consultation process, part 3 of the 1996 bill proposes a two‐stage review process overseen by the prescribed regulatory review body, which I understand will be the Office of Regulation and Review. This body must certify the adequacy of consultation on a legislative instrument. The first stage requires that comment be sought from representative bodies of those affected. This is to be conducted prior to development of the legislative instrument. The second stage requires public advertisement and occurs after the legislative instrument is developed. The 1996 bill also makes consultation decisions subject to review under the AD(JR) Act.

This process will be considerably more onerous than the one‐stage post‐development consultation process required under the 1994 bill. The 1994 bill excluded ADJR review of the consultation process. Whilst this process is more onerous, it is submitted on our part that it should be supported as representing best practice. However, ADJR review of that mechanism could—and we should note this—be used by any organised lobby as a means to frustrate the making of necessary legislative instruments. I think the government should bear this in mind as their legislation takes effect.

In this context, it is noted that the ability to frustrate the development of an instrument is somewhat more limited because of a failure to consult in compliance with part 3 of the bill, but does not affect the ultimate validity of a legislative instrument. Notwithstanding this, I think it is fair to say that the ability to frustrate the development of an instrument by this means should not be understated.

As noted, the 1994 bill excluded ADJR review of the consultation process. However, such a provision would not prevent judicial review of that process because of the availability of common law administration review, which is, of course, protected through the original jurisdiction of the High Court under the constitution and section 39B of the Judiciary Act. We do have some concerns with this particular proposal but, as I said earlier, we will not be opposing these changes.

I move now to the second set of Labor amendments: Labor amendment 5 which goes to the legislative instrument proposal. The 1996 bill generally widens the information that must be included in a legislative instrument proposal. The so‐called LIP will now contain a fuller analysis of the options available to achieve the purpose underlying a legislative instrument and the relative merits of alternative approaches. A LIP is required to take into account the indirect social and economic costs and benefits of a proposal. However, in detailing an inclusive list of matters that need to be taken into account, the government has not listed environmental matters, as were listed in the 1994 legislation. I note that this particular change does not necessarily exclude the consideration of environmental matters but is symbolically very significant. It is another indication that this government does not take environmental and social concerns as seriously as it should.

We believe the parliament should explicitly refer to environmental concerns as a matter to be taken into account in the drawing up of a legislative instrument proposal. As a consequence, our amendment will not limit the generality of other matters that a decision maker may decide to take into account but will explicitly include environmental matters.

The next area where we have proposed amendments is consultation exemptions. Here there are a number of changes between the 1994 bill and the 1996 bill on the range of matters for which exemption from consultation may be granted. For instance, the 1996 bill does not provide for exemptions where, one, a legislative instrument is required urgently, two, significant or comparable public consultation on the instrument has already occurred, three, notice of the instrument would give an unfair advantage to particular individuals and, four, the Attorney‐General certifies that public consultation would not be in the public interest.

Instead, the 1996 bill does provide for a range of exemptions where, for instance, the instrument is required in the interests of national security, in which case no certification by the Attorney‐General is required. The instrument is an airworthiness directive. The instrument is a commencement proclamation. The decision maker proposes to make a 12‐month temporary legislative instrument or the regulatory review body certifies that the LIP is adequate and otherwise waives part 3 consultation requirements where no such consultation is required by the enabling legislation, or agreement is comparable, or the costs of complying with part 3 outweigh the benefits to be obtained by the instrument. We believe that the 1996 bill is too restrictive in some cases and is open for abuse in others. Accordingly, we propose an alternative regime that accepts a number of the above changes whilst modifying others.

Firstly, we believe that an exemption should be available where the instrument is urgently required or where notice would give an unfair advantage to individuals. However, such an instrument should only have a 12‐month temporary operation and should be certified by the regulatory review body as being necessary. Secondly, the exemptions for prior, significant or comparable public consultation should be retained, but we believe there should be a requirement that the regulatory review body certify that such consultation has indeed taken place. This will provide a central checking mechanism, thereby helping to prevent errant departments from getting around the consultation requirements.

Thirdly, the public interest tests, we believe, should be retained, thus eliminating the need for specific national security and airworthiness exemptions. In our amendment, we have included both these matters in a list of matters included within but not limiting the public interest test. We are concerned that, given the broad effect of this bill on legislative instruments, we do not wish to prejudice matters for which the public interest would militate against consultation pursuant to the bill.

Fourthly, we do support the exemption of commencement proclamations and, fifthly, the exemption for 12‐month temporary instruments should otherwise be removed. There should be no need beyond those that I have already outlined for a temporary legislative instrument to be created. A provision of this nature is, we believe, open to widespread abuse. Finally, we believe the power of the regulatory review body to limit the consultation required should be retained as set out in the bill.

We have further amendments, for instance in respect to disallowance exemptions. The 1996 bill disallowance exemptions are similar to those contained in the 1994 bill, with three exceptions. These are three additional types of instruments which they exempt. They are certificates by the attorney extending the sunset period, proclamations under section 5 of the Flags Act and proclamations made under the Quarantine Act.

We support the exemptions of the Attorney‐General's certificates. The exemption for proclamations under section 5 of the Flags Act will also be supported. However, in respect of the Quarantine Act, it is actually unclear as to why legislative instruments should be exempted from disallowance in this respect. The breach of such proclamations can give rise to considerable criminal penalties and we believe should not be included. In doing so, we note the view of Senator O'Chee who agrees with us in respect to this. Both Senator O'Chee and the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills have raised concerns about the exclusion from disallowance of legislative instruments that arise under a national scheme of legislation. A similar exemption was contained in the 1994 bill. We believe that this exemption should, however, remain and we accept the government's position here.

Early backcapturing is another area where we support the government but, in respect of non‐legislative instruments and sunsetting, we do have a range of amendments. I do not think there is enough time for me to go through them at this particular stage, but I could speak to those in the committee stage.

In conclusion, as I said at the outset, we support the introduction of the bill. We have a number of amendments to it. Much of the bill is similar to the bill introduced in 1994. We believe some of the amendments the government has made can be supported at this stage but, as I have set out to explain in a number of areas, we do have concerns. We will be moving amendments in accordance with the statements I have made in this particular stage of the debate.

I will finish here. I do not know whether it is opportune for us to go back to the previous legislation. Senator Brown is not in the chamber, so maybe it is not. Maybe we can continue with the second reading debate of this bill and return to the telecommunications interception bill later on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —A key component of the rule of law is accessibility to those rules, consistency in their application and transparency and control over their development. Last Friday, Chief Justice Brennan in his `State of the judicature' address stated the following:

SPEECH.PARA: If we are to be governed by the rule of law, we must have a judicature to administer it. The characteristics of that Judicature reflect the functions it is charged to perform. First, it must be a Judicature that is and is seen to be impartial, independent of government and of any other centre of financial or social power, incorruptible by prospects of reward or personal advancement and fearless in applying the law irrespective of popular acclaim or criticism. Second, it must be a competent Judicature: there must be judges and practitioners who know the law and its purpose, who are alive to the connection between abstract legal principle and its practical effect, who accept and observe the limitations on judicial power and who, within those limitations, develop or assist in developing the law to answer the needs of society from time to time. Third, it must be a judicature that has the confidence of the people, without which it loses its authority and thereby loses its ability to perform its functions. Fourth, it must be a judicature that is reasonably accessible to those who have a genuine need for its remedies.

The Australian Democrats wish to associate themselves with the sentiments expressed by Chief Justice Brennan and indeed with the whole tenor of his speech delivered in Melbourne last Friday. The learned chief justice has, I believe, touched on many of the values which should underpin the bill we are about to debate.

The bill before us today represents a significant improvement in the law‐making processes of this country. I wish to publicly commend the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) and this government for its introduction. I know it has a long cross-party history in its development and this government is now bringing it in. I and my party commend you for it.

In essence, the bill seeks to reform the procedures for making, scrutinising, publishing, amending and repealing subordinate legislation—in effect, the machinery of Australian government. It will do this by defining more clearly and comprehensively the forms of subordinate legislation subject to parliamentary review and disallowance; establishing a single register of delegated legislation with legislative instruments only being enforceable if they are on the register; introducing public notice and consultation procedures for changes to delegated legislation affecting business; providing for the backcapture of existing subordinate legislation and placement on the register; introducing automatic sunsetting provisions requiring all legislative instruments to be reviewed every five years; providing parliamentary scrutiny of all forms of delegated legislation with each instrument to be tabled in each house of parliament within six days of registration; and, hopefully, providing a major incentive for the other eight governments in Australia to follow suit. That is of profound importance to Australians.

However, the Australian Democrats do have concern with allowing the Attorney-General to issue a certificate in specified circumstances to clarify the nature of an instrument. By far though, in the main, the Democrats applaud these initiatives and will be supporting the bulk of the bill. However, we are concerned that the efficacy of the bill and the all‐important principles underlying it will be unnecessarily undermined by those exemptions and qualifications the government has put in, and we think that the amendments before the Senate should in fact improve that situation.

Having praised you, however, I must focus in my speech on the second reading on our main areas of concern. The first I have already mentioned, and that is the certification by the Attorney-General. The ability of the Attorney-General to certify whether an instrument is legislative or not means that, if the Attorney‐General certifies that an instrument is not legislative, parliament has no powers at all to deal with the instrument. As Senator O'Chee, who is a recognised parliamentary authority on these matters, pointed out in his report, this will mean:
. . . the executive can then make laws it likes under that particular provision without Parliament even knowing, far less having the opportunity to disallow the instrument.
He went on to say:
. . . this power represents a serious diminution of the rights of Parliament.

That is an exceptionally serious statement to make, particularly by a member of the government. Senator O'Chee is, in this instance, spot on. In view of his comments, we will then be pleased to receive his support when a division is called on those amendments that will mitigate his concerns.

Our next concern relates to national schemes of legislation. Last year's working party of representatives of scrutiny of legislation committees throughout Australia conclud ed that `effective parliamentary scrutiny has been threatened by the rise of national schemes of legislation which emerged from bodies such as COAG and various ministerial councils'. These schemes are becoming increasingly important and it is appropriate that parliament be able to scrutinise such instruments. Therefore, we look forward to those amendments which deal with national schemes of legislation. I think that is in Senator Colston's amendments.

We are concerned that the bill excludes quarantine act proclamations from disallowance, although not from tabling. This exemption was introduced in the House of Representatives as a government amendment. Senator O'Chee argues that, as breaches of these proclamations incur serious penalties, they should be subject to disallowance.

Our next concern is the bill does not apply to instruments providing for the terms and conditions of Commonwealth employees. It is intended that those instruments will not even be tabled in parliament. This exemption includes determinations from the Remuneration Tribunal which at present are subject to full parliamentary allowance or disallowance.

Our next concern is the bill's formal consultation process will apply only to matters affecting business. This bill sets up a fairly extensive formal consultation process for legislative instruments `likely to have a direct, or substantial indirect, effect on business'. The bill lists the enabling legislation to which this process will apply. Other legislative instruments will be subject to the same process only `if the rule‐maker considers that the procedures are appropriate', which seems to be a quite wide discretion granted.

We think this is an unnecessary bias in favour of consulting with business. Some crucial pieces of enabling legislation are conspicuous by their absence from the bill—the Social Security Act, for example. It should be noted, however, that many major pieces of enabling legislation dealing with the environment are included in the bill, presumably on the basis of their impact upon business.

Consultation is specifically not required under the bill where the instrument is not likely to have an effect on business. Instru ments which give effect to the following specific budget decisions are also expressly excluded from the consultation process, such as decisions proposing to repeal, impose or adjust a tax, fee or charge, decisions proposing to confer, revoke or alter an entitlement or decisions proposing to impose, revoke or alter an obligation.

The bill contains no power to amend legislative instruments. We think that is a concern. The inability of the Senate to amend regulations or disallowance instruments has been a source of frustration for the Democrats. This bill does not alter that situation sufficiently and we believe still frustrates the effective role of the Senate.

This may sound a dry topic to those who are listening, but I remind them that these instruments affect Australians as much as laws do, and maybe more so in cases. There are over 100 different types of legislative instruments in Australia. Australians are inextricably subjected to literally thousands of pieces, rules, regulations and ministerial decisions which permeate their daily lives. We have come to call these rules and regulations delegated or subordinated legislation. We need them. There is a very good reason for them.

Parliament is the supreme law making authority in this country. It is charged not only with making laws but also with supervising and scrutinising those powers it bestows on the executive arm of government, on the administration of government and on the executive's instrumentalities for it is the parliament, notably the Senate, which represents the people and holds the executive accountable.

As any member of parliament and as any senator will attest, the sheer volume of delegated legislation—in recent years that volume has been considerable—has meant that a number of democratic concerns need to be restated and in some instances reinvigorated. When I speak of democratic concerns, I refer to the long‐held belief of the Australian Democrats that the continued legitimacy of government in this country can be maintained only if we get progressive, participative, representative democracy and if the essentials of democracy are adhered to. In the broadest terms, this means that the laws the citizens of this country are subject to must be accessible by them and must be subject to parliament's purview.

At a seminar in 1990 conducted by the Commonwealth Attorney-General's Department it was suggested that all subordinate legislation was in effect secret or hidden legislation due to the fact that it does not usually enter the public arena until after it has come into force. The government is attempting to address this. As I said, we do welcome the government's efforts in this regard. Clearly, the pile of red tape that ensues with regulations may have the effect of burying and concealing the laws to which citizens are subject. In any event, inaccessibility does not enhance the operation of the rule of law in this country.

I would like to flag that the Democrats will be moving amendments with regard to gender‐specific and relationship‐specific language. As I have said in previous debates, the Democrats are of the view that the time has long past in public discourse and especially in the letter of the law when sexist or relationship specific language could be used. The effect would be to discriminate and to disenfranchise sections of the Australian community. Our amendments will reflect a non-gender‐specific and non-relationship‐specific requirement in the registration of future legislative instruments.

I hope the Senate will be supporting our amendments. I flag to those parties who have put up amendments—the government, the Labor Party, Senator Colston and others—that we are likely to be supporting the bulk of those.

TALK.START.PARA: —As other speakers have indicated, the Legislative Instruments Bill 1996 has had a long gestation and substantial scrutiny by the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. The chairperson of that committee tabled a report in the Senate on 21 November 1996. The committee has produced a good analysis of the benefits and shortcomings of the proposed legislation.

BREAK.PARA: As Senator O'Chee indicated in his report, the changed procedures in this bill generally improve the ability of parliament to scrutinise delegated legislation. This is to be both applauded and encouraged. As always, however, there are some concerns in relation to certain aspects of the bill as it currently stands. I will discuss some of these key issues.

Firstly, I have a great concern about clause 8 in Part 1 of the bill which provides the Attorney‐General with the ability to effectively exempt certain regulations from parliamentary scrutiny. Senator O'Chee has been oft quoted so far in this debate, so I will continue the trend. He stated in his report on this bill:
If the Attorney certifies that the instrument is not legislative then parliament has no powers at all in respect to that instrument.
Senator Murray indicated then that the executive would be able to make any laws without parliament even knowing. Senator O'Chee went on to say:
The power of the Attorney to give conclusive certificates, reviewable only in the procedural formalities, is a serious diminution of the rights of parliament.

We have to understand here that this is not just a technical issue. There may well be a case where the nature of these instruments becomes an increasing problem. We have seen the figures from the Bills Digest which indicate that we have got a growth from 1982‐1991 of 703 to 1,645 instruments, so it is a growing problem. We may well have, at some stage, a High Court challenge on the nature of law making and the nature of the separation of powers. It is not a fanciful scenario.

If that happened, the problems we are having between the states and the Commonwealth government in relation to taxes would probably pale into insignificance in relation to all of the laws accompanied by such instruments and the complexity of going to each of the laws and trying to deal with them, if the nature of law making and instrument making is challenged in the High Court at some stage because of the problem with the constitution. Just think of what we could be doing. At this stage we have to try and avoid a situation where that might happen in the future.

As far as Senator O'Chee's comments in relation to this bill are concerned, I probably could not have said it better myself. I will be moving, in the committee stage of the bill, to oppose clause 8 in part 1 of the bill. Whilst I will be commenting further in the committee stage, it should be noted here that this is one of the most important aspects of the bill. The parliament must have the ability to properly scrutinise the activities and decisions of the executive. Failure to put in place proper mechanisms to facilitate that scrutiny could only be seen as a major attack on democracy in this country. As I say, if at some stage that is challenged in a constitutional manner in the High Court, we are going to have a real problem on our hands.

Secondly, I have some concerns in relation to part 3 of this bill which covers consultation before making legislative instruments. I was delighted to see specific acknowledgment of the need to consult before delegated legislation is drafted. However, my optimism was dashed when on further examination I discovered that not only is this consultation limited to legislative instruments likely to have a direct and substantial effect on business, but the proposal is to focus on the social and economic costs and benefits of each such option without consideration of such things as environmental aspects. I will be moving amendments to rectify these limitations. We cannot as a parliament say only certain things require community consultation when we look at the frustration that is already building in the community about such things.

Thirdly, I am concerned about the provision in clause 61, subclause (7), which prevents the disallowance of legislative instruments in relation to the establishment or operation of an intergovernmental body or a scheme involving the Commonwealth and one or more states. Again, as Senator O'Chee stated in his report to the Senate, these schemes which involve the Commonwealth and states and territories are likely to become more important and it would seem to be quite fundamental that parliament should scrutinise this legislation. I will be moving to have this subclause deleted during the committee stage of the bill.

Subclause (8) of clause 61 also contains an exemption from disallowance with respect to proclamations under certain sections of the Quarantine Act 1908. There appears to be no rational explanation for the decision to provide this particular exemption and consequently I will also be moving to oppose this subclause.

Finally, I am concerned that certain instruments in relation to the terms and conditions of employment of persons employed by the Commonwealth, by Commonwealth statutory authorities or by government business enterprises, or as members of the Defence force or the Australian Federal Police, are to be incorporated in this bill as instruments that are not legislative instruments and consequently not disallowable by the parliament.

I will be moving to oppose this provision in schedule 1 of the bill during the committee stage. It is a very dangerous thing, if you think about the current situation where more and more of what we do in parliament ends up being confused with business commercial‐in‐confidence, more and more outsourcing, and so on. The parliamentary scrutiny must remain in relation to such things and the independence of the Public Service must be maintained. It is very important and should not be underestimated.

In conclusion, therefore, I wish to restate the commitment of the Greens to the principle that the parliament has the right and the responsibility to properly scrutinise the activities and decisions of the executive. Delegated legislation is a reality in modern public administration and unfortunately, as I mentioned before, an increasing reality. The increasing level of delegated legislation has created the necessity for better systems and structure for the proper scrutiny of these instruments, not worse. I trust that the Senate will agree to the amendments that I have foreshadowed and that I notice other honourable senators have foreshadowed in order to facilitate that scrutiny.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —The title of the bill that the Senate is discussing at the moment is the Legislative Instruments Bill 1996 . That is enough to turn anybody off and people can go to sleep. But it is a very important piece of legislation because, at the least, it goes to the very heart of the separation of powers between the executive, the legislature and the judiciary. It is very important. I have said this year after year after year: it is most important that parliament does have proper oversight of executive government actions. That is part of our democracy. It is not proper for unelected persons to determine, without reference to parliament, issues which are legislative in character.

SPEECH.PARA: I am going to deliver a speech to the Senate on behalf of Senator Colston, who would have dearly liked to have been here today. He has had a longstanding interest and commitment to the work of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. He was a chairman of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee on two occasions for more than three years and deputy chairman since the 1996 election. He is able to speak with deep knowledge about the issues involved. Under those circumstances, it is my privilege to express his views to the Senate, which happen also to be mine and happen to be those generally of the committee.

The Regulations and Ordinances Committee is the committee which, on behalf of the rest of us in the Senate, scrutinises legislative instruments to ensure that they comply with the highest standards of parliamentary propriety and personal rights. The committee's annual reports and other reports to the Senate indicate that it has experienced considerable success in improving the quality of legislative instruments. Laws made by the executive under the authority of a parliamentary enactment can have the same effect upon individuals as the provisions in their enabling act.

Indeed, the effect upon individual members of the public may be more immediate because the parent act will often set out only the broad principles of a legislative scheme while the actual administrative details are filled in by legislative instruments made by ministers or by public servants. Let me say that this is no reflection on the work of public servants in this regard. They have a very important and onerous task to perform.

Because of this either immediate or long-term effect on individuals, it is important that any relevant umbrella legislation, such as the present Legislative Instruments Bill, should include the widest and strongest provisions for parliamentary scrutiny of these instruments. The existing provisions relating to legislative instruments are covered by only six pages of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 and three pages of the Statutory Rules Publication Act 1903. On the other hand, the bill that is currently before us is 113 pages long. Perhaps the most important question now is whether the rights of parliament and, therefore, the people are protected adequately by the proposed new scheme and whether the tenfold increase in statutory provision does not include any measures which dilute, diminish or otherwise derogate from those rights.

In this context, Senator Colston, who prepared this second reading stage speech, recalled that the previous 1994 version of this bill provided that only the whole of a regulation could be disallowed. Under that bill, it would not have been possible to disallow a single provision of an instrument. This serious reduction in the power of the parliament was fortunately detected by the Regulations and Ordinances Committee and has now been rectified in the current bill.

The committee does not oppose the bill. The chairman of the committee, Senator O'Chee, has to run around the course here today. I must say that I have read Senator O'Chee's speeches to the various fora on the particular areas, and I was most impressed. In respect of the current bill, Senator O'Chee reported to the Senate on 21 November 1996 and 23 June 1997 that the bill would generally improve parliamentary scrutiny of legislative instruments.

Senator O'Chee also pointed out, however, that there are several areas where the bill unacceptably removes from parliament what should be its natural and appropriate powers in respect of supervision of these instruments. Senator O'Chee's statements described these areas of concern and Senator Colston had circulated amendments which addressed these concerns and which the committee believes may be necessary to preserve the legislative supremacy of the parliament.

One of the most disturbing areas of concern is provisions in the bill and circulated government amendments which would remove from the operation of the bill instruments in respect of employment by the Commonwealth. These instruments include Remuneration Tribunal determinations and determinations at present made under the Public Service Act and the Defence Act. At present, these instruments are subject to varying degrees of parliamentary scrutiny.

In expanding further on these classes of instruments, Senator Colston has given some instances of problems which the committee has found. Remuneration Tribunal determinations set terms and conditions of employment for ministers, judges, senators, members of the House of Representatives, Public Service secretaries and heads and members of government statutory authorities. Under the government amendments, these determinations would not be subject to full parliamentary control. In addition, Public Service determinations and Defence determinations provide for allowances and other conditions of service for scores of thousands of Commonwealth public servants and members of the Australian Defence Force.

The Regulations and Ordinances Committee has in fact extracted some concessions from the government in respect of these instruments. The problem is that the government amendments relate to specific provisions which are likely to disappear with the proposed repeal of the present Public Service Act. I think that is an important question which we would need to consider in the committee stage. If this happens there will be no scrutiny at all of these instruments.

Government amendments also give some concessions in respect of the Remuneration Tribunal determinations but these are still excluded from the bill. The minister has informed the committee that the reason for this is that it would be `unfair', to use the minister's words, to expect the upper levels of Commonwealth employment to be subject to the full vigour of parliamentary scrutiny. My amendments will provide for legislative instruments affecting Commonwealth employment to be subject to the bill. When I say `my amendments', I mean Senator Colston's amendments, which I will be moving. I notice that one or two of them are similar to one or two of the opposition's amendments.

I will now give some details of actual industrial relations type instruments scrutinised by the committee. One such case which was the subject of a special report to the Senate involved the rights of Commonwealth public servants. Our late colleague Senator Olive Zakharov took an extremely close interest in this particular case. An official of the Department of Industrial Relations, with no meaningful consultation with those affected, made a determination which entrenched an injustice for some 30,000 members of the Australian Public Service. Also, the explanatory statement for the determination did not describe its nature or effect. The Regulations and Ordinances Committee ascertained that the official had made the determination in defiance of a recent report by the Merit Protection and Review Agency which advised that the position was unfair, inequitable and obviously anomalous.

When questioned by the late Senator Zakharov during a meeting with the committee, departmental officials revealed that they had known of the injustice for almost 20 years. I am pleased that this matter had a relatively satisfactory conclusion, with the Prime Minister and Minister for Finance agreeing to a one‐line budget appropriation of $4.1 million to right the injustice. This case underscores that it is essential that the Senate, through the committee, continues to scrutinise these instruments and that the bill should provide for this. Thus the Senate was not only exercising its audit and control function over executive government decisions but it was exercising its important function to uphold the rights of individuals.

The committee has experienced many other problems with instruments of this type, almost all of which were made or supervised by officials of the Department of Industrial Relations. The committee has scrutinised Remuneration Tribunal determinations and Defence determinations which were void for invalid subdelegation; Defence and Public Service determinations void for prejudicial retrospectivity; a Public Service determination void because its drafting did not reflects legislative intent; and Defence and Public Service determinations where the maker did not comply with the requirements of the enabling act.

One Public Service determination had a corrigendum attached with sticky tape, while another had handwritten alterations with no initials, date or any other identifying mark. Another was neither signed nor dated. In respect of one Remuneration Tribunal determination the minister advised the committee that, on the one hand, it could be considered invalid while, on the other hand, it could be valid. These are all problems of validity. As well, the Regulations and Ordinances Committee has found problems with the substantive provisions of many of these instruments. The committee therefore believes that it is important for the Senate to continue its supervision of this type of instrument.

In this brief outline that I have presented to the Senate on behalf of Senator Colston I have dealt with only one type of delegated legislation, namely, instruments dealing with the terms and conditions of Commonwealth employees. I know that honourable senators will consider these matters carefully, as they have always done in respect of this very important function of the Senate which deals with the rights and privileges of individuals and the rights and responsibilities and privileges of the Senate in respect of audit and control of executive government decisions and upholding individual rights.

There will be a number of amendments but, as other honourable senators said, the government should be commended for bringing forward the bill. There are a number of amendments that Senator Colston would like the committee to consider. The bill in general makes important changes to the ability of the Senate to scrutinise and, if the Senate wishes, to disallow legislative instruments. Many of the changes are beneficial. I do commend the government in respect of that.

BREAK.PARA: These changes will enhance the power of the Senate to supervise and control legislative instruments made by the executive. The beneficial changes include: an increase in the number and types of instruments subject to tabling and disallowance, many of which at present have no parliamentary oversight at all; legislative instruments to be tabled within six days instead of the present 15 days; statutory requirement to table explanatory statements; power to postpone disallowance motions for up to six months; backcapturing and sunsetting of legislative instruments, which will ensure continuing parliamentary review of legislative instruments.

The bill will also benefit the public by greater availability and access to legislative instruments and benefit the business community by mandatory consultation and impact assessment. The general thrust of the bill, therefore, will improve the position of the parliament and the public in relation to legislative instruments. Unfortunately, however, the bill includes a number of provisions which will diminish the role of the parliament in the new scheme, and it is these defects which Senator Colston's amendments and others that will be moved will address.

As we and the committee see it, there are four important defects in the bill. The bill provides for the Attorney-General to issue conclusive certificates as to whether a particular instrument is or is not legislative. Obviously, that is not a goer, and everybody knows it is not a goer. All we will have to do is say that those particular certificates should be subject to disallowance and that fixes that problem.

The bill excludes instruments which provide for national schemes of legislation—such as Corporations Law, the competition code, road transport reform and occupational, health and safety—from parliamentary disallowance. These schemes are likely to become more important, and it is inappropriate that parliament should not be able to scrutinise this legislation. Parliament should have the same option of disallowance of the instruments as it has over other legislative instruments, many of which are of far less consequence than national schemes. We are hearing more and more of national schemes, and I have the distinct feeling, which is supported in rather more technical terms by the Regulations and Ordinances Committee, that we are tending to lose control of those situations on behalf of those persons who elect us here.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like treaties.

—Exactly, like treaties, as Senator Murray interjects. That is why I was so happy to originate the move to have a treaties committee way back. Thankfully it was taken up by somebody else with a bit more clout, and now there is a committee.

BREAK.PARA: The bill excludes Quarantine Act declarations from disallowance. These declarations, which could severely disrupt the activities of individuals and businesses, provide for penalties of up to 10 years imprisonment and a fine of up to $100,000. The reason for excluding the declarations from parliamentary scrutiny is apparently that they are important and sensitive. This is, however, a reason in favour of disallowance, rather than the opposite.

The fourth major defect of the bill—an important defect in the bill, as the committee sees it—is that the bill at present provides expressly that regulations may exclude instruments providing for Commonwealth public sector conditions of employment from any parliamentary scrutiny at all. Following correspondence with the regulations and ordinances committee, the government has circulated amendments which go part of the way towards addressing this deficiency but in other ways makes the position worse. The amendments that will be moved by me on behalf of Senator Colston provide for full parliamentary scrutiny of these instruments and possible disallowance by either House.

I will not go into the details of it now as it is more appropriate to deal with those at the committee stage, but I do thank the work that has been done by the members of the regulations and ordinances committee over many years, including the fine work that Senator Colston has done on that committee. I do thank those members for continuing to work on behalf of the Senate in the best interests of our electors and, I believe, in the best interest of good governments of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin by congratulating the government for bringing forward the Legislative Instruments Bill 1996 and congratulating the previous government for being the St John the Baptist, as it were, to the present bill. In that context, since this bill has had its genesis over two governments of different colours, I congratulate the administrative laws branch of the Attorney‐General's Department, which has had the carriage of this legislation for some time now and has brought it forward to its present state.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a very good bill and, as speeches have indicated so far, it can be made better, and debate no doubt will ensure that it is made better. There are two matters which I will comment on later, if time arises—that is, the issue of the national schemes legislation and the issue of conclusive certificates.

It does, as Senator Harradine pointed out, seem a dry subject because it deals with process. Process is the means by which particular things are worked out so that a result is obtained from a beginning. A legal system depends upon process—the issuing of writs, the serving of a defence, the serving of interrogatories on the other side and discovery. It has probably changed since I was in the profession but, nevertheless, the issue of process is very important because it ensures that a right and fair result is obtained where it would not otherwise occur.

Process tends to be dry because you have to take step by step the journey you are going to go on. People like to get to the end of the journey suddenly. But process is a matter that is essential for the proper operation of our courts and it is essential for the proper operation of this place, the parliament. Parliament is still, in theory at least, the dominant force in this society and the force that ensures that fairness, that justice, that proper process, is carried out.

Over the years, parliament has become dominated by the executive. Mr Justice Brennan—as he then was; he is now the Chief Justice of the High Court—made that point very powerfully on 7 August 1990 in his Blackburn Lecture. I will quote Mr Justice Brennan because it is very pertinent to the present debate. He said:

The theory of responsible government which made the fate of an Executive Government dependent upon the confidence of the Parliament was, so to speak, turned on its head by the political dependence of the majority members of the Parliament on the Executive Government. Policy formulation became primarily an executive function. As the pressure on legislative time intensified a virtual monopoly over initiatives for legislation passed to the Executive Government.
Later in the speech, His Honour said:

As the wind of political expediency now chills Parliament's willingness to impose checks on the Executive and the Executive now has a large measure of control over legislation, the courts alone retain their original function of standing between government and the governed.

I think there is a lot of truth in what he says. What he is saying is that, in reality, parliament does not provide as good a check over the executive as might be desirable. That is a bad thing for democracy. That is what this bill that is before us today goes to remedying to some degree.

May I say in passing that His Honour was talking about the duty of the court to ensure that the proper operation of government, in the sense of the three arms of government, continues. It has been worrying to see in recent times how much the courts have been under attack because the courts, like parliament, like the executive itself, are necessary for us to live in a good society.

It is time that we the parliament, as one of the three arms of government, gave weight not only to the executive, which we do through the party system, but also to the courts. I think it is time that we as parliamentarians emphasised more and more the need for the courts to remain independent, the need for the courts to be attacked, yes, but attacked only in a proper way and attacked only in a fair way. Some of the attacks on the court that have been going on in recent times have been beyond that limit which is necessary to ensure that we have a proper government and a proper functioning society in this community.

BREAK.PARA: So I take this opportunity, as I hope others will over the Spring session, to ensure that the courts are vindicated. As the Chief Justice says, the courts do not have the ability to defend themselves as we in this chamber have the ability to defend ourselves. In any event, that would be a bad thing. Once the courts start taking on a partisan position—partisan in the sense of having to defend themselves from attack—then this very delicate system—and it is a very delicate system—begins to diminish. We should not see any of our great instruments of government diminished. They are parts of democracy.

The thing about democracy, of course, is that democracy is not efficient. Democracy is not the recent outcome of competition and it is not found in the marketplace. That is the problem: efficiency and competition and the marketplace are the gods of the moment. I think the difficulty we have with the way we are going round our social functioning at the moment is that we measure everything in those terms. We say, `Well, the courts and the parliament are not efficient. They don't enter into competition as they should, and they don't allow the marketplace to operate.' Of course they do not. If we allow these great pillars of society in which we live to diminish in any way, then we are in trouble.

What the Legislative Instruments Bill 1996 is doing is establishing a relationship between the executive and the parliament which will lead to greater fairness. As I said, there are things in it that are capable of improvement, and I hope those improvements will take place. This is not, in a sense, a party political debate because I think both parties have agreed that a bill like this ought to be brought forward and enacted. I think it is a debate that concerns our concept of what we ought to do as parliamentarians.

Senator Harradine has mentioned the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances—a committee that will have the most to do with this act. It has been a great committee over the years, and there have been some great people on it. In fact, I think the original idea of this bill came from some thinking by Senator Bob Collins, and it has been taken on since then. Senator Harradine has mentioned Senator Colston, and it would be ungracious not to mention him in this context, as well as everybody who has spoken so far. I know Senator Murray has a great appetite for seeing that the balance in society is such as to produce a good society. Senator Bolkus, the person leading off on this debate, has pointed out the opposition's position on this. Again, he is a person who has had much to do with establishing right relationships within society over the years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—Senator Harradine, you yourself have been constant, may I say, in taking up these matters that go to the democracy we live in and these issues of process. And if process is not there, you will not have a democratic system operating, because the way things are done is crucial to the proper outcomes that we need.

BREAK.PARA: The issue of national legislation is one that I do not think has been dealt with in the right way in this bill, because that is going to be excluded from the consideration of the parliamentary committees. Senator Bill O'Chee has done much work in this area, and so have people from the parliaments all around Australia. I think that that is an area that parliament must keep a part in, because it is going to become an area where more and more legislation is made.

Everybody knows what it is all about, but I will just put forward what happens. The various parliaments around Australia and the federal parliament itself come to agreement about certain issues. For example, the Corporations Law, which governs how companies operate in Australia, is the result of national legislation. So is much of the legislation that deals with censorship. It is going to become more and more apparent that this legislation is apposite and that therefore it will be made.

It is proper that parliaments around Australia have a say in this, particularly when that national legislation is going to be subordinate legislation, that is, legislation that is not made by parliament but made outside parliament by people who are unelected—as the expression has been used, not in any derogatory sense but as a matter of fact. It would be wrong and a serious flaw in this legislation if it were to go forward and take away the ability of parliament to look at these national schemes of legislation. It is just contradictory in terms. If parliament is the supreme legislative body, then how can it be kept away from some of the most vital areas in which legislation will take place?

On the issue of a conclusive certificate, that is something that the parliament should not deny itself. We are either responsible as members of parliament or we are not. If we are, then certainly we will be able to treat properly the subordinate legislation that comes before us. If we are not up to it, then we are going to be put out at the next election. After all, that is what democracy is all about: the ballot box. That is the test. If the people of Australia say, `You have treated subordinate legislation in a way that it should not have been treated. You were irresponsible', then the ballot box will decide. We have to have faith in the ballot box.

There is natural and—in a certain sense—proper inclination in the executive to keep things secret, because the executive does have to get things done and does have to be efficient, and it is a nuisance if people are going to supervise, as it were, everything the executive undertakes. But once you start to get to that position and once you start saying, `We'll leave out the process', then you get all sorts of problems. That would be a very bad thing.

The other point I want to make in this context is the very big issue of how far parliament should be able to look at commercial‐in‐confidence records. We can look at all sorts of things—whether we are going to go to war, whether we are going to build hospitals, whether we are going to send people to gaol for breaking the law—but commercial‐in‐confidence is beyond that. There is something magic in the phrase `commercial‐in‐confidence'. It is beyond argument. At estimates committees, people will say, `We will let you have a look at that document about the fact that we are about to sell off a part of Australia, but what we are not going to do is let you see the contract by which we got some microphones for the Senate chamber.' Somehow that has got a quality about it which is beyond argument and you cannot have a look at it. I just think that it is absurd, as seen in that statement. If parliament is what we say it is, then there should be an ability to look at that commercial‐in-confidence stuff.

I am not saying that parliament should simply ignore the proper rights of the executive, because it is a three‐tiered system of government and there are rights and powers that the executive should be able to exercise. I am saying that that proper distribution of power between parliament and the executive has been disturbed for a long time, and there is now an attempt to disturb it as between the executive and the courts. The courts are showing a lot more fight than parliament ever did. And so they should, because once the courts become, as it were, browbeaten, then God help us—and I use that clause advisedly.

This is a very big issue. We have had money bills, industrial relations bills and Telstra bills coming through—all of which were of great importance and were paid due regard to—but this is a bill which raises issues that are as important as, if not more important than, any of those.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I acknowledge the contributions made to this debate by Senator Bolkus, Senator Murray, Senator Margetts, Senator Cooney and Senator Harradine. As Senator Harradine said, the Legislative Instruments Bill 1996 goes to the heart of good governance. As speakers before me have indicated, it is an area in which most Australians will have little or no interest, but it is nonetheless an area which deals directly with their daily lives.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Cooney said, this is a matter that saw its origins in the former government, and it is a matter which this government sees as being extremely important. For that reason, the government continued with this bill, and that is why it is before the Senate today.

I acknowledge the work done by Senator Colston who has a number of amendments being put to the Senate via, I believe, Senator Harradine, and with his concurrence. Also, I acknowledge the fine work done by Senator O'Chee as chair of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee. I do not think people realise just how important the Senate Regulations and Ordinances Committee is, nor how important is the Senate Scrutiny of Bills Committee which Senator Cooney chairs. I believe those committees stand as watchdogs for the community in relation to legislation that comes before the parliament. I believe it is a remarkable task that is carried out by these committees. It is something which is somewhat unique to the Senate and something which is the envy of parliaments of other countries.

This bill has been the subject of a great deal of scrutiny. It has gone before a number of Senate and other committees and has had the full gaze of members of parliament, senators and expert witnesses. By necessity, the bill has been a compromise in relation to consultation procedures and exemptions, and to the application of consultative procedures to instruments affecting business, as well as to exemptions in certain areas such as quarantine and migration. This bill nonetheless increases significantly the accountability of the executive in the making of regulations and the scrutiny of those regulations. I believe that speakers today have acknowledged that.

The government accepts the rationale for some of the amendments that have been mentioned today, but the government cannot see its way clear to supporting a number of amendments, and we will be dealing with those amendments and the reasons for the government's course of action during the committee stage. Suffice to say, the government accepts the spirit in which those amendments have been put forward and that really we do have bipartisan or multiparty support for a bill of this sort, and that a bill of this sort will go to serving the people of this country and the good governance of this country. I believe it appropriate that I reserve comments in relation to the respective amendments to the committee stage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

BREAK.PARA: Motion (by Senator Ellison) agreed to:
That consideration of the bill in committee of the whole be made an order of the day for a later hour.

TITLE.XREF: TELECOMMUNICATIONS (INTERCEPTION) AND LISTENING DEVICE AMENDMENT BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.
The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Chair, I remind senators that we had an amendment being drafted by Senator Brown for the Greens. The thrust of that amendment, that there be a sunset provision, as I understood it from Senator Brown, was to allow for a period of time when members of the AAT would be used, and then that would expire at a given time.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand there has been some drafting in relation to that, and that officers from the department were in consultation with Senator Brown, but I am advised that the government is unable to support that amendment which will be shortly forthcoming. Perhaps the situation is now for Senator Brown to move his amendment. I see Senator Margetts is in the chamber; perhaps she could be of assistance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I could be of assistance; I will endeavour to be so. My understanding is that Senator Brown is ready—he has drafted his amendments. But the Australian Democrats have requested of him more time to consider the amendments. Our side is ready, but we are indicating out of deference to the concerns of the Democrats that we want more time. We request that more time be given.
—I regret that there seems to be some misunderstanding in communication. We would be quite happy to deal with it now.
—Firstly, I would like to move the amendments as circulated.
—I haven't seen them.
—I am sorry, I thought they had been circulated.
—Are they long ones? Would you like to read them out if they are not long ones?
—Yes, I will read them out. They read:

BREAK.PARA: (1) Page 2 (after line 14), after clause 2, insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 2A Cessation of operation of amendments made by certain items

PARA.TAB: The amendments made by items 6, 19, 20, 24, 25, 27 to 39 (inclusive), 47 to 50 (inclusive) and 52 of Schedule 1, Schedule 2 and items 1 to 8 (inclusive) and 11 to 13 (inclusive) of Schedule 3 cease to have effect at the end of 1999.

BREAK.PARA: (2) Clause 3, page 2 (line 16), omit "section 2", substitute "sections 2 and 2A".

The amendments will have the effect of instituting a sunset clause so that the amendments that the committee is accepting to enable officers of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to issue warrants for listening devices to be placed on the phones of citizens will be enacted for the next two years, but will cease to function then. It means, in effect, that the parliament will review the functioning of this new system, which the government and the Democrats have voted for, to enable non judges to issue warrants for listening devices to be placed on the phones of citizens.

TALK.START.PARA: —We haven't voted for it; you had better retract that.

—Senator Murray says they have not voted for it and has asked me to retract it. I will in so far as I am jumping the gun there. I am making the presumption that it will be voted for by the Democrats. He has raised my hopes that in fact they will vote against the amendments that they have supported, by voting against this bill in the third reading debate.

BREAK.PARA: The Greens are very concerned about the implications of breaking the time‐honoured system whereby no‐one less than a judge is required to issue a warrant to place a listening device on the phones of citizens. We accept that there are criminal activities that need to be brought to book and that there are good reasons for judges to issue a warrant to have a listening device placed on a phone to catch criminals. But quite clearly there are major civil liberty implications in a loosening of this system.

We have heard that there are, on average, two phone taps being applied in Australia per day, seven days a week, 365 days a year. That number is increasing. I am concerned that it will increase rapidly. We need to know that, where legal phone tapping is involved, an extremely good reason has been put—remember, this is done in secret—and that there is an adjudicator there who is highly qualified and has the confidence of the community in ascertaining whether the law enforcement authority has good reason for putting a listening device on a citizen's phone.

The amendments that have been accepted by the committee mean that, for the first time, it will not have to be a federal judge; it can be an Administrative Appeals Tribunal officer who is not a judge. There are 39 of them. What is more, we know from the debate in this committee that judges will be increasingly reticent about being approached to issue a warrant. The obvious conclusion is that not only will AAT officers be available to issue warrants, but also there will be a rapid transfer of applications from judges—who will increasingly refuse now there is a new option available—to the AAT officers. We will see a rapid increase in the number of warrants being issued by non judges as the number of warrants issued by judges drops.

What will be next? Is the government going to approach the parliament because of the burden placed on these 39 non judges in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to issue listening devices and say, `Look, we've now got to go to law court officers'? To make light of it, they might next ask that we accept law students as arbiters on this matter. We cannot make light of this because it is a very serious matter. The least we can do at this stage, with the Democrats having accepted the government's amendments or the government having accepted the Democrats' amendments, is put a review period on it. I hope that we will get the support of the Democrats. I thank Senator Bolkus, by the way, for talking over this matter at the outset. I think the least we can do in this place is to put a review period on this two years down the line.

When we were in committee earlier this morning, I asked Senator Ellison if he would give an outline to the committee of the qualifications of those people in the AAT who are not judges but who are going to, inevitably, be asked to issue phone tapping warrants as a result of the amendments to the legislation which we are dealing with here. I would like to hear what those qualifications are. It should be remembered that, whatever they are, we are in the process now of transferring this extraordinarily important arbitration, as to who should be listened in to and who should not, away from the safety of insisting that it be a judge. I seek leave to move both amendments together.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

BREAK.PARA: (1) Page 2 (after line 14), after clause 2, insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 2A Cessation of operation of amendments made by certain items

PARA.TAB: The amendments made by items 6, 19, 20, 24, 25, 27 to 39 (inclusive), 47 to 50 (inclusive) and 52 of Schedule 1, Schedule 2 and items 1 to 8 (inclusive) and 11 to 13 (inclusive) of Schedule 3 cease to have effect at the end of 1999.

BREAK.PARA: (2) Clause 3, page 2 (line 16), omit "section 2", substitute "sections 2 and 2A".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, I indicate that the government will not be supporting this amendment. The Greens have mentioned a two‐year sunset clause after which AAT members will no longer be able to issue warrants.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem we have is: who would issue the warrants after that stage? This is the problem that bedevils the whole situation: the judges have said that they will not, as a group, issue these warrants. They have said that they will only do this task whilst there is no alternative arrangement in place. Once there is an alternative arrangement in place, they will cease issuing warrants and that will be it. What we will have is a problem revisiting us in two years time.

The government cannot support this amendment. It is merely putting off the problem for a period of time, after which we will face the same problem again when the judges say, `We're not taking it back; we're not going to do it.'

In relation to qualifications, I understand that Senator Brown's office has been provided with the qualifications of the members of the AAT. I understand that, as at February this year, there were 87 members. That figure could be a little different because I believe there is a more current chart available. Suffice to say that it is in the region of 87, and I am advised that some 54 are not legally qualified. The pool that we are looking at here has a total number of 39. So those who are not qualified are not included in the pool. In relation to a deputy president, section 7 of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act states:

A person shall not be appointed as a Deputy President unless he is enrolled as a legal practitioner of the High Court, of another federal court or of the Supreme Court of a State or Territory . . . for not less than 5 years.
So that covers that aspect. It further states:
A person shall not be appointed as a senior member—
of the AAT—
unless he:
(a) is enrolled as a legal practitioner of the High Court, of another federal court or of the Supreme Court of a State or Territory and has been so enrolled for not less than 5 years; or
(b) has, in the opinion of the Governor‐General, special knowledge or skill relevant to the duties of a senior member.

That is a proviso in relation to a person as a senior member. In relation to those who are appointed as non‐presidential members—that is, other than senior members—the person has to be enrolled as a legal practitioner of the High Court, another federal court or a Supreme Court of a state or territory, and must have had experience of not less than five years at a high level in industry, commerce, public administration, industrial relations, the practice of a profession or the service of a government or an authority of government. They must have obtained a tertiary degree, after studies in the field of law, economics, public administration or some other field considered by the Governor‐General to have substantial relevance; or have, in the opinion of the Governor‐General, special knowledge or skill in relation to any class of matters in respect of which decisions may be made in the exercise of powers conferred under the act.

So section 7 of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act relates to the appointment of members of the AAT. In relation to the pool that the Attorney‐General will be drawing from, I will just seek advice on that. I will correct the number of members on the AAT that I mentioned previously as I have just received more up to date figures. Those figures are: presidential members, 15; deputy presidents, 10; senior members, 20; and ordinary members, 54. That is a total of 99, so the figure of 87 which I mentioned before was a bit out. This, of course, does not include the President of the AAT. The Attorney‐General would draw from a pool of only 39, not the whole 99. I am advised that, out of the pool of 39, only one member—a senior member—is not legally qualified.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the amendments moved by Senator Brown. I do not want to reopen the debate that we had yesterday. However, Senator Ellison said that they have got a problem in that the judges will not do this. Just briefly, the judges issued 740 or more warrants last year. The judges are doing it and, in terms of that problem, this has been something which has been floated through the Attorney‐General's Department for the last four or five years—which includes the term of the previous government. The previous government took the view that there was a balance which had to be struck, and that they were not going to be pushed into this in the same way that the judges are allegedly pushing this government into it now. That is just restating some of the facts of yesterday's debate.

BREAK.PARA: Are we talking here of a work to rule practice by the judges? Of course we are not. We are talking, in fact, of judges actually applying the law which has been passed by this parliament and a law which this parliament thought required a balance between protection of individuals and capacity for adequate law enforcement. Let's face it: if it were the High Court that was pushing this on the government, you would have neanderthals like the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer), the Premier of Queensland and others bagging them consistently.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that you withdraw.
—I withdraw.
—Thank you, Senator.

—The other thing that needs to be said about this is that we really are talking about a large and fundamental extension from judicial officers of federal jurisdiction to members of the AAT. Without wanting to disparage members of the AAT, we have gone through this debate before, as I said yesterday. I invoked then the fact that the balance was struck in a bipartisan way some 14 years ago. If I were a law enforcement agency, I would be looking to judicial officers to issue these warrants, as opposed to the broader extension that the government has in fact got through this parliament. I would be looking for certainty and predictability.

BREAK.PARA: There is some concern amongst some law enforcement agencies about this measure from the government. Senator Ellison says that this is not good enough and asks, `What will we do in two years time?' There is a fair chance, Senator Ellison, that you will not be making the decision in two years time. There could very well be a change of government and that is something you have to take into account. But two years is long enough for any government to think about what they do if this legislation does lapse in two years time. One option, of course, is to come back here and say, `We will extend it,' and commence the parliament at that stage. Another option is to give the Federal Court some extra resources to do the work that they should be doing and to do it adequately. It is not good enough to drain their resources to give them more work to do and then to come in here claiming that there is a problem.
