What this measure does is, I think, very healthily put the government on notice in respect to a decision taken yesterday which is too broad and really does not balance the protection of innocent people adequately. We passed it yesterday and my real concern last night was that, in giving the government a blank cheque in this matter, we do not and we have not imposed sufficient scrutiny on them as to how it will be administered. Senator Murray tried yesterday, but we did have some practical problems with what he was trying to do. I understood and supported what he was trying to do but how he was trying to do it created a bit of a problem.

So this measure puts the heat on the government to administer the scheme over the next two years and to administer it properly. We would be concerned, for instance, at how the Attorney‐General was to approach this. The sentiment very strongly of this parliament is that only judges should do it where judges can do it. Some of us have a stronger view than that, but I think it is fair to say that the bottom line of the parliament is that it should be judges first and primarily.

This particular measure of a sunset clause keeps the Attorney honest. He has to come up, particularly, with the amendment moved by the Democrats in respect of statistics and produce those statistics to this parliament. He has to show that he has been serious about ensuring that judicial officers have taken a primary role in issuing intercept warrants—not junior officers and not the juniors amongst the AAT appointments. The best way to ensure that is to keep the government on notice that, unless they administer the scheme properly and fairly and balance considerations of human rights with law enforcement, then they will not get endorsement for this measure in two years time. So I welcome the fact that Senator Brown is moving this.

I do not think it is a problem for the government. Senator Ellison, if you were really serious about this, if you showed some flexibility you would actually be accepting this measure this morning and be moving on to the next item of debate. Two years is a long time for you to think about a matter like this. I know the Attorney‐General takes a lot of time considering matters and that there is a huge stack in his office, but no‐one would suggest it would take him two years, if he was still in the job, to consider what to do with this.

Your options are to prove that you have done it properly, to come back here and seek more resources not just for the Federal Police but for the courts. In the meantime, we could get some view of how the scheme has been administered, both from the law enforcement side and from the civil liberties side.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Brown of the Tasmanian Greens unfortunately misrepresented our position. I hope that is not going to be a characteristic of how you evaluate the procedures and debate. If I can recap, because I am aware you were not involved in the entire debate, every party and every independent within the Senate voted for the Telecommunications (Interception) and Listening Device Amendment Bill 1997 to be considered in the committee stage. The Democrats put up 10 detailed amendments, of which one got through, as amended. Labor put up amendments which had the effect of splitting the bill, with which the Democrats did not agree. We thought the bill should be evaluated in the whole. We have still got to get to the third reading which is the stage when we will decide and indicate whether we are going to vote for or against the bill. We have given no indication, either in the debate on the second reading or in other debate as to our final voting position.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the intercession of Senator Brown has been extremely helpful on amendment 663. We think the sunset clause provision is desirable. I would remind senators that the Senate Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills, on which both Senator Cooney and I sit, recommended such a procedure but it was the consideration of the parties which have put amendments up in advance of the debate that they should rather take an absolute position otherwise. However, the absolute position has been defeated. So I commend you for your amendment, Senator Brown, and indicate that the Australian Democrats, like the Labor Party, will support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope the government will support this as well because, for the reasons outlined, it is a very good procedure. It is something of a leap into the dark to be going beyond judges for the issuing of warrants to allow the authorities to be able to place a phone tap, a listening device, on the phone lines of citizens. What concerns me again is that the bulk of work in issuing those warrants will be going from the federal judges, where it has always been, to non‐judges in the Administra tive Appeals Tribunal. We have heard from Senator Ellison for the government that one of those persons in the AAT is not legally qualified. He is not a legal practitioner.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Ellison interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —`Only one,' says Senator Ellison. Already we have gone from insisting that there be a federal judge arbitrating on whether a warrant—remember these warrants are sought in secret—is granted to phone tap Australian phone lines. Now suddenly we are finding that persons issuing warrants will not even have to be legally trained. I find that most alarming.

SPEECH.PARA: I fortunately do not know who the specific members of the AAT are that we are referring to, so I feel free to comment on the principle. It is a very serious matter indeed that the chamber is considering a government request—I think Senator Murray will agree that this has Democrat endorsement—that officers of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, at least one of whom we know is not legally qualified, are suddenly being asked to approve secret listening devices being placed on the phones of citizens without their knowledge because there will be legitimate circumstances for doing that in the pursuit of criminals.

Suddenly we go from having an insistence on federal judges to having people without legal qualifications being given that role. I object to that. It is not a light matter; it is a very serious matter. Moreover, the number of requests going to these officers is going to be greater than that which have been going to the judges, simply because there are far fewer of them.

When this legislation goes through, the judges are going to say, `We now have the out. We are not going to deal with these requests for a warrant to allow phone tapping.' So, suddenly, we are going to have non‐judges, including one person without any legal qualifications although no doubt well qualified in other ways. Senator Ellison listed those qualifications: you can be qualified in economics, that will do; you can be qualified in some other matter, that will do; you need to have spent five years somewhere on a board or on a committee, that will do—in other words, almost anything will do.

We have to be very alarmed about the direction in which this is heading. I feel very concerned about the prospect of these changes getting through the Senate. I feel that even the sunset clause is not going to be enough, but it is the best we can do. That is why the Greens are moving it. I am pleased to hear that the Labor Party and the Democrats are going to support it. It is a vital amendment because a review by this Senate is essential if the government and Democrat majority is to have sway in allowing AAT officers, including nonlegally qualified persons, to be responsible for issuing in secret taps on citizens' phones.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to a deliberate misrepresentation by Senator Brown of the Tasmanian Greens. The Australian Democrats have not signalled their support for this bill.
—That is not a point of order, Senator Murray.

—I stand on what I have said. The test will come with the vote. But I, for one, am not going to vote in support of legislation that allows this major change in the protection of civil liberties that Australians should expect from their parliament to go through without far better reason than the government has brought forward.

—I noted the speech by Senator Brown of the Tasmanian Greens. I must profess that, when someone grandstands on issues which are important to Australians and, in the process, tries as usual—in contrast to your colleague from the WA Greens—to smear us wrongly about our attitude and our approach to these things, I find it profoundly irritating. It does not win you a friend from me, nor does it win you friends from anywhere else.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to correct a point that Senator Brown made. He said that non‐lawyers will be asked to perform this task. That is a misrepresentation of the situation. Indeed, what Senator Brown has forgotten to say is that the person has to be nominated by the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) before that person can have the power to issue a warrant. At the moment, only one of those people in the pool who can be nominated is a nonlegal practitioner. That does not mean to say that the Attorney‐General will say to that person who is a nonlegal practitioner that he or she can issue warrants.
—Are you saying that they won't?

—The situation, Senator Brown, is that you said that non‐legal practitioners would be asked to issue warrants. I heard that plainly. That is not the case. It is only those people who are nominated by the Attorney-General who are to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind you that, in relation to the part-time senior members and ordinary members, the Attorney-General is restricted from nominating a person who is not legally qualified. So the only point that you could possibly make—and you have sought to make out that we are going to have non‐legally qualified people issuing warrants—is in relation to the full-time senior member at the moment who is a non‐legal practitioner. That can only be on the basis that the Attorney-General chooses to nominate that person. You would have to wait to see whether the Attorney-General does that. I just wanted to correct the misunderstanding that you had of the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —If a person has been put in a pool of people who can be selected, you would have to be fairly reasonably assured that that person may have a chance of being selected at one stage. Why would you put a person in a pool of people to be selected and say, `But they are not actually going to be picked'? It does not hold water. This is the circumstance now. We have a person without legal qualifications on there now. We have no indication what will happen in the future. We have nothing to indicate that something will or will not be done.

SPEECH.PARA: That brings me to my second point. Senator Murray has indicated that, because he has not indicated how the Democrats will vote in this debate, their position is being misrepresented. Fine. This is the opportunity. Why don't you advise the chamber how the Democrats will vote at the third reading stage then everybody will be disabused of the position the Democrats are taking.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to expose the perfidy, if I may put it that way, of the Tasmanian Greens' Senator Brown. I advised Senator Brown at the second reading stage off the record—and I asked for it to be off the record because I wanted to see how the debate progressed—that, if the Australian Democrats's amendments did not get up, we would be voting against the bill at the third reading stage. He knows that, I know that and now you know that.

SPEECH.PARA: Once again we have got this grandstander, this stuntman, coming along with a serious issue and abusing my trust and the trust of those within this chamber. I advise senators sincerely that this is not a person whose word can be trusted. I am offended by it, quite frankly. To make it perfectly clear, through my office I advised the government advisers that it was probable that we would be voting against this bill at the third reading stage. That they would be able to confirm through the minister.

Do not let anyone in this chamber—as Senator Brown has tried to do because it is on broadcast, because it is an opportunity to come in and grandstand and because he is trying to represent himself in a way which is unacceptable—come in here and try to represent the way the Democrats are proceeding. I advise Senator Margetts, who as a WA Green I have the profoundest respect for, as you know, that we will be voting against the third reading because the pool of judges has not been enlarged, which was our intended amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, because the amendment to allow AAT officers to issue warrants for secret phone taps has got through the committee and the legislation is going to be endorsed by the major parties in this chamber, the effect is that we are going to see officers of the AAT who are not judges—not any of them—now given the power to issue warrants for phone tapping. Senator Murray of the Democrats can protest about my stand and the stand of the Greens on this matter, but in effect the Democrats have been central players to that circumstance and that outcome.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to ask Senator Ellison to give a clarification if he is saying that the officer on the AAT who does not have legal qualifications is not going to be put in the position of being asked to issue warrants. There is nothing in this legislation as I understand it that is going to ensure that that officer is not asked.

I am not going to be taken away from the central point of what is happening here and that is: for the first time non‐judges are going to be given the authority to issue warrants for phone tapping. Moreover, because of the circumstances in which this legislation has come into this parliament, the majority of warrants—if not all of them—are going to end up being issued by people who are not qualified judges.
It is a major change and it is a very concerning change. Community groups for civil liberties are opposed to it and I remain absolutely opposed to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Brown's comments, made with his vast diplomatic skills, have not dissuaded me from voting for the amendment; I will be so doing. We canvassed all of those matters last night.

BREAK.PARA: Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Ellison) proposed:
That this bill be now read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to record that the Australian Democrats will be voting against the third reading motion. We do so on the grounds that the pool of judges which we had proposed was not enlarged. On those grounds, therefore, we find ourselves unable to vote for the bill, despite its improvements.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That this bill be now read a third time.

The bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the government amendments to be moved to this bill. This memorandum was circulated in the chamber on 16 June this year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 4, page 3 (after line 3), after the definition of explanatory statement , insert:
gender specific language means language that expresses bias in favour of one sex, and which therefore treats the other sex in a discriminatory manner.
(2) Clause 4, page 3 (after line 6), after the definition of government business enterprise , insert:

relationship assumptions , in relation to the depiction of marriage‐like relationships, means language that expresses bias in favour of relationships between persons of the opposite sex and which therefore treats relationships between persons of the same sex in a discriminatory manner.
(3) Clause 16, page 17 (after line 13), at the end of the clause, add:

(3) In promoting measures to ensure that legislative instruments are of a high standard, the Principal Legislative Counsel must ensure that legislative instruments do not contain gender specific language or relationship assumptions unless it is necessary to identify persons by their sex or by the nature of any marriage‐like relationship to which they are a party.
(10) Clause 42, page 43 (after line 22), at the end of the clause, add:

(4) Notwithstanding anything in this Act, the Principal Legislative Counsel must not register a legislative instrument if the instrument contains any gender specific language or relationship assumptions.
(11) Clause 52, page 54 (after line 19), after subparagraph (vii), insert:

TAB.TAB: (viia) whether gender specific language or relationship assumptions have been used in the instrument; and

SPEECH.PARA: I will not speak at length on these matters because I think they are self-evident and, hopefully, I will get support around the chamber.

What we are seeking to do with these amendments is avoid gender specific language or relationship assumptions being used in legislative instruments unless they are necessary. For instance, amendment No. 1 gives the definition of gender specific language as:
. . . language that expresses bias in favour of one sex, and which therefore treats the other sex in a discriminatory manner.

Plainly, if you were dealing with prostate cancer and you referred to males, that would not be exhibiting bias. I guess we could find some other analogies of that kind. The reason we do so is not an exercise in political correctness; it is an exercise in trying to ensure that significant sections of our society are not annoyed or upset or offended by language which, in the past, may have been regarded as acceptable but is no longer.

We believe that language is a very potent force. It has been a force of oppression. It is also a force of change. How we use language both in our daily life and in legislation affects the sorts of messages we send about what sort of society we are. I have quoted the American feminist Gloria Steinem before. She said:
New words and phrases are one organic measure of change. They capture transformations of perception, and sometimes of reality itself.
Into that you can also include getting rid of old words and old biases which no longer exist or are no longer necessary.
Democrats amendment No. 2 concerns relationship assumptions. It says:

. . . in relation to the depiction of marriage‐like relationships, means language that expresses bias in favour of relationships between persons of the opposite sex and which therefore treats relationships between persons of the same sex in a discriminatory manner.

We regard that as unnecessary and undesirable in a modern society. We have deliberately required that the legislative counsel must not register a legislative instrument if the instrument contains any gender specific language or relationship assumptions expressed in the manner I have laid out. I would hope that that is helpful to senators listening to the debate.

We think that previously section 23 of the Acts Interpretation Act was thought to be sufficient because it, in part, states that words importing a gender should include every other gender. This attitude, as exemplified in section 23 of the AIA, has helped perpetuate a culture in law where men are specified to mean and include women. In our view, the resulting effect has been to contribute to sexism and male domination in law and, therefore, in the spheres of public life.

To use gender neutral language results in the opposite effect in that no offence can be taken in any quarter and removes a historical bias and discrimination which we think is often present in legislative instruments which refer to persons' relationships. We are particularly trying in this instance to guide those persons who will be devising new regulations, and when the five‐year period comes up we will have to review regulations which have been couched in old language.

The amendments are consistent with the Democrats' proposal to have discrimination on the basis of sexuality removed from Commonwealth law. It is unreasonable to disenfranchise persons in same sex relationships and where that distinction is discriminatory and not reasonably necessary to give efficacy to the laws of this country.

It is a fact that same sex couples are in large numbers in Australia and they contribute, as other citizens do, to our laws, taxes and the running of our country, and they are entitled to the same consideration as couples of opposite sex. We are not about prescribing one relationship over another or trying to lay down a way in which people should live; we are reflecting the reality of our society and the need for neutrality in law in these areas. We hope that we will get the support of the parties and the senators for this.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —For the record, the government opposes these amendments. Firstly, the government would point to the fact that primary legislation on these areas such as the Sex Discrimination Act already covers the matters mentioned by the Democrats. This would be duplicating that. Furthermore, there would be a great deal of work involved for the Office of Legislative Drafting in the drafting, in that each instrument would have to be addressed in the manner outlined by Senator Murray. That would be an onerous task. For the reasons of the undue burden placed on the government and that there would be duplication, the government opposes the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition supports the amendments. It is a curious argument the government puts up. The government is not claiming that what Senator Murray is trying to do is a policy problem. I think implicit in what Senator Ellison said was that what Senator Murray is trying to do is desirable. Then he goes on to say that it is duplication because the Sex Discrimination Act covers it already. Then he says that if we were to pass these amendments the task for the drafters would be onerous. If the Sex Discrimination Act covers it already, there should not be an extra task. I do not think you can have it both ways, Senator Ellison.

SPEECH.PARA: What you are trying to argue is that, on the one hand, there is no extra task and then, on the other hand, the task for the drafters would be onerous. It would not be onerous. It is just one of those factors they have to take into account. They should do it as a matter of course. They could probably program their computers to do most of the work for them. I do not accept this concept of an onerous task.

In terms of the Sex Discrimination Act, we all know that a subsequent act of the parlia ment supersedes the pre‐existing act. In fact if the Sex Discrimination Act does cover this field, there is no guarantee that what we are passing today would not somehow touch on or infringe on the application of the act. I think what Senator Murray is trying to do is desirable. I do not think the implications involved in terms of resources are a problem at all. If the government want to do it, they can do it. The bottom line here is that they do not want to do it. If you do not want to do it just say so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be supporting the Democrats amendments 1, 2, 3, 10 and 11. I think it is ludicrous to suggest that the requirements would be onerous. It should be a normal part of the way we function in 1997. It is only onerous if you do not want those principles to take place, in which case no matter what the words are, no matter what the community wants, especially those in the community who feel this is necessary, you will still find it onerous. The government will find it onerous and those people who do not want it will find it onerous. That is a pity. I think it ought to be a normal part of the way we operate and a normal part of legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Murray, I have a matter of technicality. Why do you want to put the amendment in the way you have it there? Amendment No. 1 states:

SPEECH.PARA: gender specific language means language that expresses bias in favour of one sex, and which therefore treats the other sex in a discriminatory manner.
Don't you just mean that gender specific language means language which treats the other sex in a discriminatory manner? Amendment No. 2 states:

relationship assumptions , in relation to the depiction of marriage‐like relationships, means language that expresses bias in favour of relationships between persons of the opposite sex and which therefore treats relationships between persons of the same sex in a discriminatory manner.

Don't you simply mean relationship assumptions, in relation to the depiction of marriage‐like relationships, means language that treats relationships between persons of the same sex in a discriminatory manner? It seems to me you are going through a tortuous process to get to a result that could be got to more simply, particularly if you are going to have interpretations of that and you are going to have a parliamentary draftsperson going around trying to work his or her way through it. Amendment No. 11 states:
(viia) whether gender specific language or relationship assumptions have been used in the instrument; and

Why don't you just say `whether gender specific language has been used in the instrument'? I am not sure what is meant by `relationship assumptions', with respect. How do you write legislation free of relationship assumptions? I can understand your writing it without gender specific language or in a way that does not treat relationships between persons in a discriminatory manner and so on. I get a bit concerned that we are sending these instructions to our parliamentary drafters. Hilary Penfold is one of the great parliamentary drafters, I might say. It worries me that this is a fairly complicated way of expressing what you want to express.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cooney, you have me between a rock and a hard place because I have the most profound respect for the draftsperson who exercises our instructions and I have the most profound respect for you, and the two of you disagree. I must tell you that I am quite happy to accept any amendments you may seek to put which would make it clearer. I am careful not to write these things myself because I do not have the experience in parliamentary draftsmanship which is appropriate, and I do take advice.

SPEECH.PARA: To answer your specific questions, Senator Cooney, I will give you an example I gave earlier. There are times when, I suspect, it may be necessary to use gender specific language, and we cannot envisage all the situations. I used an example of a health situation which may be peculiar to a male or a female. That is not being discriminatory in the negative sense; that is being naturally discriminatory. Consequently, the draftsperson expressed the instruction in the way that we see there.

With regard to relationship assumptions, it may be that at times the draftsperson writes a particular instruction presuming that they are referring to heterosexual couples. If it is the intention of government in particular circumstances to provide for heterosexual couples as distinct from same sex couples, we believe they need to be explicit if it is in a non-discriminatory fashion and if it is necessary. But, if it is merely an assumption and the result is it would be unclear to those who thereafter have to deal with the rules and regulations, we thought it was necessary to, once again, express it as we have there.

So, Senator, Cooney, I will say to you that I am happy to take any improving amendments if you want to put them, because it is the thrust I am after. However, unless you think that what we have before the Senate will really result in a problem, we should proceed as we are. I have received a note from the draftsperson—and, as I say, I respect very highly the draftsperson—and the message is, `Senator Cooney's suggestions are eminently acceptable.' It is up to you, Senator Cooney. You can change the words as you see fit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say that I understand what Senator Murray is attempting to do, and it is important, quite clearly, that there be no unjust discrimination as between the sexes or, in respect of the matter that he refers to, unjust discrimination against persons who are homosexual. I understand that that is quite important in areas of, for example, employment and the like. However, I am not proposing to support the amendments. Amendment No. 2 states:

SPEECH.PARA: relationship assumptions , in relation to the depiction of marriage‐like relationships, means language that expresses bias in favour of relationships between persons of the opposite sex and which therefore treats relationships between persons of the same sex in a discriminatory manner.

The fact of the matter is that the parliament and this nation do discriminate in favour of marriage, and quite rightly. Believe it or not, that is, and has been for many years, a part of the Family Law Act. The family is the fundamental group unit of society based on the marriage of a man and a woman voluntarily entered into for life. That is as I recall it from the Family Law Act—and, as I say, would you believe.

But the nation does happen to discriminate, or should discriminate, in favour of marriage. Does anybody disagree with that? I do not think too many around this chamber would disagree with that, and it is a matter which I think we should uphold.

As to the question of gender specific language, I think it is fair to say that people have come to an understanding that, as has always been said, the term `man' embraces `woman' and vice versa. As far as I can see, the use of the word `persons' is probably desirable.

On balance, I am inclined to vote against the amendments. I rise at this time to make that point just in case people are engaging people in drafting changes, as indicated as possible by Senator Cooney.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must make it clear—I will focus on the relationship assumptions area and the remarks that Senator Harradine has made—that what we are attempting to do here is prevent bias and discrimination, which is unacceptable. Quite plainly, our family law and our taxation law and all sorts of other laws support and promote the traditional family being of man and woman. I think it is of great regret that there are so few families in this country. I think something like 13 per cent of our population now live alone.
—It depends on your definition of family.

—Yes, it depends on your definition of family, but certainly far too many people live alone. I, for one, am a great believer in the virtues of companionship but, of course, for many people companionship includes same sex partners. That is what makes them happy and content. Senator Harradine, all we are expressing here is that bias and discrimination, which are not justified, should not be used in legislative instruments and assumptions accordingly. So you must not infer by that the opposite proposi tion: that we would, in fact, be at all discriminating or against the virtues of the family as traditionally understood.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —There are several elements within the definition which need to be teased out here. There are many people in Australia who have families which do not fit into what might be considered the traditional definition of families, but they may be loving, supportive relationships. They might be extended families; they might be single-parent families; they might be same sex couples with children or without children or whatever. There are many definitions. There could be a number of adults who consider themselves to be a family. There are many people who consider they are a family. Of course, anybody who has studied ethnography or anthropology will realise that every community may have a preferred or a general model for a family, but there has been a whole range of models for families throughout history and throughout culture. So the family can be a whole range of models, even within Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose we should not be saying necessarily that one model is good and the other model is bad. I do not think anyone is necessarily saying that families do not need support. But you could also ask, when we are talking about families, whether we are talking about a particular type of family or about a range of other models that can and do exist within Australia. These models work for people to give them the support they need. Otherwise we might all end up being an unsupported group in society who become dysfunctional because of the lack of relationships between people.

Sometimes when we put the dollar above everything else, as we do in many other pieces of legislation, that is what we are assuming: that people will and should operate as individuals. Sometimes I think this traditional idea of the family is part of the kind of dollar society which says you have a proprietorial notion. I am not suggesting Senator Harradine is saying this, by the way, but one of the things coming through in the general debate is that the family can be a proprietorial body. That is another version of economic fundamentalism where the father owns the wife and the children, and everybody else should butt out. So there is a whole lot of debate going on in our society about what a family is and what the support structure is.

At the same time, we know that within the law it is not possible for the family structure of some people to be recognised at the moment in terms of what is considered to be a legally binding marriage and what is not. We know that there are many people who may have a marriage certificate, which means nothing to them, who do not provide love and support for their family, for various reasons. We also know that there are many people in our society who do provide love and support but either do not or cannot obtain the legal document which says they have signed on the dotted line under what is considered to be a legally binding marriage in Australian law.

So the issue of what is necessary to keep society together and what is currently the norm—even though the norm might be, in the end, the exception—needs to be dealt with. I think these kinds of challenges in the legislation do have to be dealt with seriously. They are not about whether people think families are good or bad. They are about whether or not we are open enough to think that a wider definition of what is a family, what is marriage and what is a legitimate relationship should be considered equally and without prejudice in our society.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have already indicated, the opposition does support Senator Murray's proposed amendments. We also realise that the numbers will not be there to get these amendments up. So I indicate at this stage that, after Senator Murray's amendments are put to a vote, if they are not carried, I will be seeking to move the amendments in an amended form to refer only to gender specific language.

SPEECH.PARA: So, for instance, I will be moving amendment No. 1 with the deletion of the words after `of one sex' in the first line. I will not be proceeding with amendment No. 2 because that purely deals with relationship assump tions. I will be seeking to move amendment No. 3 with the deletion of the words `or relationship assumptions' in the third line and deletion of all the words after `sex' in the fourth line. In relation to amendment No. 10, I will move that we delete all the words after `gender specific language' in line 2 and, in relation to amendment No. 11, deletion of the words `or relationship assumptions have' in the first line and replace them with the word `has'.

So, having lost the relationship assumption amendments, the impact of what we will be seeking to do is to excise the gender specific language ones and proceed with them as a second option for the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Margetts for her graciousness in indicating that she was not referring to me. As a person I suppose I have been in different types of families. I have been a single parent for a couple of years, and I hope that I understand from personal experience the importance of those families being treated as families and of their rights and needs being considered by individuals and by the legislature.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that we are now faced with a proposal by Senator Bolkus for amendment of certain words. I would like to hear from the government now or in due course as to how the government would see this impacting on the tasks of the legislative draftsperson—or `drafter', as Senator Cooney said. What are the types of actions that would need to be taken? What are the types of words that need to be used for the purpose of implementing this? There are, are there not, precedents for this in other jurisdictions? That is another matter that I would like to have explained. I would like to hear fully from the government as to how this would be implemented in practice, if the amendments to Senator Murray's amendments to be moved by Senator Bolkus were adopted. I would expect that Senator Bolkus's amendments to Senator Murray's amendments would be the first to be put to the committee, would they not?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine, I under stand that Senator Bolkus has said that he will put his amendments after Senator Murray's amendments have been dealt with.

—As I said, he can do that if he wants to. Obviously, he is entitled to do it. What I will do if you do it that way is another matter. I think that the most appropriate thing, if he is choosing to move that way, would be to move the amendments and have the discussion on the matter now as a whole. I would certainly like to hear from the government.

—As I said at the outset, we support the initial amendments. But if they were to go down, then we would be moving our amendments. I think we have capacity to discuss them sequentially, and that is what I am suggesting we do. It should not take all that much longer. If the government were to indicate, for instance, one way or another on our set of amendments, it might just make the whole process much faster.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —Even with the amendments put by Senator Bolkus, we still have a situation where the drafting and the practical effect of the amendment are not avoided. The situation at the moment is that you have an instrument which is simply registered. As I mentioned earlier, primary legislation deals with the questions of principle—that is, whether something does discriminate, does offend against laws such as those dealing with human rights, sexual discrimination, et cetera.

SPEECH.PARA: But there is another side to it: the aspect of how you physically deal with the drafting of the instruments as they come through. I am advised that even with the amendments proposed by Senator Bolkus it still would mean going through each instrument and altering wording if necessary. That would entail the work not only of legal drafting but also of officers concerned in presenting the instruments. So it is a more an aspect of footwork, of going through the drafting of the instrument. That is something which is not there at the moment. If you multiply that by the number of instruments—and I don't know how many there would be but certainly a good many are dealt with from year to year—you then increase greatly the work imposed on the officials concerned. The government thinks in a practical sense that Senator Bolkus's amendments still present that problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the government doing at the present moment about gender specific language in legislative instruments? Is there some policy that the government and the various departments have? Is there some way that that information could be provided to us?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —My advice is that there is no check done in relation to gender specific language. But that does not mean to say that the drafting of the document is not addressed in that manner; it is just that there is no check on that. It may be that the parliamentary draftsman might be able to give us some guidance on that, and I could have that advice shortly, I believe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been listening to the debate with interest and trying to determine which way I should go. Quite plainly, the wording in the amendments we have put are not acceptable to the Senate as a whole. Labor, the Greens (WA) and the Australian Democrats have put on record their support for them, but we do not have the numbers. I would think, with your guidance, that my best course might well be to withdraw my amendments on the understanding that Labor will then put their amendments, which will make it far easier for both Senator Harradine and the government to consider them afresh.
—You will need leave to withdraw your amendments.
—Yes. I seek leave to withdraw my amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
Amendments withdrawn.

BREAK.PARA: Amendments (by Senator Bolkus)—by leave—proposed:
(1) Clause 4, page 3 (after line 3), after the definition of explanatory statement , insert:
gender specific language means language that expresses bias in favour of one sex.
(3) Clause 16, page 17 (after line 13), at the end of the clause, add:

(3) In promoting measures to ensure that legislative instruments are of a high standard, the Principal Legislative Counsel must ensure that legislative instruments do not contain gender specific language unless it is necessary to identify persons by their sex.
(10) Clause 42, page 43 (after line 22), at the end of the clause, add:
(4) Notwithstanding anything in this Act, the Principal Legislative Counsel must not register a legislative instrument if the instrument contains any gender specific language.
(11) Clause 52, page 54 (after line 19), after subparagraph (vii), insert:

TAB.TAB: (viia) whether gender specific language has been used in the instrument; and
