PROCTEXT.PARA: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Ferguson)—Order! It being 12.45 p.m., I call on matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coonan, Sen Helen

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise as a matter of public interest this afternoon the issue of misuse of parliamentary privilege. Recent instances, both here in this place and in the New South Wales parliament, have generated debate and public controversy. Abuses of privilege have caused many to wonder whether the unqualified right of free speech in parliament ought to be tempered with at least some individual responsibility for members of parliament to ensure their information has a factual basis before embarking on a denunciation of others.

SPEECH.PARA: There can be no doubt that parliamentary privilege is an essential underpinning for the proper functioning of a free and democratic society. In Australia, parliamentary immunities and privileges are part of the ordinary law by virtue of section 49 of the constitution. There is a legitimate role for parliamentary privilege in a democracy and in the public interest to air matters of serious concern that may not otherwise see the light of day because of restrictions such as strict defamation laws or, in more extreme cases, conspiracy to suppress information.

It has been acknowledged that members of parliament misuse privilege from time to time to the detriment of the reputation of individuals. Yet it is steadfastly maintained that the unfettered right of free speech is so important and so immutable that it is impossible to find some principled way of ensuring that parliamentarians exercise free speech responsibly.

Recent events have caused many of us to question whether it is beyond our collective wit to ensure some limited accountability for statements made in parliament which appear to be recklessly indifferent to the truth. I refer, firstly, to events in my own state, the state of New South Wales, and to statements made in the Legislative Council by Mrs Franca Arena MLC concerning the late David Yeldham QC, who killed himself subsequent to Mrs Arena having named him in parliament as being linked to paedophilia activities. Secondly, I refer to statements made by her last week alleging a criminal conspiracy between the Premier of New South Wales, Bob Carr, the Leader of the New South Wales Opposition, Peter Collins, and Police Royal Commissioner, Justice James Wood, to conceal evidence identifying prominent individuals as being involved in paedophilia activities.

Both episodes were followed by extraordinary events. One of these events, David Yeldham's death, was catastrophic. The other, the setting up of an inquiry into the conspiracy allegations to be conducted by a New South Wales Supreme Court judge of appeal, unprecedented. While the contents of the fourth volume of Justice Wood's report are not in the public domain, what is known about this appalling chain of events is, firstly, that the basis for Mrs Arena's allegation that David Yeldham was involved in paedophile activities at all was third‐hand and relied on the assertion of an informant whose brother had told him Yeldham was identified in a photograph.

BREAK.PARA: Secondly, Mrs Arena claimed parliamentary privilege in protecting her sources in declining to give evidence before the Wood royal commission, as she was perfectly entitled to do. Thirdly, Mrs Arena has failed subsequently to name any more so‐called prominent individuals and has failed so far to substantiate her allegations that there is a criminal conspiracy engaged in by the Premier, the Leader of the Opposition and Justice Woods to protect those individuals from exposure. Fourthly, as Professor Enid Campbell, Professor of Law at Monash University and an expert on parliamentary privilege points out, there may be very real questions as to the validity of any external body, such as the inquiry set up by the Premier and supported by Mr Collins, to inquire into the truth of matters covered by parliamentary privilege, in any event.

So far, then, this sorry episode involving parliamentary privilege has left one person dead, the integrity of the Premier and the Leader of the Opposition and the impartiality of the royal commissioner questioned, and others, including parliamentarians whose identity has been barely disguised, subject to innuendo and smear.

Another recent controversial use of parliamentary privilege has involved Senator Conroy reading into Hansard a transcript of interviews said to be by National Crime Authority investigators with Mr John Elliott and others—evidence that had been ruled inadmissible in the Supreme Court of Victoria.

I hasten to say that serious issues appear to have been raised relating to the operation of the NCA and its investigation of Mr Elliott and others. I acknowledge there is a legitimate public interest in assessing the efficacy of the NCA as a public institution. As aspects of the matter concerning whether the protection of parliamentary privilege extends to matters covered by the secrecy provisions of the NCA have been referred to the Senate Committee of Privileges, it would be inappropriate to discuss it in any further detail.

However, it fairly and squarely raises a broader issue of community concern—that is, the extent to which information that is otherwise inadmissible in courts or tribunals, or confidential information or even commercially sensitive information or that classified as secret in the national interest, can be made public by a member of parliament simply reading the content of documents into Hansard with impunity. Although there are cases where the community may well feel that the justice system has failed, is it really appropriate for the matter to be tried again in the parliament?

It raises the spectre of individuals being persecuted or being accused in a public forum with little or no effective redress. If the legal system has failed to achieve a fair balance between the interests of the person or persons accused of criminal or civil wrongdoing and the public interest in having that person brought to justice, it is, in my view, for the legal system to address. There is not much point in having elaborately honed rules of evidence to protect those accused if, once acquitted, the trial is run again in parliament without any safeguards at all for the individual concerned.

Another recent controversial resort to parliamentary privilege was the statement in the New South Wales parliament by Richard Jones MLC that the columnist Piers Akerman, who had vehemently opposed the proposed heroin trial, is a drug addict. Although Mr Akerman has denied the allegation, had the damage already been done?

The Senate, of course, provides a right of reply to persons aggrieved by statements made under parliamentary privilege. Some other parliaments have now adopted this procedure. But it is cold comfort when all it can do is to provide some damage control. It is not a procedure which can be used speedily to counter incorrect information and in circumstances where the damage to an individual's reputation may be irreparable or damage to commercial interests incalculable.

These matters have prompted me to revisit the purpose and objectives of parliamentary privilege. Whilst I unreservedly accept and will fearlessly defend the proposition that parliament could not function democratically if parliamentarians are impeded either individually or collectively in carrying out parliamentary work, it begs the question whether serious misuse of privilege could ever be regarded as assisting or protecting the proper work and functions of parliament.
In an article written in 1988 entitled `Parliamentary privilege: changes to the law at federal level', Mr Harry Evans, Clerk of the Senate, issued a timely warning when he said:

PARA.EMPHASIS: The retention of any immunity and powers . . . depends on the wise exercise of them and the respect commanded by the institution. If the gap between the theory of what parliament should be and the perceived reality grows too wide, there will inevitably be a demand for further changes.

BREAK.PARA: In the light of recent events, it is not good enough for us to go on invoking the mantle of parliamentary privilege as a cloak to relieve us of collective responsibility for our conduct. I recognise the difficulty of differentiating between fearless inquiry in pursuit of the truth on the one hand and outrageous, reckless and unsubstantiated accusations on the other. Sometimes there is a fine line.

In my view, it is time for the Senate to refer to the Committee of Privileges the task of inquiring into the misuse of parliamentary privilege and, if warranted, to recommend guidelines to enable the Senate to better protect its processes from abuse of the immunities conferred by elected office.

In 1988 the Senate was the first Australian legislature to recognise the justice of a citizen's right of reply. Almost a decade later, it is time that the Senate again showed leadership in structuring a principled approach to deal with blatant misuse of a precious right that brings the institution of parliament into disrepute. If we do not take steps to make ourselves more accountable in the way we use privilege, we will have only ourselves to blame if a community groundswell will require it. How much longer can we continue to have all rights and no responsibility?
Today, in a letter to the Sydney Morning Herald, Susan Yeldham, the daughter‐in‐law of Mr Justice Yeldham, had this to say:

PARA.EMPHASIS: How sad it is that Franca Arena can cause so much damage to so many people and then not have to substantiate or be accountable for her claims.

What a waste of taxpayers' money to have someone in her position who not only has no understanding of the basic principle of innocent until proved guilty, but does not seem to understand the difference between bisexuality and pedophilia.

BREAK.PARA: It is a sad day indeed when the only redress that the relatives of the late David Yeldham have is to write letters to the editor. It is time for us all to consider these matters and to more responsibly use privilege.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop, Sen Mark

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to begin by placing on the record my support for the idea of a white paper on foreign and trade policy, as was recently released by the government, entitled In the national interest . When consideration is given to the fact that it is the first such white paper in the history of this nation, one sees that it is a welcome initiative.

SPEECH.PARA: A white paper in this area of government policy should, of course, have one primary focus. That focus should be on Australia's strategic engagement with the remainder of the world. Thought should be given to our engagement with our immediate region and also we should assess and evaluate our current relationship beyond this region. That engagement should seek to place Australia in a leadership position. Such a leadership position requires Australia to recognise that its own national interests are, by and large, compatible with the interests of our region.

Additionally, the Australian government must recognise that immediate domestic economic advantages do not always and only constitute the long-term interests of the region and the nation. Such an approach would identify the long-term interests of the nation and the region. In particular, policy makers should be aware of regional issues that, in advancing the region, also advance Australia.

This approach requires a focus on three main areas. Firstly, there must be a recognition of the international shift towards regional forums. This trend has placed an increased emphasis on the importance of multilateral relationships for Australia as opposed to bilateral relationships. These multilateral relationships will have an impact on Australia economically in areas of trade and in regard to regional security.

Secondly, Australia must be committed to a long-term approach to the region with a full commitment. By a full commitment, I mean that Australia must be prepared to tackle all regional issues that will advance both regional and national interests. This means being involved in the region on difficult issues, such as human rights, as opposed to only issues that create economic benefit to Australia. This would recognise that regional security is also assisted by the advocation of democratic ideals and beliefs.

Thirdly, Australia must have a plan for Australian involvement in this region. Identification of growth sectors and political trends is an important tool. However, this identification is of little value without a government plan that seeks to advance regional and domestic interests.

In determining the course of Australia's engagement, it is incumbent upon the government to recognise that the national interest is served by the pursuit of the following goals—regional security, sustainable domestic and regional economic growth, and the exportation of democratic ideals and goals. Integration of these goals and the right balance between the three identified areas of Australian involvement is, it must be conceded, a difficult proc ess. That is why a strategic approach is required. This approach would identify areas of concern and interest to Australia and then set about creating an environment in which these goals may be attained. I would like to discuss each of those issues in some detail.

Firstly, multilateral relationships. This approach has two policy implications—regional security and regional trade. As previously mentioned, there has been a gradual shift over recent decades from a high emphasis on bilateral relationships to an increased emphasis on multilateral relationships. This has resulted in a redefining of international partnerships and often the establishment of regional trade zones.

This trend requires Australian policy makers to accept our immediate region as a community of nations, each engaging the others and making decisions based on regional advancement and security while trying to acquire some domestic benefit. This trend towards regional relationships is highlighted by forums and agreements such as ASEAN, NAFTA and the European Union. Through these forums, nations as member states are moving forward together, rather than as separate entities.

An appropriate response by the Australian government would be to actively participate and engage these forums, rather than seeking to do business in a bilateral paradigm. Put simply, if East Asia decides to move forward together, Australia must seek to share in that advancement with the whole of Asia. Australia must seek to influence those decisions that primarily must occur through multilateral channels.

The government's white paper does not appear to recognise the importance of this approach. It continues to define the national interest in terms of immediate economic achievement without any thought to long-term planning and outcomes. The document states:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Multilateral means will remain an effective way to advance Australia's interests. However Australia must concentrate on issues where its national interests are closely engaged.

SPEECH.PARA: The white paper also argues:

PARA.EMPHASIS: A central feature of the Government's approach to foreign and trade policy is the importance it places on bilateral relationships as a means of advancing Australian interests. Bilateral relationships are the basic building block for effective regional and global strategies.
Linked to the Government's focus on bilateral relations is a selective approach to the multilateral agenda.

SPEECH.PARA: This comment illustrates no attempt to identify long-term trends or to even seek to influence those trends through Australian engagement in regional forums that determine those events and outcomes.

The danger of an approach that is not long term or strategic and underestimates the significance of multilateral negotiations is highlighted in recent problems between Australia and China. These problems are a result of Australia's posturing regarding its relationship with the United States and its poor understanding of the impact of a beat-up of bilateral relationships with the United States in the Asia Pacific region.

China, as an emerging world economic power and an obvious regional military power, will have an intense impact on the future direction of the region. Australia must be aware of this when conducting its foreign affairs and it must also be aware of the impact from its bilateral negotiations.

It is likely that the United States involvement in the region and China's response to that will have the greatest impact on issues of regional security over the next 15 years. Australia will play a crucial role in this regard. The involvement of the United States, as the only remaining world superpower, will assist in underwriting security in this region. Australia's close relationship with the United States means that we have an opportunity to benefit from this involvement. On the other hand, China's response to this involvement and to Australia's role will have an equally significant impact on the region.

Additionally, China's role in the region will have an impact on Australia's future success. China has a rapidly growing economy which provides a large market for Australian industry. Equally important to Australia, as a Western liberal democracy, is the process of reform, both economically and politically, that is likely to take place in China. Management of Australia's relationships with the United States and China will be critical in Australia's position in the region and our own economic advancement. To date, the government has not managed this mixture of relationships well.

The Howard government has overplayed its hand by posturing in regard to the Australian‐American reliance. The annual Ausmin talks were hailed by the government as a `re‐invigoration' of the alliance. This comment, in addition to the white paper's emphasis on bilateral relationships with America, highlighted that this government has not identified the trend towards multilateral diplomacy and the impact this will have on our relationship with China.
In response to the posturing of the `re‐invigoration' comment and the white paper, the Peoples Daily, the official newspaper of the Chinese Communist Party, made the following comments:

PARA.EMPHASIS: . . . Australia shows a strong trend of relying on the USA.

SPEECH.PARA: and it—

PARA.EMPHASIS: . . . not only exaggerates the importance of the US military presence in the Western Pacific, but also it supported enhanced defence co‐operation between the US and Japan.

SPEECH.PARA: The Chinese commentary said this revealed:

PARA.EMPHASIS: . . . the two basic orbits of foreign policy of Australia: in economics and trade it faces towards Asia, but in security it relies on the USA and Japan. This shows that although Australia has continuously expressed the idea of getting involved in Asia, it lacks confidence that the members of the region can solve their own security issues through dialogue and consultation.

SPEECH.PARA: These comments were later reprinted by the Sydney Morning Herald . If nothing else, these comments illustrate how bilateral relations with the United States are interpreted in the region and the impact this can have on Australia's further engagement with the region. The fact that the government did not understand this before its needless posturing on the US‐Australian alliance is of some concern.

This highlights an equally important issue. This government, through its white paper, has failed to devise any plan for Australia's engagement in the region over the next two decades. It is fair to argue that the government has identified a number of trends that are occurring internationally and, more specifically, within our immediate region. Those trends are the continued expansion and economic growth of the East Asian region, the emerging significance both economically and militarily of China within the region, the increased significance of East Asia economically to Australia, and the impact of increased regional trade on skill acquisition and employment growth. All of these points are correct, yet the white paper details no plan to involve Australia in the progress of these likely trends in such a way as to place an Australian influence on these changes.

There is no clear and defined plan by the government to assist Australian industry and business with its engagement of the region, nor is there an attempt by the government to state and argue for an Australian position in regard to these changes.

In this respect, the document In the National Interest is an excellent chronicle of events to date and a sound analysis of the likely trends that will proceed over the next 15 years. It however makes no attempt to place Australia in a central position to take advantage of these changes. This lack of strategic plan for Australian engagement within its immediate region is a major failure of this white paper.

Finally, the white paper appears to hedge its bets in regard to engagement of the region. For Australia to be accepted by its neighbours as a truly active member of the region, it must make a complete commitment to the future of this region. This requires Australia to not only make decisions and plans about issues of economic benefit but also to realise that the safety of regional citizens and the maintenance of their basic human rights is in Australia's interests. Internal political unrest which stems from a lack of reform creates a broader sense of turmoil within the region. This does not serve the interests of Australia or the region itself.

History has taught us that economic reforms have generally been preceded by political reforms. As countries open themselves up to the West, they are likely to feel enormous pressure on their societies which did not exist before. Management of these reforms in a peaceful and constructive way will allow the region to remain secure and to advance over time. While decisions on human rights do not provide immediate economic benefit, the rights of all people and the advantages that stem from political reform are, in the long term, an advantage for the region. The government's white paper has not recognised this. It maintains that issues which relate to employment growth are of primary concern, and that issues which do not relate to this outcome are of a secondary nature.

This attitude, however, signals to our neighbouring countries that we have an interest in the region only for economic advantage rather than a wholehearted commit ment to the region on all issues. Generally, this white paper lacks clear objectives and a method of achievement. It is a document that does little to define Australia's place in the region or the world. Equally, it fails to correctly interpret the impact of current international trends both for our region and for Australia. Without an appreciation of those trends, and their impact on our country, our own national interests will not be adequately served. In this sense, the white paper is a missed opportunity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to speak in this matter of public interest debate because of a growing problem within my state of Queensland—that is, a racist movement which seems to be gaining momentum. I think it is important to put on the record some of the detail. It follows, of course, the election of the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) and the space which she has given to such movements to grow, whether or not she claims credit for them. We need to understand the way that such movements grow. These people are always within our society but they remain submerged until somebody with credibility—such as a politician—makes room for them to operate. I believe that is what Pauline Hanson has done.

SPEECH.PARA: There is weekly evidence in my state that, since the election of Ms Hanson—and I must say the Howard government has failed to effectively rebut her view of the world—the number of those in our community who indulge in racist scapegoating to alleviate the pain of modern living is on the rise. I believe that bigotry, intolerance and hatred are on the rise in Australia because of a lack of leadership.

Last week, members of the Ipswich City Council and local ethnic groups were horrified to report the appearance of white Australia posters and material which were plastered around Oxley. The Australian of 23 September 1997 contained a picture of one of these posters, which said:

PARA.EMPHASIS: This nation was built by white men,
This nation belongs to white men!

SPEECH.PARA: Incidentally, I do not know where the white women were, but that is a good example of the kind of thing that is now being freely displayed, particularly in that electorate.

This is an abomination, and it requires a strong response from the federal government—a response which I believe has been lacking. In fact, we have actually seen the Howard government, in a climate of blatant racism that even the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) would not deny, cut funding by 40 per cent to the most important body in this country for combating racism; that is, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. There is much other evidence of the rise of bigotry, racism and intolerance that I believe will become entrenched in Australia unless we have the kind of leadership which will show Australians that such behaviour will not be tolerated.

I have here a copy of Wake Up Australia, which is the newsletter of Pauline Hanson's One Nation Party. I find it very interesting that Wake Up Australia is also the title of a newspaper published by Tony Pitt who, at least some weeks ago, was the convenor for the One Nation Party in the Hervey Bay area. I think it might be useful if I read to the Senate some of the material from this newspaper. I might add that Mr Pitt was also the former convenor of the Confederate Action Party. In the Wake Up Australia, he gives us a gem entitled `Why Wik?'. The article says:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Nobody in their right mind would sit down and conciliate, with a bunch of Maoris, Afghans, Indians, Malays and seven eighths whites, who pretend to be Aborigines, over what happened well over two hundred years ago, unless there was something in it for them, and there is, BIG MONEY.
Two thirds of Australia is claimed by militant Aborigines backed . . . trained and funded by the Black Muslims, Gaddaffi, Indonesia and others who covet our mineral, oil, land and fishing.
Black youths force whites off the footpath, steal at will, and get away with it. Whites live behind bars with dogs and are still not safe.

SPEECH.PARA: Great stuff, Mr Pitt! I wonder if he is still the convenor for Ms Hanson's party in Hervey Bay in Queensland. I imagine he is.

BREAK.PARA: There is also a cartoon in that newspaper captioned `Asians love Australia'. It is a picture of some obviously Asian people sitting round a table with a plate and on it is Australia, which they are carving up.
Let me read you another gem from the newspaper Wake Up Australia. It says:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Wanted
Interpreters
English to Indonesian—So Muslim invaders can communicate with Australian slaves.

Before anyone gets emotional about the above comment being racist, let us look at reality. Mr Sambawaga (Spokesman for the Golkar Party) said "We will attack (Australia). Get it?" Ali Alitas (Minister for Foreign Affairs‐Indonesia), on the same TV program said, "Mr Sambawaga reflects the sentiment of the people and the parliament of Indonesia."

BREAK.PARA: I would like to get a copy of the actual interview because I am sure that there are some misquotes.

I was also very concerned to see in this newspaper an advertisement for a book by Mr Geoff McDonald. This book, which is quite old, is entitled Red over Black. I wrote a reply entitled `Technicolour fantasy', because the book is a fantasy. It is all about a conspiracy by Aboriginal people to get land rights and then invite the communists to come in and take over Australia. If it was not serious, it certainly would be a laughing matter.

The newspaper also contains a map—I don't know if this is where Mr Howard got his map from, but it is very similar to the one which he held up on the 7.30 Report a little while ago—which shows most of Australia coloured in black. The inference is obvious.
Another article in the newspaper is entitled `Why would anyone need a semi auto?'. The article states:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Australia must face reality in matters of defence. To rely solely upon a regular army the size of ours is a recipe for certain defeat.

The lessons from the past must be heeded. In Korea the human wave attacks overwhelmed our forces. The enemy did not care how many of their own died to exhaust our ammunition and exceed our rate of fire. Guerillas do not present an attackable entity to be overwhelmed.
If we are well armed and defended we will not be attacked. Weapons of destruction, if in our possession need not be used.

BREAK.PARA: Because they will be a deterrent, I presume; and so the newspaper goes on.
In the time I have left, I want to refer to a magazine of one of the shooters lobby groups in Queensland. The magazine is called Lock Stock & Barrel.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are you bothering to read them?

—They send them to me. We have lots of these kinds of groups in Queensland, as we always have had. It has always been a concern to me and that is why I have kept an eye on them for many years. The journal of the shooters' lobby, Lock Stock & Barrel , declares itself a backer of the One Nation Party. It is interesting that it should do that in preference to the official Shooters Party, which I thought it would have backed.

BREAK.PARA: The coalition certainly should be concerned about this magazine. In one edition, it had a cartoon of this country's Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and its Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer) facing a firing squad, backed by Pauline Hanson and One Nation. As the Deputy Prime Minister himself pointed out last month, One Nation has repaid this loyalty from Lock Stock & Barrel by privately meeting with Ron Owen from the Shooters Party. The transcript of that meeting is in this journal and it makes interesting reading.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why should we worry?
—Apparently your leader has, Senator McGauran, because this is the magazine which Tim Fischer quoted from in a press release just a week or so ago.

BREAK.PARA: There were some more interesting bits in the magazine, that he failed to quote—I thought you would be interested to hear some of those as well. This magazine has a very interesting advertisement which features a picture of a cupboard. The advertisement says:

PARA.EMPHASIS: New gun laws have made your possessions a target. Flushed doors, internal hinges, deadlocks, 6mm of steel will help to preserve them even if your not going to get a licence.

BREAK.PARA: And so you can buy one of those cupboards which will be available to you.

There is also an article about snipers and how to pick up targets. It is a very interesting article, particularly the way in which it talks about how you need to pick your target very carefully and makes very clear who the target should be.

This ought to be of concern to all people in Australia and certainly to the government. The government would do well to make a declaration fairly soon about where its preferences are going and if, in fact, it is going to support the entry of people like this into our parliament.

The coalition should take note of the cartoon—even though not a very good one—of the Prime Minister and the Deputy Prime Minister. Tim Fischer, himself, has referred to it. As they are lined up in front of a firing squad, the Prime Minister is saying:

PARA.EMPHASIS: See Tim, if we had paid more for those guns in buy back, this couldn't happen.

BREAK.PARA: I do not know whether you want to laugh about it, but I do not really think it is a laughing matter.

Another target for this magazine is the whole vaccination program, which is the subject of a bill to be debated very shortly in this parliament, and on which the Democrats have certainly supported the government. The article speaks about vaccine causing polio and it says:

PARA.EMPHASIS: DPT vaccine has also been linked to cot death in a study conducted by Dr. V. Scheibner and Leif Karlsson, a bimechanical engineer, using baby breathing monitors. They concluded that DPT vaccine caused stress‐induced breathing and that children who had died from cot death most commonly died after DPT injection.

BREAK.PARA: So you can see the kind of crazy material that is put out by Lock Stock & Barrel and which supports the actions of the member for Oxley. I believe parliament ought to clearly condemn these actions. They should also be addressed by the government and I do not believe they are being effectively addressed at this time.

The Democrats call on the Howard government to take responsibility for the ugly wave of bigotry and intolerance that has been unleashed in its term of government and take steps to address it. For example, it should restore funding to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, apologise to the stolen generation and give the federal police more resources to investigate discriminatory materials being distributed in Oxley.

I believe we need to tackle this outbreak head‐on or it will become entrenched. If this outbreak is not tackled in Australia, particularly in my home state of Queensland, then we will face a reputation similar to that of the deep south of America where, for example, arson attacks on black churches continue. I do not want that for my country or my state and I fervently hope that the government does not want it either.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eggleston, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —I was delighted to see reports in today's press about the former Governor‐General Sir Zelman Cowen declaring his support for a republic. As the debate over Australia's head of state intensifies, those present in the chamber will be aware of the significance of a former Governor‐General, a former member of the Privy Council and a former defender of the monarchy now backing the republican cause.

SPEECH.PARA: Sir Zelman Cowen is one of Australia's foremost constitutional lawyers and was the Dean of Faculty of Law, University of Melbourne, before becoming Governor‐General. His conversion to the republican cause is a very significant step towards the goal of having an Australian institution for our national head of state.

The tide is certainly turning on the republican issue. I believe a country's head of state should symbolise the ethos, values and aspirations of a nation. It is for this reason that I personally support an Australian republic. I do not believe the British monarchy represents the values which characterise Australia. It follows, therefore, that I do not consider the monarchy to be an appropriate institutional format for the office of Australia's head of state.

Where are public opinion polls now on the subject of a republic? More than 40 years ago in 1953, 77 per cent of Australians supported the monarchy and only 15 per cent supported a republic. However, by December 1996 the AGB McNair poll, published in the Sydney Morning Herald, showed that a majority of Australians in all states except Tasmania supported conversion to a republic. This has been confirmed by the September 1997 Newspoll, conducted for the Australian, which showed that 54 per cent of Australians favoured a republic while only 30 per cent supported the monarchy, with 16 per cent being undecided.

I would like to say a little about the history of republicanism in Australia which first appeared in the 1850s, when the Australian colonies were attempting to gain self‐government from Britain. The republicans of the 1850s identified republicanism as a means of gaining political autonomy. Essentially, this derived from the axiom of 19th century nationalism, that all nations should be self‐governing.

When self‐government was granted to the Australian eastern colonies in the 1850s, republicanism—in terms of local independence—lost momentum and its sense of urgency. It was not until the 1880s that republicanism again became a strong sentiment in the Australian community. The republicans of the 1890s were driven less by a desire to be independent of the British government than by a desire to create a society which symbolised the spirit of Australia.

The ideal of Australia becoming a republic was pursued by many of those who participated in the federation debates during the 1890s. Among those were many of the writers for the Bulletin, including Henry Lawson and his mother, Louisa, who was the editor of a republican newsletter in Sydney in the 1880s and 1890s. However, conversion to independent republican status was not regarded as a feasible option by the harder heads in the Australian colonies, because towards the end of the last century the economic structure of the colonies was geared to providing food and raw materials to the British market and our security depended on the presence of the Royal Navy.

Similarly, economic and security considerations constrained the further development of republican sentiment in Australia for most of this century. However, the constitutional crisis of 1975 did result in some rekindling of support for the concept of an Australian republic, particularly in the left wing of Australian politics, and this probably explains why there has been something of an ALP flavour to the current resurgence of republican sentiment.

Now, in the 1990s, John Howard, as Prime Minister, while making no secret of his commitment to the constitutional monarchy, has recognised that there is strong sentiment in favour of a republic and that the matter is an issue for national discussion. He has provided a national forum for debate on the question of our head of state by establishing the Constitutional Convention to work through the issue. Personally, I am pleased that the Constitutional Convention is to go ahead, because I believe that, in focusing national attention on the issue, the debate will be considerably advanced and will strengthen support for Australia's conversion to a republic.

Australia has already broken a lot of the ties which once bound this country very closely to the United Kingdom. I would like to detail some of what I regard as the incremental steps towards a republic. Firstly, Australia's national anthem was changed from God Save the Queen to Advance Australia Fair on 21 May 1977. We no longer have God Save the Queen played in cinemas before the movie begins, as was the case until well into the 1960s and 1970s. I must say, it would now seem very strange to do that.

Secondly, Australia has its own flag and has not used the Union Jack as our official flag for many years. No government since 1945 has appointed a member of the royal family to hold the office of Governor‐General. When Buckingham Palace sent out feelers to the Australian government for the appointment of Prince Charles as Governor‐General in the early 1980s, it is said that it was found that there was very little political support for the idea.

In 1942, Australia adopted the Statute of Westminster. This statute was passed in the United Kingdom parliament in 1931 and stated that the British parliament would not legislate for any dominion without the request and consent of the dominion concerned. It is interesting that Canada and South Africa both accepted this independence from the British government much earlier and more readily than did Australia. It was probably only the imperatives of the Pacific War which caused Australia to adopt the Statute of Westminster because Australia needed to be in control of its resources for the war effort.

Finally, in 1986, Australian legal appeals to the Privy Council in London were abolished, so that the High Court of Australia became the final arbiter of the Australian legal system. Thus, slowly, step by step over the past half‐century, Australia has moved progressively away from, and become independent of, the United Kingdom government. Commenting on the slow ending of our dependence on the United Kingdom, John Hirst, a well‐known historian at La Trobe University and a leading conservative republican, has said, `All this has gone on and no alternative focus of civic loyalty and allegiance has replaced it.' His view is that, having moved away from Britain and the monarchy, Australians of today no longer readily accept the appropriateness of the Queen as our head of state.

For that reason, John Hirst suggests that there is a void in our national consciousness about our head of state and, in effect, he believes we are in a kind of transitional zone. I must say that it seems to me self‐evident that the Queen is no longer quite acceptable as our head of state. For example, nobody really wants her to open the Sydney Olympic Games, but we have not decided who or what the replacement should be.

In the circumstances that we find ourselves in in the 1990s, Australia is very different from the sort of place it was in earlier times in our history when republican sentiment existed. Today, the key constraints of security and trade which made it impractical for Australia to adopt a republican constitution in the past, no longer apply. To me, the question of the republic is a question of national maturity and national identity. One could ask: is it a matter of an idea which has reached its time? Personally, I would have to say, that this is the case.

Contemporary Australia has carved out its own role in the world. Just as in the mid‐1980s we took charge of our legal affairs by ending Australian appeals to the Privy Council, I believe that it is now appropriate for us to take charge of our political affairs by creating an Australian institution for our national head of state and, in so doing, converting the Commonwealth of Australia to a republic.

But unfortunately, as this debate is progressing, there is growing evidence that those who support the continuation of the British monarchy in Australia are perhaps not totally committed to rational debate on the question of whether we should have an Australian head of state. Disinformation is being put about, for example, that the Australian Republican Movement wants to change the Australian flag. This is simply not true. The ARM has no policy at all on changing the flag.

I frequently hear it said that the Australian Republican Movement does not know what it stands for. That, of course, is absolutely not true. The ARM supports, firstly, creating an Australian institution reflecting the democratic and egalitarian values of Australian society for our national head of state to replace the British monarchy in Australia.

Secondly, the office of head of state should be largely ceremonial. Thirdly, the ARM would want Australia to still be called the Commonwealth of Australia and we would still remain members of the British Commonwealth. Australia would still compete in the Commonwealth Games, and we would have still, of course, play cricket. Republican Australia would continue to recognise the Queen as the head of the British Commonwealth.
As I said, I think the tide of history is running in favour of an Australian republic.

BREAK.PARA: As the polls confirm the trend and show ever increasing support for the conversion of the Commonwealth to republican status, I do not think the time of change is very far away. Mr Acting Deputy President, I would seek leave to incorporate some tables of recent polls which show trends in support of the republic and the monarchy.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today in this debate to say a few words about the public sector. As a senator for the Australian Capital Territory, this particular subject has great relevance for the people I represent.

SPEECH.PARA: Canberra bashing is an expression, in my view, of anti‐public sector sentiment and, in the context of the Howard government's pursuit of such sentiment, a reflection of an anti‐government approach. It is not anti‐government in the sense that certainly Mr Howard is the head of the Liberal government, but anti‐government in the true sense of the word.

Governance of the people of Australia is something that every federal government has been aspiring to, certainly since Federation. But I put to this place that this government is not about the good governance of Australia and, in the context of the people who provide the service to the public in the employ of the federal government, that they do not respect or acknowledge the contribution that those people make to the good governance of this country.

I would like to take this opportunity to pay tribute to all those who are engaged in servicing the public of Australia. There are some 1.3 million, which represents one of the lowest proportions of public servants in the Western world and the expenditure is quite small in comparison, with only the United States of America and Japan spending less on their public service.

It is the pursuit of providing a service to the public that I want to focus my remarks on today. What we have seen over the last 18 months is not a rapid increase in improving the efficiencies and effectiveness of the Australian public sector. What we have seen goes far beyond that. Indeed, because of the work of previous governments, we have a very lean and efficient public sector.

What we are now seeing is a deconstruction of the ability of that sector to provide services to the public, a deconstruction that has come in many forms and that started with the changes to the Industrial Relations Act. Those changes undermined the morale and dignity of the working people in the employ of the federal government. Anyone who has worked on wages would know that having security of employment is probably one of the most important features of our general feeling of wellbeing, of having a safe and healthy workplace and remuneration adequate enough to ensure the welfare of ourselves and our families.

The changes, under the Workplace Relations Act, brought many pressures to bear in both the private and public sector. But the flow‐on effect from the changes that were put in place will disadvantage all Australians. That may seem like a big statement but, based on previous industrial relations awards systems, many of the gains made in the public sector by those working people impacted eventually through the private sector awards, pulling the standards of working people up right throughout the work force in this country.

There are other changes affecting the morale and dignity of the public sector in this country. The changes to the Public Service Act is one quite critical initiative that is currently occurring. Those changes again diminish the job security quite specifically of people employed in the public sector, as well as undermining their conditions of employment across a number of key facets. One of those key facets is equal employment opportunity.

It is important that public servants have the opportunity to be able to seek promotion, to provide fearless and frank advice and to have some redress if unfair decisions are made. The appeals process and the Merit Protection and Review Agency that this government is advocating abolishing go to the heart of those employment conditions that had built our public sector up into a strong and important contributor to Australian society.

There are other changes announced recently with respect to superannuation and outsourcing plans that affect the employment of people. But I just want to say something, perhaps on behalf of the people who are employed in the service of the public in this country, to everyone who is not so employed. Every time you hear the Prime Minister or this government criticise Canberra or the role of the public sector, what you are hearing is a government which is not advocating the good governance of this country. What you are hearing is the words of a government which prefers to see the governance of this country managed via a contract, or by a sector whose members do not, perhaps, put the interests of the public at the forefront of their considerations but put first either the interests of their shareholders or their ability to make a margin for the survival of their own company.

I do not want my comments to be misinterpreted as an attack on the private sector's role in the provision of services. The point I am making is: why introduce a layer into the provision of services in such a way that it compromises in some way, whether it is through efficiency or value for money, the effectiveness and the equity of delivery of those services?

Opportunities do exist across the board for a melding or a meshing of the mechanisms of service delivery to be agreed upon and formulated. That is fine, and we have seen examples of that operating effectively. What is not fine, and what will not serve the public interest, is an approach by this government to deconstruct the public sector completely.

What this government does not understand, as I think has been reflected in many of the comments by senior ministers, is that not everyone in Australian society is motivated by their salary package or by a need to climb up the socioeconomic ladder. There are some Australians who are quite prepared to serve in the interests of this country in whatever way they feel comfortable with. That means that there are people right throughout society—and I am focusing on those employed in the service of the public—that choose to do that job because they have a social conscience. They choose to work in such a way that their work will benefit others. This notion does not enter the consciousness of our Prime Minister. That observation is one that is most telling about his and his government's attitude towards both those employed in that sector and those Australians who stand to benefit from the equitable distribution of and access to the services provided in that context.

So where is the recognition and acclamation that many people in the service of the public deserve? The silence is deafening. What instead we get from the so‐called leaders of our country is massive cuts, forcing redundancies which the figures of the union which represents those workers show are now up around the 18,000 mark. That is 18,000 individuals. Add on to that their families that have been specifically disaffected by this government.

We have seen no less than four or five significant attacks on their conditions of employment. We have seen no less than three quite specific initiatives to deconstruct the public sector and the networks established to provide services to the public, be they physical or be they information services or indeed be they the regional centres employing public sector people. There is no acclamation from this government; there is only a barrage.

We feel it here in Canberra because a high percentage of our work force is employed in the public sector. It is a lot lower than it used to be but it is still in the high forties—48 per cent, I believe. So we are feeling it and probably the regional areas of this country are also feeling it. I have no doubt that metropolitan areas are feeling the results of the funding cuts and coordinated approaches provided previously, whether it is the closing down of the Medicare office or whether it is the changes to the employment programs that now preclude effective access and operation.

There is no acclamation for these people; there are only demoralising changes and funding cuts that appear to have to have no motivation beyond the driest of dry fiscal justifications. There must be a point when the current leadership of this government understands that to go any further and continue on this path will structurally undermine Australia's ability to service those in need. It is not good enough to set up a structure where those who can pay can still get access or where those who happen to live near an outlet providing services can walk to them. Those people are probably a lot better positioned to access services generally. It is the ones that are not that the public sector has been weighted towards.

Perhaps the most disaffected will be those that the Prime Minister has described as the interest groups, the fringe groups, the fringe dwellers. I think they are the most in need. If the public sector does not support those people in our society then no‐one else is going to because the only other people providing for society require, through their structure, the ability to make a margin for their existence to prevail.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Salvos?

—I am going to acknowledge that. Here is a strategy from the government. Let us look at the pressure that community groups and volunteer groups are already feeling under this government. Is it an acceptable policy approach for this government to turn to the goodwill of the volunteers of this country, who are under enormous pressure, to fill the gap in the public dollar? I do not believe that is acceptable public policy and if that is the solution, as was bandied across the chamber today, I am even more disturbed about the leadership of this country.
