TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I have more good news. I inform the Senate that, following the resignation of Senator Dominic Foreman due to ill health, Senator Kay Denman has been appointed Deputy Opposition Whip.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Minister, has your attention been drawn to media reports that the Minister for Family Services, Mrs Moylan, was `bucketed and ambushed' at yesterday's joint party meeting by members of `the sisterhood' who are alleged to have been dismayed by her handling of the portfolio and resentful of her position in the ministry? Has your attention also been drawn to the scurrilous allegation that you, of all ministers, abandoned Mrs Moylan when she looked to you for support in regard to criticism of the child‐care assistance application form, which was drafted by your department? Minister, do you deny that this incident took place or is it the case that, while the reports are essentially correct, your role in this sordid episode has been badly and sadly misreported by the media? Minister, will you assure the Senate that you were not party to this, one way or the other?

—It is a pity the opposition does not learn to sift fact from fiction. Clearly, Senator Faulkner is much more interested in fiction than he is in fact. I have always made a point, in my time in the parliament, not to speak about matters that took place in the shadow cabinet, in the cabinet or in my party room. I do not intend to move from that position now.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Apparently the minister will not acknowledge her role in this matter. Minister, the Prime Minister is on record as having stated that Minister Moylan deserves `support and commendation' for her efforts. Do you agree with the Prime Minister on that? If so, why didn't you offer it to her?

—Minister Moylan has been a friend of mine from the time she came into the parliament. We work closely together. We have a close, warm and continuing relationship. We have supported each other in many a circumstance over the years and I fully expect it to continue for the future. So don't think you have pulled one on this one!

—My question is addressed to Senator Newman, Minister for Social Security. Minister, the Prime Minister officially launched Centrelink this morning, the new agency responsible for the delivery of Commonwealth government services to Australians. How will Centrelink work and how will it improve service delivery to Australians around the country from a wide range of backgrounds? What will it mean for those Australians who receive payments such as newstart, family payment, sole parent pension, the disability support pension, the age pension, Austudy, child‐care assistance and other government support?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Troeth is prepared to ask the important questions that need to be addressed in the Senate and I am very glad to have the opportunity to answer this very sensible question. Centrelink, which was launched, as Senator Troeth said, by the Prime Minister today, is a service delivery agency of great importance for the delivering of government assistance and programs. It has been a major innovation in government service delivery. It is an historic reform.

ANSWER.PARA: Probably, as the Prime Minister said today, in the context of the last 50 years there has not been a more important reform in terms of delivery of services to Australians. It puts government services under the one roof. It provides a one‐stop shop for information about government assistance and for programs for Australians from all around the country and from a wide range of backgrounds. It is going to be the human face of government with a focus on customer service, no more queues or standing behind counters, better forms and more user‐friendly correspondence.

We all know how government departments seem to have had a knack of writing to constituents letters which are beyond understanding and certainly quite frightening. We are trying to change all that. We believe that the services under Centrelink will be more convenient for customers and more efficient in the use of taxpayers' funds in delivering services. It will operate through 400 centres around Australia employing some 24,000 staff.

We have almost eight million customers, when you take into account the elderly on age pensions, families, the disabled and people who need unemployment assistance, and make 159 million payments every year. So we are going to be covering the services that have been provided in the past by Social Security, by the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, by the Department of Health and Family Services and by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. We are going to be providing all the services that Social Security used to provide: child‐care and student assistance payments, registration of applicants for income support and for employment assistance, self‐help job search facilities, referrals for employment assistance and specialist labour market assistance.

As I have said, it is all about better and more efficient service. We have heard for so long now the frustration that Australians—particularly, but not only, people in country areas—have found in trying to do business with different government offices, where they have had to go to the CES and fill in one long form and stand in one lot of queues to register that they are unemployed and then go to the social security department, fill in another form, stand in more queues, and get more anguished and frustrated.

It has been a very important thing today to have the Prime Minister launch this new enterprise of the Commonwealth government. He said in his speech today that the first constituent concerns he heard as a new member of parliament, and they have continued on ever since, related to the frustration that his constituents found in trying to access and deal with different government departments.

I think many of the people watching question time today would express that same concern. We have done something about it. There are different services under the one roof for the very first time. The chief executive officer of the agency is a woman, Sue Vardon, who was the Telstra Businesswoman of the Year in 1995. She is responsible for 24,000 staff and payments of about $40 billion every year. I congratulate the staff of the agency, who were from the CES and DSS, who have worked so well to come together to make this enormous reform. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Thank you for that information, Minister. I would be particularly interested to know the significance of Centrelink for people living in country areas of Australia and how that initiative will improve their access to government services. Would you also explain what action the government has taken to improve the telephone service offered by Centrelink, which is of particular importance to people living in rural and remote areas.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you very much, Senator Troeth. The issues that you raise are vitally important for people in country Australia. As I said, those 400 offices are right around Australia. This morning the Chairman of Centrelink, Mr Marrett, said that, if he set out on foot to visit each office, he would be gone for at least a year. Even using aeroplanes and cars, it has been taking me a long time to visit the offices.

ANSWER.PARA: For instance, there are offices in towns like Young and Cowra in New South Wales, where they did not have a social security office and now they do have one. There is an office in Goondiwindi in Queensland that did not have a CES and now has one. There are also offices in Kununurra in Western Australia, Ararat in Victoria, Coober Pedy in South Australia, Queenstown in Tasmania, Tennant Creek in the Northern Territory and Bourke in New South Wales. We are looking at pilot programs with the state governments so that we can have one‐stop state and Commonwealth offices in country areas where it is not viable to have individual offices. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's gallery of Mr Frank de Grave, Vice Minister for Social Affairs and Employment in the government of the Netherlands. On behalf of honourable senators, I welcome you to the Senate and wish that your visit here will be both informative and enjoyable.
—Hear, hear!

—My question is directed to Senator Newman, the Minister for Social Security. I refer to your entry in the register of interests of 28 November last year when you declared a loan from your private company, Frome Holdings Pty Ltd, to yourself. Are you aware that, in the budget, the Treasurer announced a crackdown on such loans because they are used for tax avoidance? Can you confirm that your loan is an excluded loan, at commercial rates, on commercial terms, and not just a tax minimisation arrangement for your personal benefit?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I am trying to find the most accurate way to give you the detailed information, because it is not something that is foremost in my mind. I can certainly check the detail as to how this is technically described and let Senator Sherry know. Certainly, I have not been a party to improper practices and I have always declared my circumstances.

ANSWER.PARA: That is a company of which I no longer have any director's responsibility. Since the time I have been a minister, I have had no involvement in the running of the company. That is the best I can answer for you now. I will certainly get more information for you, if you need anything further.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. You may just check part of your answer, Minister, because I understand you are still a shareholder in the company. In light of your answer, will you table the loan agreement from Frome Holdings to you that will prove the loan is an excluded loan and not in breach of the proposed changes to section 108 of the tax act as outlined by the Treasurer in May; or are you just another creative minister engaging in tax avoidance, along with half your colleagues who have shown a flair for such activities through their multitude of trusts?
—Madam President, I am perfectly prepared to do whatever is legally required of me in order to satisfy the shadow minister's question.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance. I note a number of positive comments today in response to the government's proposed changes to the superannuation arrangements for Commonwealth employees. Will the minister inform the Senate of the rationale for these changes to Public Service superannuation arrangements and, in particular, the desirability of workers having greater choice in their superannuation arrangements.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for that important question which is of great interest to public servants in this country. I noted, Senator Gibson, as you might have noted this morning, that there was an article by Daryl Dixon in the Canberra Times commenting on the changes that were announced by the government in relation to Public Service superannuation. The article was headed `PS super scheme changes mean winners all round'.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Lundy interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lundy, that is what it said. Senator Lundy, I know you have a particular interest in Public Service matters, as you should, but you have to make sure that, in the representations you make, you represent public servants, not public servant union leaders. Let me tell you that the two can have quite different views, as so often has happened in the past.
—Perhaps you can tell that to the 18,000 who have lost their jobs under your government.

—Senator Lundy is getting very excited because the CPSU does not like it. The new superannuation arrangements for Commonwealth employees announced yesterday by the Minister for Finance will provide Commonwealth employees with more choice and opportunities in managing their superannuation. The changes are in line with the government's 1997 budget commitment to facilitate greater choice in superannuation arrangements across the work force. Senator Sherry has said on some occasions that he is in favour of choice.
—Informed choice.

—There is always, of course, a big `but', but he is in favour of choice. I will be interested to see whether Senator Sherry can reach a position on this one because he has so much difficulty elsewhere.

ANSWER.PARA: Under the arrangements announced yesterday, Commonwealth public servants will enjoy the same opportunities in respect of choice of superannuation as private employees. The government is acting as a responsible employer in implementing the choice of fund arrangements which will apply to private sector employers. The government is strongly committed to providing workers with choice over their superannuation. The choice of fund arrangements will give Australian workers a greater degree of control over their superannuation which in turn will give them a greater sense of ownership of these savings.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is small business saying about those funds?
—Senator Mackay asks about small business. They are the anti-small business party. They had 13 years. You are the anti-small business party.
—They are bucketing your changes. Too much administration; that's what they are saying. They are bucketing your changes.

—Senator Mackay, I keep on telling you that we are the party of small business and we are the party of the battlers; you are the party of the big unions and the union leaders. That is the difference between us. You do not understand that.
—Too much red tape; that's what they are saying.
—Red tape!

—Senator Lundy says `red tape' in relation to small business. I could quote you a stream of examples—for example, unfair dismissals. That is what you did. Remember that? That is what you did for small business, Senator Lundy.

—Senator Kemp, you are in breach of the standing orders by directing your remarks to a senator across the chamber. I am particularly interested in the answer to this question of Senator Gibson and would invite you to apply yourself to it.
—Thank you, Madam President. But, as you can see, I was being unduly provoked from the other side of the chamber.

BREAK.PARA: Choice will have a positive effect on attitudes in the community. Choice, along with the taxation rebate for savings, we believe will help promote a savings culture in this country. The choice of fund arrangements will be more flexible and responsive to the retirement income needs of all Australians. The initiative will increase competition and efficiency in the superannuation industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, will Commonwealth employees be disadvantaged by the proposed changes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said and as was said in the newspaper today—and I hold that up because Senator Lundy obviously missed it—under the heading `PS super scheme changes mean winners all round', the government is not forcing workers into any particular arrangement. Existing government employees will have the option of continuing in their current superannuation scheme with no change to their existing arrangements or choosing to move to another fund or retirement savings account if that better suits their personal circumstances.

ANSWER.PARA: The remuneration of existing and future Commonwealth employees will not be reduced by these changes. The government will continue to fund agencies at the existing cost levels of the current Commonwealth superannuation schemes. The last year has been a very good year for superannuation and this is more good news.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Minister, are you aware of a survey conducted by the Australian Bureau of Statistics of nearly 2,500 people aged between 45 and 75 undertaken for the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia by Melbourne University researcher Roslyn Cornish, which shows that 81 per cent of men and 64 per cent of women who had retired early between 1992 and 1996 reported being forced into early retirement rather than choosing early retirement? How does this data reconcile with your claims that your measures to include superannuation assets in the means test for over‐55s is designed to stop people whom you, Senator Newman, describe as `the millionaires of Australia who have extraordinary amounts of superannuation tucked away in hollow logs'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting that Senator Murphy should ask that question, because I found the press release put out by ASFA quite interesting. It said, for instance, that the majority of early retirees have superannuation of less than $40,000—that is, of course, something that I have told you in this chamber several times before. Customers with superannuation of less than $40,000 will not be affected by the changes to the over‐55s superannuation measure unless they have considerable other assets.

ANSWER.PARA: For example, an allowance couple with a $40,000 lump sum with no income from any other sources would not be affected by the income test and would need to have over $138,500 in other assets apart from their home to be affected by the assets test. The means test arrangements protect customers with smaller amounts of savings. Only those with significant savings or other assets will be affected by this measure and in most cases the interest earned on their funds should offset any reductions in payments.

ASFA suggests that the unemployed should be excluded from the change. To apply the change depending on whether a person considered they had retired or were unemployed would be inequitable and would create an obvious avenue for avoidance. What we have done in this measure, as you would well know, is simply to replace the position that you changed in 1993 to the extent that somebody who was not eligible for a pension if they were at age pension age became eligible for unemployment benefits if they were 55.

BREAK.PARA: That is a nonsense. You should not be eligible for that if you have got the means to support yourself in terms of assessment for a pension. Why should the taxpayer be asked to support you in the years immediately prior to that?

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, the research also showed that men who had retired before pension age—and this might be those that have more than $40,000—for other than voluntary reasons, had a high degree of dependence on government pensions and benefits. Isn't this research proof that your government has abandoned older male workers who have been retrenched or have taken non‐voluntary redundancies and is punishing them by forcing them to draw on their retirement nest eggs? Why wasn't that something that the Prime Minister should have explained to the BHP workers at Newcastle, whom he has condemned to no future at all?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Murphy has a problem understanding this, but let me say that ASFA defines the phrase `early retirees' to include people who are induced to retire early because of a lack of a job or for health reasons.
—What about people who use the money to pay off their home loans et cetera?
—Just listen, if you want to learn something. Do you mind? ASFA suggests that the bulk of people—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I was asked a question and I am trying to answer.
—Order! Senator Newman, please continue.

—ASFA suggests that the bulk of the people who `retire early' and receive unemployment benefits do so for factors beyond their control rather than to rort the system. That seems to us to be correct and it is not inconsistent at all with what I have been saying. While there have been financial planners encouraging people with assets of a million dollars to move into this area, the majority of people have not been in those circumstances. In fact, the majority have had superannuation of less than $40,000 and have not been affected at all. (Time expired)

—My question is addressed to Senator Ellison, the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology. The Cassini space probe is due to be launched on 14 October, or no later than 15 November this year, carrying some 33 kilograms or 33,000 grams of plutonium. Given the government's expressed concern when the Russian space probe Mars 96 re‐entered the earth's atmosphere last year with its deadly cargo of 24 grams of radioactive plutonium, will the government make representations to the United States government about the threat of nuclear material being deposited over Australia and the world by the Cassini space probe? When will you make that representation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised by Senator Hill that that has been answered on notice. I was given notice of this question and I have been advised that in relation to the Cassini mission, which involves the European agencies, NASA and Italian agencies in sending a spacecraft to Saturn and return, the Cassini mission has undergone an extensive safety evaluation as part of the normal nuclear safety launch approval process, by an interagency nuclear safety review panel comprising the US government, industry and academic experts. Cassini will deploy the Huygens planetary probe to explore the atmosphere of Saturn's largest moon, Titan, adding greatly to our scientific knowledge of the formation and composition of this planet and its moons, and the solar system generally.

ANSWER.PARA: It is critical that Cassini is launched on schedule by November this year or the mission could face a two‐year delay, substantial cost overruns and a greatly reduced scientific pay‐off. As there are no viable power alternatives for Cassini itself or for devices aboard the Huygens probe, any action to influence the US government in this regard is not considered warranted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question, Madam President. The minister mentioned NASA's evaluation and I am wondering: does the government accept, then, the environmental impact statement from NASA regarding Cassini which states that some five billion people could be exposed to radiation and radioactive material following an accident in the earth's atmosphere? Does the government sanction this use of plutonium—and so much use of plutonium—when it comes to Cassini? I ask: what guarantee the government or the minister can give the Australian people that they will not be subjected to radioactive material in the case of an accident with this space probe?
—Senator Stott‐Despoja has raised a number of matters that were not alluded to and I will refer them to the relevant minister.

—My question is to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. I refer to your earlier answer to Senator Gibson and the torrent of rhetoric we heard. Will you guarantee—no ifs, no buts, no waffle—that new Commonwealth employees will receive the same level of notional employer contributions, currently around 13 per cent, into their new superannuation arrangements as existing APS employees? If not, how can you claim you are not breaking your pre‐election promise not to reduce employer contributions to public sector superannuation and to retain separate arrangements for public sector superannuation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Sherry for that comment. I have been waiting for a while to get a question from Senator Sherry. The last time I got a question from Senator Sherry I congratulated him on being appointed shadow Assistant Treasurer. Today, I would like to commiserate with him for being dropped as shadow Assistant Treasurer. I just wanted to be consistent and put that on record.

ANSWER.PARA: Also I would like to make the point that we are providing public servants, of course, with the same rights as people in the private sector will be having. I would have thought that would have been widely welcomed by the Public Service.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you give a guarantee?

—Senator Sherry, you didn't listen to my answer. That has always been a bit of a problem with you. You did not listen to the answer I gave. So, Senator Sherry, I will say this to you again; I will read it:

BREAK.PARA: The remuneration of existing and future Commonwealth employees will not be reduced by these changes. The government will continue to fund agencies at the existing cost levels of the current Commonwealth superannuation schemes.

Have you got that down, Senator Sherry? I know that you often get it wrong on superannuation. While we are on superannuation, it would be of interest to people in the chamber, in the light of some of the comments by Senator Sherry over recent months, that I have had a chance to speak to many people on superannuation and to review how the last year went in superannuation.

Senator Sherry, I have some good news for you and your hairdresser. Senator Sherry said on radio that he was advised by his hairdresser that they had lost confidence in superannuation. You did, Senator Sherry. If you ask me a supplementary, I may be able to go through my papers and find you the quote.

The last year has been a very good year for the superannuation industry. You would not have believed it if you had listened to Labor members and senators. Senator Sherry, as I have said before, this is good news for the Public Service and good news for the superannuation industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I note, Senator Kemp, that you will not give an unequivocal guarantee in respect of a reduction in benefits. Senator Kemp, given the proposed changes, what advice, if any, has the government received from the Australian Government Actuary concerning the viability of the PSS or the CSS, given that your proposal to close the PSS could undermine its stability for remaining members?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sherry, you are noted for your silly scare tactics in relation to superannuation. You have established an incredible record over the last year with hundreds of quotes saying how awful things were in superannuation, and you are on the same track again. This is what Senator Sherry said:

ANSWER.PARA: I do not believe you can claim that, because money flowing into superannuation has increased, confidence has not declined. We would submit all the anecdotal evidence we are receiving—including from my hairdresser . . . he has been cutting my hair for 18 years.
Well, you tell Stefan or Johann or whoever he is, Senator Sherry, that it is a good year for superannuation and it is good for public servants.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill. I refer the minister to the agreement in January 1996 to expand the production of uranium at Roxby Downs and to the fact that there were two fundamental conditions placed on that approval for expansion: independent auditing of the operations of the mine and the establishment of improved community consultation methods. Can the minister provide details of independent auditing at Roxby Downs, particularly how the contract was arranged and the terms of reference? Can he also table copies of any audit documents that have been produced? Can he indicate to what extent Commonwealth environment agencies have reviewed that audit or the criteria from the audit? What action has been taken to establish more broadly based community consultation? Has the membership of the community consultative forum and its terms of reference been finalised? If so, can the minister provide details? Can he indicate what role the committee will play in the current EIS for the next expansion?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Most of the answers the honourable senator seeks were set out in a press release of mine dated 11 June 1997. I will send a copy of that to Senator Margetts in case she missed it.
—What about the rest of us?

—I will send a copy to all of you if you like. Just let me know. These were recommendations made by the previous government. This was after approval by the previous Labor government for expansion of Roxby Downs. You know their three-mine uranium policy: apparently increasing this uranium mine was legitimate; opening a new one is illegitimate. This was good uranium as opposed to bad uranium. What was even more surprising was that this approval was given without a further environmental impact study—a little surprising, I would have thought. I guess that means it was very good uranium; it did not require any further environmental studies.

ANSWER.PARA: Nevertheless, there were a series of recommendations which we basically accepted. The honourable senator has referred to two of those recommendations. In relation to the consultative committee, the press release sets out the format that it has been agreed it should have. The composition of that committee representatives is being worked through now between the Commonwealth and the South Australian government agencies. It is expected that nominees to both committees will be called for and appointments made in the near future. As far as I can recall, and I will check the record, the independent audit recommendations were accepted also. I will get the honourable senator detail of what independent audit is to be provided.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I did read the press statement. It said `will be established', and that is exactly why I asked the question about what action has been taken. Clearly the minister has indicated it has not happened yet. That is a precondition, I believe. It is my understanding that the terms of the indenture agreement between Western Mining Corporation and the South Australian government stipulate that no document, including, presumably, documents associated with the `independent audit', can be released without the approval of the parties to the agreement. Does the minister agree that this throws serious doubt on the independence of the independent audit?

—From my memory, the independent audit actually has to be provided to the representative committee. I would have thought that would give to the honourable senator the confidence in the process that she is seeking. Obviously some aspects of the audit would relate to matters that are commercial‐in‐confidence and she would not expect that to be put on the public record. Provided that the committee is set up and works in the way that we intend it to work—and that is what we will ensure will happen—then I am sure that she can have confidence in the processes that are being adopted to give the community, in turn, confidence that the highest environmental standards will continue to be met by this mining venture—a venture, I might say, that brings considerable wealth and opportunity to South Australians.

—My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, how do you justify beneficiaries of trusts used for tax avoidance being able to qualify for the $450 savings rebate and the $150 low income rebate which enables each and every trust beneficiary to receive $8,400 a year tax free? Given this and in light of the Prime Minister's statement that he will not be claiming the savings rebate, do you believe that ministers should allow beneficiaries of trusts under their control to claim the $450 savings rebate just to avoid tax?
—Senator George Campbell, you do not seem to understand that it is a rebate which is applied to people who qualify. The qualifications are set out in the budget statement.
—He is asking you to justify it.

—Senator Campbell may not understand this but it is very clear that the vast proportion of the funds which are available under the rebate will flow to low and middle income people. You do not appear to understand that, Senator Campbell. Senator Campbell, it is interesting for you to get up and ask your first question.
—Answer the question.
—Order! There are too many interjections on my left.

—We believe it is a very fair measure. It is an equitable measure. Senator Campbell, you might not realise it but it is a measure that has been very widely welcomed in the superannuation industry which the Labor movement, I thought, did have a passing interest in. I welcome the first question from Senator Campbell. Is that the George Campbell that Mr Keating, the Labor Prime Minister, was referring to when he said, `I say this to George Campbell and all the others—that they carry the jobs of dead men around their necks.'
—Madam President, on a point of order—
—Order! Senators on my right will cease interjecting so I can hear Senator Faulkner's point of order.

—Madam President, I think you know that Senator Kemp, asked a specific question by Senator Campbell, is required and obligated under the standing orders, which you are charged to enforce, to answer or to try to answer the question.
—Order! There are far too many interjections on both sides.

—It may be of great interest to Senator Kemp and perhaps even other members of the government to quote from some document about Senator Campbell. I imagine any diversion away from Mr Jull or Mr Sharp would be of great interest to the government today. But, Madam President, you are obligated to demand that Senator Kemp at least attempt to answer this question. If he cannot, he ought to sit down. Quoting from a document about Senator Campbell or anyone else is not in order. I ask you, Madam President, on this occasion to rule this way and sit the minister down if he cannot provide the justification that Senator Campbell asked for in his question.

—On the point of order, I think I can give a bit of perspective on this for Senator Faulkner. I thought the question did not precisely deal with the facts. It made comments about tax avoidance and it made aspersions on people. It would be very handy for Senator Campbell to find out early that if he wants to get up in this chamber and make aspersions about people he must be prepared to take them back. I am sure George Campbell is prepared to take it back because he can give it and he can take it. Senator Faulkner has always had a glass jaw and he has proved it once again.

—Order! The question ought to be dealt with in the fashion that it has been asked. Aspersions ought not to be cast on anybody by anybody asking a question or by anybody answering. I think Senator Kemp perhaps had gone beyond what was necessary to answer the question at that time. Is there anything more you wish to say on the question?
—Yes, there is one more thing I can add. Peter Cook has just confirmed to me that that was the George Campbell I was quoting—much appreciated and thank you once again.
—Madam President, on a point of order—
—Order! Senators on my right will make less noise.
—I am just astonished. I never did any such thing. I cannot use the word `lie' in here but that is as close as I ever have come to hearing a senator actually commit an untruth in this chamber.
—Order!

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Will you ask the Prime Minister to instruct his ministers that they are not to claim the savings rebate through their trusts in order to avoid tax? If not, why not?
—If, Senator Cook, you say you did not tell me that—but I thought you did—I apologise.

—Madam President, I rise on a point of order. You have previously in question time today directed one minister's attention—in fact, this minister responsible for answering the supplementary question asked by Senator Campbell—to the fact that he ought not address his comments to a senator across the chamber and not through you. But, Madam President, you would also be aware that the minister was asked a specific question and ought to answer it. Whatever Senator Cook, or any other person, may think, it is not even a remote attempt on the part of this minister to answer the question. Obviously, this particular minister holds your rulings in contempt. Why do you not on this occasion undertake what I think is an obligation on your part—that is, require the minister to either answer the question or, if he will not answer the question and he defies your ruling, sit him down as you are required to do?
—Madam President—
—Order! I do not need any help on this, but if you insist.
—Madam President, there is one matter—
—Order! There is far too much shrieking and carrying on today. It is absolutely disrupting and making a nonsense of question time.
—Madam President, I think it is important that we understand the rules of the game that should operate here.
—It is not a game, Senator Alston; it is a serious operation of the Senate.

—I accept that, Madam President, but I do not think for one moment that you or any other senator would allow Senator Faulkner to say what he just said about Senator Kemp being the minister who simply treats the rules of this parliament with contempt. I submit that you should require him to withdraw that clear aspersion, that clear breach of the standing orders, and to not throw in those sorts of gratuitous insults under the guise of making a submission.

—I do not accept your proposition, Senator Faulkner, that Senator Kemp is flouting my rulings. Senator Kemp, in answering this question, clearly allowed himself, firstly, to be diverted and, secondly, to respond to Senator Cook. He should not have done that. He has 46 seconds left to deal with the supplementary question.
—Thank you, Madam President. Senator Campbell, I am answering your question, if you would like to listen.
—Senator Kemp, direct your remarks through the chair and not across the chamber.

—I was seeking to answer Senator Campbell's question, but I noticed that he was diverted. I wish to draw his attention to the fact that this is a very fair measure. It is an equitable measure. The savings rebate has been widely accepted, and I will not be speaking to the Prime Minister on that matter.

—My question is to Senator Hill, the Minister for the Environment. Minister, during the last election campaign, the coalition gave a commitment to the Australian people to initiate the largest ever environmental rescue program in Australian history—a commitment delivered on with the establishment of the Natural Heritage Trust. Will the minister advise the Senate as to the progress of the implementation of programs under the trust, particularly in relation to efforts to protect and restore Australia's native bushland? Will the minister also explain how the activities of the trust are complemented by other recent environmental initiatives of the Howard government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be pleased to do so. It is true that last Friday the Howard government launched the national vegetation initiative, which we have called bushcare. It was a historic occasion because it was the launch of a program that gives the best chance to revegetate Australia that we have ever seen.

ANSWER.PARA: You will know, Madam President, that for 200 years we have been clearing this country. In fact, there has not been one year in which we have revegetated more than we have cleared, and we as a government are determined to turn that around. To do so, we have put in place a $350 million investment in retaining and protecting remnant bush and in revegetating. To launch that at the national landcare conference last Friday was, in fact, a great privilege.

BREAK.PARA: This will mean a tenfold increase in investment in revegetation programs in this country. In fact, some seven-odd very small dispersed programs that the previous government ran will now not only be combined but have that enormous increase in capital support. Not surprisingly, this is being welcomed by all Australians interested in the challenge of revegetating our country, and the response from community groups has really been enormous. I must say that that is particularly pleasing.

I had the opportunity also on Friday to announce a contract of $4.5 million with Greening Australia, which has established itself as perhaps the paramount of non-government organisations with expertise in this particular field. This contract will allow it to support community groups with that expertise all the way across Australia in order, therefore, that the community contributions will be made on the basis of best practice.

Community applications for support under the bushcare program are in and have been vetted through the regional assessment processes and the state assessment processes. I have had the opportunity, as a member of the ministerial board, to peruse them in relation so far to Western Australia, South Australia and Victoria. Announcements to those community groups will be made in the very near future.

This program supports the range of environmental programs that the Howard government has been able to commence, particularly in the area of nature conservation. I am very pleased to be part of a government that is taking nature conservation so seriously.

You will be aware that the task force that we set up on whaling to look at ways in which Australia might lead the world towards an end to commercial whaling has now put down its report, and that is being considered by the government. We will respond to that in the near future. I am very much looking forward to the government taking up that challenge, and it will be applauded by all Australians.

You will be aware that we are the first government anywhere in the world, in fact, to put in place dugong sanctuaries to protect that particular mammal. I think that is a great initiative. In relation to the albatross, of course, you would be aware that we have it listed under the Bonn convention. We are leading on the development of a regional plan to protect albatrosses that are greatly threatened, particularly from inappropriate fishing practices.

You will be aware of the investment we have put in to protect cassowaries in the program outside of Cairns designed to protect that particular bird. A week or so ago, I announced that we were adding particular protections to seahorses and sea dragons. As far as I know, we are the first government in any country in the world to initiate such protections. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, can you confirm that you were one of the senior government ministers who have been approached by Liberal colleagues and donors about the government's now aborted crackdown on the use of trusts to avoid tax? Do you deny that pressure from these groups has prompted the Prime Minister to back away from the proposed crackdown, as reported in the press today? Can you tell us how many battlers have trusts and how many will lose out as a result of the Prime Minister's decision as reported?
—Madam President, I am intrigued by this question.
—Try to answer it.
—Order! Senator Kemp, just wait. There are far too many interjections. If you ask a question, you should at least listen in silence.

—Hear, hear! Thank you, Madam President. I am intrigued by this question. Of course, the issue of the taxation of trusts, as Senator Collins may know, arose initially with legislation which was proposed by the former government—you are aware of that?—in 1995, I think. That then lay on the table for a long time. I do not know, but I suspect the former government was a bit slow to move on it, so that lay on the table.

BREAK.PARA: We announced that we would accept the general broad thrust of that policy. There was extensive consultation—particularly in relation to some adverse effects that some people felt were unfair—and there was a great deal of public discussion on this matter. The Treasurer announced some changes to those trust measures, Senator. I think those changes were widely welcomed in the community. In the latest budget we indicated that there would be a further review of trusts. That was an announcement the Treasurer made in the budget, and that review is continuing.

Senator, we welcome input from a wide range of people. We notice that the Labor Party, as they always do, duck the hard issues. Senator, you were in government for 13 years. Were you worried about the taxation of trusts when you were in government for 13 years? Just as you were coming to the end, you then thought that you would propose some changes. But, Senator, you never put those changes through the parliament.

This is an important issue. There has been widespread consultation and discussion on this issue, extending over a very long period of time. The measures that we have announced are public measures. I thought they were welcomed by the Labor Party. I am intrigued that you may have asked a question which is contrary to your current policy. I shall look closely at the comments that the former shadow assistant Treasurer made on this issue to see whether you are not on message there. I think you may be off message.
We are a government which consults, and we consult widely. The taxation of trusts is a very complex issue. It was an issue that your government, in the end, could never tackle.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, since you were not able to answer my question about how many battlers have trusts, perhaps you might be able to make that one of the terms of reference for this review you have pre-empted. Further, was the backdown decided by cabinet? If so, how many ministers absented themselves on the basis of a conflict of interest?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I think you are misreading the whole press on this, Senator Collins. I do not know who is feeding you these questions, but I have always warned you not to take questions from Senator Sherry. The argument in the press this morning was that small companies would be affected. That was the debate. You have actually missed the point. You have genuinely missed the point. Senator, I am intrigued.

ANSWER.PARA: I just say for the record that the Labor government were in office for 13 years. At the end, they proposed some changes to the taxation of trusts but never got them through the parliament. Like so many other issues, Senator, you ducked it. I do think you are probably off message. I will look at the response of the Labor Party to the trust measures. I think you are off message.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Prime Minister, and I wish to follow the line of questioning from Senator Collins. My question is about trusts, and I preface it by declaring a personal interest as a member of a trust, and this is declared in the pecuniary interests register. Minister, I refer to media reports of yesterday's joint party meeting and ask: why has the Prime Minister interfered in the tax office's review of trusts—a review actively promoted by his own Treasurer—by assuring coalition MPs that small business trusts will be protected for tax planning purposes? Isn't the tax commissioner now under extreme pressure to narrow the ATO review to conform with the PM's remarks, if he expects government support for legislative changes? Is the government still concerned that income being funnelled through tax minimising trusts is rising at more than twice the rate of the PAYE system and is now over $116 billion a year? (Time expired)

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —If the Prime Minister said, as was reported yesterday, that the government would not be doing anything that would bankrupt small business, then I can quite understand that, because we are actually on the side of small business. Not surprisingly, a review of taxation would take that into account.

ANSWER.PARA: We actually believe that small business is the key to job creation in this country. That is why we have put so much emphasis on policies that have enabled interest rates to come down five times since we got into government, on policies that keep inflation low and on the reform of the industrial relations system, to give greater flexibility to benefit small employers in their employment. And that is why we are looking in part at taxation reform as well—in order to support small business.

I regret that you seem to have misunderstood the outcomes of yesterday's discussions—or what was reported—because I can assure you that any adoption of taxation reform will be consistent with our wanting small business to grow and prosper.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, given your statement, if I can rephrase it, that your party is totally committed to pursuing trusts, will the Prime Minister ensure that the tax commissioner and the Treasurer are able to pursue trusts which are being used for tax avoidance or undue tax minimisation? Will you give that assurance to the Senate?

—Nothing has changed from the announcement in the budget that a discussion paper on the taxation of trusts will be released. Obviously, there are issues relating to taxation of trusts. I agree with what Senator Murray said: the expansion of trusts has been considerable. And there are, particularly in relation to large business, questions of equity relating to that. That will be taken into account. So it has not been affected at all. But I reiterate that this government is firmly on the side of small business, and taxation reform, to which we are committed, will actually be designed to support small business growth, particularly in order that we might expand employment.

—My question without notice is directed to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. Minister, has your attention been drawn to comments by the Malaysian Prime Minister, Dr Mahathir, that currency trading was `unnecessary, unproductive and immoral'? Do you support his call that such trading should be banned? Is it the case, as Dr Mahathir claims, that some of the measures proposed in the Thai rescue package amount to a deliberate attempt to hijack and impoverish Asian countries?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, Australia is a very strong supporter of the international monetary system and of its institutions, including, of course, bodies like the IMF which promote that system—
—I hope so.

—Well, this is an answer to the question. A serious question was asked and I am responding to it. Australia participated fully in the IMF support package for Thailand, which was accompanied by the adoption by the Thai government of a major economic policy package to address the problems which were apparent in the Thai financial system and to establish sound settings for the economy. In this government—and I expect that this is a bipartisan policy—we are strong supporters of the international monetary system, and we participated fully, because we believed it was important—

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Faulkner interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Faulkner, it was a serious question which I have responded to in detail. Your yabbering and chattering on there is pathetic. Madam President, you have had occasion to make comments about this side of the chamber. You would be aware that it is very difficult to answer a question with Senator Faulkner choking and jabbering as he does. Senator Denman, I can confirm that we support the international monetary system and we strongly supported the package for Thailand.
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal expla nation on the grounds that I have been misrepresented.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In question time, Senator Kemp commenced to read a quote during an answer to Senator George Campbell. At that time, Senator Faulkner correctly, in my view, took a point of order. Later, in speaking to the point of order, Senator Kemp said words to the effect that `Peter Cook has confirmed that the quote refers to George Campbell.' I never did any such thing at all, and Senator Kemp knows full well that I did not. Standing orders prevent my saying on this occasion that the minister has lied, and I cannot say that. If standing orders did not prevent my saying it, I would say it.

SPEECH.PARA: At the time of Senator Faulkner's point of order, I said across the chamber to Senator Kemp that he had now gone over the top and he was going too far. The videotape of the incident will show that that is the case. Senator Kemp has, I think, now gone too far in repeating the allegation, and he should withdraw it and apologise for making an unfounded allegation in the first place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—There are some facts I think we are agreed on. While there was some difficulty in the chamber, Senator Cook did make a comment which I thought confirmed the fact that that was the George Campbell. Then Senator Cook indicated that he did not do that. I then stood up, if you remember correctly, and said, rather graciously, I have to say, words to the effect—and the videotape will show this, so you can ask your staff to replay the videotape—that if it is the case, as Senator Cook says, he did not confirm that that was George Campbell, I apologise. I think the Hansard will show that, Senator Cook.

SPEECH.PARA: I might say that if you had not talked so much you would have heard what I was saying, but, Senator, if you say you did not confirm that that was George Campbell, I am happy to accept your assurances. I repeat: if that was not the case, I certainly withdraw my comment. I regret to say that the reality is it was George Campbell, and that it was the George Campbell. I put that on the record.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Taxation: Savings Rebate Tax Avoidance: Trusts

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp), to questions without notice asked by Senator George Campbell and Senator Jacintha Collins today, relating to trusts and tax minimisation arrangements.

Trusts, and the way they are used to minimise and avoid tax, is no doubt a major area of public tax policy that today deserves consideration in this country. We have only to look at the recent comments of the tax commissioner, Mr Carmody, about the way in which trusts are used to minimise tax and at some of his proposals to crack down on the use of trusts to minimise tax.

The question posed by Senator George Campbell to Senator Kemp went to the issue of the government's recently announced savings rebate of $450. We can all recall, I am sure, that the Prime Minister ruled out receiving the $450 rebate because of his personal financial position. But it is interesting that a significant number of other members of the government—in particular, ministers, who I will refer to shortly—will receive at least part or all of the $450 rebate because of the income they receive from trusts.

The other issue relates to the crackdown on trusts, tax avoidance and tax minimisation. The Treasurer recently announced—and I have a copy of his 10 February 1997 statement—that the government would proceed with trust loss measures but would significantly modify the provisions proposed in order to make the operation of the measures fairer. In this context I would suggest that the use of the description `fairer' means `weaker'. Why is the government backing down on trusts and making the proposed provisions weaker? And why yesterday, as reported in today's media, did the Prime Minister rule it out—with the excuse they always offer up when they are in trouble over tax avoidance or when it comes to the new tax surcharge on superannuation—and say that it may detrimentally affect small business?

According to the search we have carried out, the truth is that almost half of the current ministry, half of the front bench of the government, have trusts. Looking down the lists according to the current records, it is interesting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Who? Tell us.
—I will tell you who has trusts.
—Name them.

—Mr Downer has a trust; Senator Ellison has a trust; Mr Fischer has a trust; Senator Herron has a trust; Senator Hill, who was very reluctant to give any detail with respect to the Prime Minister's background—he did not mention that in his answer—has a trust; Mr Peter McGauran has a trust; Mr McLachlan has a trust; Ms Moylan has a trust; Senator Parer has a trust; Mr Scott has a trust; Mr Sharp has a trust, but I will not include him in the list of ministers for obvious reasons; Senator Vanstone—who is returning next week, and it will be interesting to probe some of her financial and other activities of recent times—has a trust; and Mr Williams has a trust. Of the various parliamentary secretaries, Mr Abbott has a trust; Senator Brownhill has a trust; Senator Ian Macdonald has a trust; Mr Ronaldson has a trust; Senator Tambling has a trust, and Mr Thomson has a trust.
—That's very interesting.

—And I will take that interjection, Senator Hill, because you have a trust. It is very interesting, Senator Hill. You, along with 18 of your 37 current frontbench colleagues—and it was 19 until lunchtime—almost half of the current government, have trusts. There is little wonder that this government is backsliding on its commitment to crack down on tax minimisation and tax evasion through trusts when half of the current frontbench have a trust in some form or other, and half of the current frontbench will benefit from the $450 rebate.(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —To save Senator Sherry and his friends having to go to a list of the backbench, I will state that I am a trustee of a family trust. I make no apologies for that. But I wish to explain to honourable senators on the other side that there are a number of reasons why law‐abiding Australians may wish to use a trust.

SPEECH.PARA: In the case of our family, we entered into a family trust arrangement to hold the family house at a time when my father had very bad heart disease. It was done for the purposes of estate planning. It was done to ensure that in case he died and my mother died soon after there would not be a problem of intestate. It is a perfectly reasonable legal thing to do to enter into a trust arrangement to protect the family assets.

The other side over there would like to have us believe that every Australian who enters into a trust arrangement does it to get some sort of tax advantage. We hear Senator Bob Collins, like a rather overstuffed galah, sitting up on the back bench going, `Tax advantage, tax advantage.' Of course, it is a non‐trading trust; there is no tax advantage. It just goes to show the lack of understanding by people on the other side.

But of course if there is a tax advantage that some Australians wish to take from entering into a trust, one has to ask: what is the motivation? The reason people use trusts for tax planning is excessively high rates of taxation and, most importantly, excessively high rates of marginal taxation which are a direct result of the—
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Order on my left.

—Madam Deputy President, thank you for your assistance, but I do not need any protection from the squawking on the other side of the chamber because they do not have any point to make. The reason we have excessively high rates of marginal taxation is the excessive spending of the previous Labor government which jacked up tax rates and forced ordinary Australian wage‐earners onto the highest possible rates of personal income tax. I know ordinary wage‐earners who have family trusts as well for exactly these reasons.

SPEECH.PARA: But there is one group of people which has no trusts at all, and that is the group of people who are sitting opposite, because the Australian public do not trust the opposition. Some of them do. Yes, Senator Crowley, I understand, has a trust. But collectively, as the opposition, they have no trust. The people of Australia do not trust those opposite because of the outrageous squawking and carrying on that we saw just a couple of minutes ago from Senator Bob Collins and his friends. There is absolutely no rationality in the carry on that we see from the other side.

TALK.START.PARA: —You came in here a schoolboy debating champion; you remain a schoolboy debating champion.
—Order! Senator Bob Collins, please.
—Senator Bob Collins, you could never be a schoolboy debater because they could not find a blazer big enough for you, could they?
—Order! Can I have you addressing the chair, please, Senator O'Chee?

—Thank you, Madam Deputy President. With your assistance we might get this back to a debate. The debate of course is about whether people in this country want to follow the line of the Labor Party. The Labor Party say, `Oh, well, there is all this tax avoidance.' Did the Labor Party attack trusts in the 13 years in which they were in government?
—No!

—No! Senator Chapman is right—no, they did not. Did the Labor Party do anything about some of the circuitous corporate and other arrangements entered into by the former Prime Minister? No, they did not. In fact, were those circuitous corporate arrangements of the former Prime Minister disclosed to the parliament? The answer is no, they were not. So, when we come to the question of public trust, there is no public trust in those opposite, because they have been displayed over 13 years to be utter hypocrites when it comes to standards of parliamentary propriety.
—Laurie Connell and all that stuff.

—We know exactly, Senator Chapman. There is all this sordid history of the Labor Party, and yet these people come in here like St Paul on the road to Damascus. They are suddenly changed and converted; they have suddenly seen the light. Unfortunately, all they see, the only light they see, is the lights of the double‐decker bus driving down the road about to run over them. People in this country are absolutely fed up to their eyeteeth with the carry on we have from the Labor Party who have no ideas and no policy. Their only policy is opposition for opposition's sake. After all, when you look at it there is nothing these people on the other side of the chamber could do but oppose, because they are incapable of coming up with new ideas. That is why the people overwhelmingly sacked that mob at the last election and decided to put the coalition in government instead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conroy, Sen Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to thank Senator O'Chee for standing there and admitting what this debate is really about—that trusts are there to avoid and minimise tax. I would like to thank Senator O'Chee for that.

SPEECH.PARA: A few commentators recently have remarked upon where trusts evolved from. John Kirkwood, a senior tax partner with Ernst and Young said:
Trusts were first developed in the Middle Ages when monks, who were not allowed to own property, appointed trustees.
That is what it is about. That is where trusts come from. It was a tax avoidance measure back then. Geoff Lehmann has pointed out:
Historically, trusts were developed for family purposes, typically deceased estates.
You look pretty dead, but you are still here. You do look a bit dead, some of you people over there with trusts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Conroy, address the chair, please.
—Sorry, Madam Deputy President. Geoff Lehmann went on to say:

BREAK.PARA: In recent years this has changed and, as Carmody pointed out, the vast majority of trust structures are now established for commercial reasons.
John Freebairn, who helped you write Fightback —

TALK.START.PARA: —Never heard of him.

—Never heard of him? You knew him awfully well in 1993 when you were writing Fightback . John Freebairn is quoted as saying that he nominates the strong growth in trusts as a major source of avoidance problems.
—Six years ago you were still in short pants.
—It might have been true when you were avoiding tax back then.

BREAK.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Conroy!
—Michael Carmody said—and this is what has caused the furore—
—Order! Senator Conroy, would you like to withdraw that imputation, please? I realise that the interjections are a bit disorderly and unhelpful—
—I did not know `avoiding tax' was an imputation.
—I think you—
—I do not say `evading tax'; I said `avoiding tax'.
—Would you just like to withdraw? The way it came out it did not sound—
—I withdraw, but if—
—Thank you.
—If Senator—
—One is legal; the other isn't.
—Correct. If Senator Ferguson has taken offence, then I withdraw.

BREAK.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order on my right and left! Senator Conroy, please continue.
—I said I withdraw.
—Why did you?
—I think it was well within my rights not to, but I would like to get on with the debate, Senator Bob Collins.
—Order! Senator Conroy, address the chair.
—Carmody said:

BREAK.PARA: . . . the vast majority of trust structures are now established for commercial reasons. Trust structures offer the capacity to split income. Why some distributions from business are conducted through a trust is so that distributions can be tax free.
This is all that Mr Carmody asked:
Why is it that some distributions from businesses conducted through a trust are tax free when the same distributions made from a business conducted through a company pay tax?
It was a simple question; that is all that he asked. And what happened? The phones started running hot. Ron Walker and Jeff Kennett were on the phone to the Liberal Party.
Senator McGauran interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —John Elliott probably was, too, Senator McGauran, saying, `Just a minute, what is that Carmody on about—taxing trusts?'

BREAK.PARA: It is a fact that in excess of 2,500 entities have been found to be associated with about 100 wealthy individuals—550 discretionary trusts, 230 unit trusts and 20 charitable trusts. During the 1995 financial year, the total amount of tax‐free distributions from reserves to beneficiaries of these trusts was about $50 million. In one case, one wealthy individual received $19 million distributed from his trusts tax free. Another wealthy individual received distributions of $5 million per annum for at least three years, tax free, from his trusts.

That is what this debate is about. That is why the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) yesterday had to hose down the backbench—because all the coalition's donors have been on the phone to them, saying, `You can't be serious. What is Carmody doing? Get a leash on the tax commissioner.' All he did was stand up and say, `Why are trusts treated differently from companies?' That is why the government and the backbenchers are running scared from the tax commissioner, who is just trying to do his job, who is just asking the questions about what is going on with regard to tax in this country. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest to Senator Conroy that before he comes in here and makes such wild accusations he should remember to take his tranquillisers at lunchtime.
—Spot on, his accusations—spot on!
—I say to Senator Collins that he accused me of avoiding tax.
—You? Never!
—Yes, he did. He accused me of avoiding tax.
—Order on my left!
—Let me tell you, Senator Conroy, that in all of my life I have never been part of a family trust; I have never had a family trust. I have never been part of a company and have never had a company.
—What about your front bench?
—Order, Senator Conroy!
—Madam Deputy President, Senator Conroy directed his remarks at me.
—They have been withdrawn, Senator Ferguson.

—I understand that, but he directed the remarks at me and I am just putting something on the record—that I have never had a trust or been a member of a trust. I have never been part of a company or a member of a company.
—But what about your front bench colleagues?
—Order, Senator Sherry!

—The remarks were directed at me. In all of my life I have only ever traded in a registered partnership with my brother, so I have paid my share of tax. Some of my colleagues say that I am crazy for not having a trust—for a particular reason.

BREAK.PARA: Let me tell you, Senator Conroy, that your problems with taxation, as an official of the Transport Workers Union, would have been a lot more of a problem to you than mine ever were to me, as a farmer. Your salary would have been a lot higher, during all the years that you worked for the TWU, than mine ever was when I was farming.

Senator Murray has admitted that he has a trust. He says it is a sensible way to arrange your affairs if you have assets. Senator O'Chee has already spoken about the reason why he had a family trust. All of those people who choose to use trusts to protect their family assets are obviously doing it for the betterment of their own businesses in the future.

What you have said today—particularly you, Senator Conroy, and also what Senator Sherry said previously—reinforces that none of you have any business sense. During the 13 years that you spent running this country, you certainly showed that you had no business sense at all, because you led this country during a period of its highest interest rates, its highest inflation and its highest unemployment. That is your contribution to how to run the business of this country.

During the whole of the 13 years that you were in government, you never did anything about altering the legislation regarding the way trusts are treated. You never made the alterations to trusts that you say this government should be making now. You had legislation in the pipeline; it was always going to be done.

But, of course, your former Prime Minister had a particular interest, didn't he? Your former Prime Minister had no problem with taxation for two years because he never even put in a return. That is how good you were at looking after the taxation interests of this country—the former Prime Minister of this country failed to even put in a return.

TALK.START.PARA: —That means you don't get a refund—you don't get the money back.

—I am not sure how the former Prime Minister had his trusts set up, but he had them set up pretty well, be cause no‐one in this place could ever get the information. The trusts were set up in such a convoluted fashion, as far as the former Prime Minister was concerned, yet you have the hide to come in here and make suggestions about people who, for a long time, have shown proper business sense in protecting assets.
—What about yours?
—I said I did not have one.
—You just boasted about it.
—I did not boast about it. I was answering a direct question.
—Does that mean you are a mug?
—In the eyes of some of my colleagues, probably, yes.
—Order on my left!

—Senator Conroy accused me of avoiding tax. In direct answer to that, I was putting things on the record. The government announced in the 1996 budget that it would proceed with changes to measures relating to trust losses, following further consultation.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Conroy interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order, Senator Conroy!

—Senator Conroy, unlike the previous government, which did not bother to consult with anybody, this government intends to proceed with the measures following further consultation. In relation to the broader issue, the government has already announced that this area requires review and that review is being conducted. When those consultations have taken place, the legislation will be put before this place. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I should commence my contribution by again declaring that I have an interest in trusts. Those of you who are avid readers of estimates—I doubt whether they number more than a few on each hand—would know that I have had an interest in pursuing these trusts and the issue of tax avoidance for some time. I think we should avoid in this debate taking either a winner or a loser approach. There are countless numbers of trusts which are managed properly and which conduct their business appropriately. It is, in my opinion, as foolish to hear Senator O'Chee defend all trusts as it is foolish for anyone else to attack all trusts.
—I agree entirely.

—That is exactly what Senator Bob Collins was saying in interjection earlier. Whether it is a matter of family assets that are dealt with, or assets that are dealt with for death, estate planning or intestacy, or for commercial reasons, is irrelevant. Anyone who puts their assets and interests into a trust is seeking to maximise their own benefit and to minimise tax. The question is whether it is legal, legitimate and in the public interest. For countless numbers of trusts it is, but there are many, maybe countless numbers of trusts where it is not. That was, indeed, the point which I think Senator Bob Collins was making from the back bench, and that, I think, is the underlying thrust of Labor's attack.

SPEECH.PARA: Our approach in this is the fair go approach, which means that Australia deserves, in the public interest, for this area to be reviewed. Our concern is that the government, quite properly, through the Commissioner of Taxation and the Treasurer (Mr Costello), announced a thorough review of tax evasion, tax avoidance and excess tax minimisation. Our concern is that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has stepped into the middle of it and said, `Hang on! Don't worry about it. It's not going to go too far.' That is the inference we have drawn from his remarks.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's not what he said.

—I understand it may not be what he said, Senator Ferguson, but, as you are aware, perception is sometimes as damaging as reality. It is very important that the government come out and say unequivocally that they will not interfere with the tax commissioner's approach, that they will not interfere with the Treasurer's review, that the review will be thorough and that reform will result, because we are talking about $116 billion.

SPEECH.PARA: Tax reform and small business reform generally must focus on those areas which tempt small business and their compliant accountants to behave in a manner which may maximise their private interest but which is not in the public interest. It is to those miscreants that this review must be directed. To hear, quite frankly, a defence of all trusts as being untouchable is unacceptable and to attack all trusts is equally unacceptable. So I support the intention of Labor's motion. I think they are right to raise this in the public consciousness and to pursue it; and, incidentally, I think they are right to support the Treasurer and the tax commissioner, which is what they are doing, in asking for a thorough review which will result in reform so as to trap those who evade, avoid and minimise unduly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Debate this afternoon has ranged very widely. Initially I thought it was related to the announcement by Mr Fahey yesterday of the very positive reforms in relation to the public sector where a great deal more flexibility has been offered under the new arrangements and people do, indeed, have greater choice. Perhaps during this particular debate it has been used as an attack by opposition people on certain members of the coalition who have been identified as having trusts.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Senate that trusts are used for a wide variety of purposes. Obviously, under any arrangement, whether it be a partnership or a company, such vehicles can be used for tax minimisation purposes, for tax avoidance purposes and for tax evasion purposes et cetera. So I think it is unfortunate that we are using the label `trusts' to put people into a little box as essentially being tax avoiders.

In such an environment, I think it is necessary to explain the plight of a lot of small business people, particularly farmers, who, for a number of reasons, either inherit a trust through property that they might have acquired through a trust arrangement, or who operate a trust through it being a convenient method by which to hold assets, to operate a business, to ensure there is a degree of equity between members of families and so on. But I must remind the Senate that, in a wider use of trusts, trusts used as collective investments attract billions of dollars around the world, even in Australia. As such, trusts are a very convenient and efficient method of holding investments.

We have to cover a lot of issues in a very short time so I will dwell on just a few. The name of the Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Carmody, has been mentioned. I think it is unfortunate when this happens in these sorts of debates. We should all know that Mr Carmody, as the tax commissioner, has two roles. One is to ensure the collection of tax according to law and the pursuit of schemes that could lead to evasion, minimisation et cetera. On the other hand, given his capacity, he also has a commitment to advise the government in relation to future policy changes on tax. Unfortunately, during this debate I think those roles have been confused by some commentators.

The other issue which I wish to mention is that there have been some comments about the way other countries deal with trusts. I remind the Senate that some countries certainly do treat tax trusts as companies but, in a sense, where they adopt such a procedure, there are other mechanisms available. For example, to take one, the United States allows US shareholders of some companies to be taxed instead of the company. In other words, there is a flow‐through treatment to ensure greater fairness and greater equality depending on the type of vehicle that you are using in relation to the operation of your business.

The other issue I wish to remind the opposition about is a very significant press release adopted by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) earlier this year when he referred to an exposure draft in relation to trust loss measures. Now, nothing has really changed in relation to that process. The only thing that has changed is that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has indicated that he does not want to impose upon small business such impositions as would make them unviable or lead them into bankruptcy. We have often seen, particularly when the opposition was in government, the so-called unintended conse quences. All the Prime Minister has said is that he does not want any unintended consequences flowing from the measures that have been announced and which will proceed to adversely affect or bankrupt small business. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.
