PETITION.TITLE: Forest Protection
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
For permanent protection of old‐growth forests and all other areas of high conservation value, and for the implementation of tree plantation strategies.

This petition from the undersigned respectfully points out that: there is an increasing and urgent demand from the people, to protect all remaining high conservation value forests which support flora and fauna unique to Australia, thus complying with the United Nations Biodiversity Convention to which Australia is a signatory. We have a responsibility to future and present generations, and the necessary reasons, knowledge and technology to act now on the following achievable solutions.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate legislate to:

PARA.TAB: Immediately stop all logging and woodchipping activities in high conservation value native forests;

ensure intergenerational equity by planning for the rights of future generations, and protecting in perpetuity all biologically diverse old‐growth forests, wilderness, rainforests and critical habitats of endangered species;

facilitate rapid transition of the timber industry from harvesting high conservation value native forests, to establishing mixed‐species farm forestry on existing cleared and degraded lands, using non‐toxic methods to protect ecological sustainability;

maximise use of readily‐available plantation timber for industry needs, using appropriate forestry techniques and progressive minimal‐waste processing methods, such as radial sawing, and wherever possible, reuse and recycle wood and paper products;
support incentives for nationwide composting, soil remineralisation, and planting programs of trees and annual fibre crops, inter‐grown with appropriate fruit and nut trees and medicinal plants;

encourage sensitively‐managed, environmental education tourism in appropriate forest areas, with full respect for natural ecosystems, Aboriginal cultural heritage, sacred sites and other sites of significance; and

progressively utilise technological expertise and resources transferred from the military sector, to help implement these tree planting solutions; and to motivate the international community to follow this example.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Industrial Relations
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The Petition of the undersigned shows strong opposition to the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill 1996, which aims to amend the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act and the Occupational, Health and Safety Act.
1. Outlawing claims arising from "reasonable management action" is a direct assault on the long held principal of no fault workers compensation.
2. The Bill's definition of "significant contribution of work" is the toughest of any compensation legislation in Australia, and will see many workers' otherwise valid claims rejected.
3. Requiring Comcare to investigate the private life of every worker who makes a claim is a gross attack on civil liberties and will discourage people in genuine need from applying.
4. The Bill's provisions will in no way assist in the reduction or prevention of illness or injury in the workplace.
5. The wording of the Bill allows for wide interpretation, which makes its bad law.
6. There are no adequate financial reasons to tighten the Comcare compensation scheme to the detriment of all workers.
Your Petitions therefore request that the Senate oppose the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill 1996 in its entirety.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALKER.NAME: Senator PARER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard
Leave granted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: This bill makes a number of technical amendments to the Workplace Relations Act 1996 (the WR act) and other legislation. The amendments are aimed at clarifying existing provisions and ensuring that they operate in the manner originally intended by the legislation. The bill also corrects some minor drafting anomalies and oversights.
These minor changes will give appropriate effect to the major reforms which have been achieved through the enactment of the Workplace Relations Act.

The act is delivering genuine flexibility and choice at the workplace level. Over 1600 new agreements have been certified, including 47 agreements made directly between employers and employees, and over 500 AWAs have been approved.

The act is better balanced than its predecessors, and reinforces a stronger sense of the rights and responsibilities of participants in the system. Section 127 of the act is providing an effective remedy to prevent and stop illegitimate industrial action, with over 100 applications for section 127 orders being dealt with by the Commission to date.
Substantial progress has been made towards harmonisation of federal and state systems through complementary legislation and a cooperative approach to administrative arrangements and service delivery.

The scope for our reforms to continue to bring about the productivity improvements which are necessary to underpin sustainable economic growth will be further enhanced by the technical amendments proposed in this bill.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Awards and arbitration—Part VI of the WR act

SPEECH.PARA: The bill clarifies the limitation on the Commission's capacity to exercise its arbitral powers during a bargaining period for a proposed certified agreement. The legislation limits the Commission's power to arbitrate during a bargaining period in relation to matters at issue between bargaining parties. The fundamental objective is for the parties to reach agreement without arbitration. The Commission should not arbitrate, for example, in relation to a claim for a new allowance to be paid if that is at issue during bargaining.

However, a possible unintended consequence of limiting access to arbitration is that it may prevent the Commission from varying an award to include a "safety net wage adjustment" to give effect to National Wage Case safety net decisions where bargaining periods have been initiated and wages are an issue between the parties. The bill therefore amends the Workplace Relations Act 1996 to make clear that the limitation on arbitration during a bargaining period does not prevent the Commission from exercising its arbitral powers to deal with an application to vary an award to include a safety net wage adjustment.

The bill also clarifies the status of awards made under section 170MX of the act, making clear that they are enforceable in the same manner as other awards. It also makes clear that where awards are simplified by the Commission during the award simplification process, any provision which has been included in a simplified award because it is incidental and necessary for the effective operation of the award does not cease to have effect at the end of the simplification interim period.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Certified Agreements—Part VIB of the WR act

SPEECH.PARA: The bill addresses two issues which have emerged during the operation of the certified agreement provisions of the act.

Firstly, the bill clarifies the time limit allowed for applications to be lodged for the certification of an agreement. Secondly, it makes clear that the 14 day period provided to employees to consider a certified agreement does not have to start again if an employer takes on new staff during the approval period. Any new starters will, of course, have to have the effect of agreement explained to them and be provided with a copy of the agreement, but the amendment will avoid the delays and unnecessary expense which would result if the approval period were to start again from scratch.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Employment Advocate
and Australian Workplace Agreements—Parts IVA & VID of the WR act

SPEECH.PARA: Also included in the bill are some procedural amendments aimed at facilitating the smooth operation of the Australian Workplace Agreement (AWA) provisions. These changes include an extension to the time limit for lodging AWAs and empowering the Employment Advocate to waive strict compliance with the technical requirements relating to the filing of AWAs.

The time limit for lodging AWAs with the Employment Advocate is to be extended from 14 to 21 days, recognising that a 14 day limit might be difficult to meet, especially where the parties are in rural centres.

Provision will also be made for the Employment Advocate to waive strict compliance with the technical filing requirements for AWAs and ancillary documents. The Advocate will have to be satisfied that the waiver would not disadvantage a party to the AWA. In the absence of such a waiver, the Employment Advocate has had to return a number of AWAs lodged to date because the applications failed in some minor way to meet the filing requirements. The amendment will not affect the substantive requirements to be met by an AWA. There will still need to be strict compliance with the substantive requirements such as the provisions relating to the no‐disadvantage test and genuine consent. The amendment provides only for defects of a technical nature to be waived. This will avoid the waste of time and resources involved in correcting minor defects whilst ensuring that the interests of AWA parties are protected.
The bill also corrects some anomalies in the provision dealing with the right of entry and powers of authorised officers of the Employment Advocate.

At present, authorised officers who are investigating possible freedom of association breaches can only enter premises where they believe relevant documents may be located. By contrast, authorised officers investigating AWA breaches and Department of Industrial Relations inspectors investigating breaches of awards or certified agreements may enter premises where relevant work is being performed and interview employees, without being limited to premises where documents may be held.

The bill corrects this anomaly by providing for authorised officers to enter places of business for the purpose of interviewing persons in connection with possible breaches of the freedom of association provisions of the act. As is the case with the existing rights of entry, the new provision does not allow access to premises used for residential purposes, and the right to interview does not empower an authorised officer to compel a person to answer questions.

PARA.EMPHASIS: No‐Disadvantage Test—Part VIE of the WR act

SPEECH.PARA: The bill also amends the process by which designated awards can be determined by the Commission and the Employment Advocate for the purpose of applying the no‐disadvantage test to agreements.

The act presently provides that where there is no award covering the work of employees whose is to be covered by a certified agreement or AWA, the Commission or the Advocate, as the case requires, is to `designate' an appropriate federal award for the purpose of applying the no‐disadvantage test to the agreement. The bill will allow the Commission or the Advocate to designate a state award as the benchmark for the no‐disadvantage test where there is no federal award covering work of the same kind as that performed by the employees whose work is to be subject to an agreement.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Termination of Employment—Part VIA of the WR act

SPEECH.PARA: The bill clarifies the application of state laws in relation to termination of employment of an employee covered by a federal award or agreement. It also ensures that there is consistency in the time limits for making applications in respect of termination of employment, and makes it clear that each of the various types of application relating to termination of employment may be discontinued.

Provision is also made for the maximum amount of compensation which may be awarded in respect of an unfair dismissal or unlawful termination of employment to be calculated by reference to the amount of remuneration to which the applicant was entitled for the previous 6 months. At present the act provides for the compensation limit to be calculated by reference to the amount received by the employee during the preceding 6 months with the employer. The proposed amendment will benefit employees by ensuring that the compensation limit is calculated by reference to the amount which an employee was entitled to receive, if that amount would be higher than the amount actually received.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Freedom of Association—Part XA of the WR act

SPEECH.PARA: The bill ensures that an agreement may not be certified when it includes a provision inconsistent with the freedom of association provisions of the WR act. This provision is required primarily because some unions are seeking to include preference clauses in agreements. The freedom of association provisions of the act prohibit discrimination based on membership or non‐membership of a union, and render preference clauses void and of no effect. However, some unions still cling to the past and want such clauses included in certified agreements. Leaving aside the futility of such an exercise, there is a real risk that some employers and employees may mistakenly take these void clauses at face value, disadvantaging employees and breaching the act in the process. It is therefore essential that agreements containing preference clauses are not certified, and for the same reasons, provisions in existing awards and agreements which breach the freedom of association provisions should be removed. Provision is therefore also made for awards and agreements to be varied, on application, to remove void preference clauses.
Registered Organisations —Part IX of the WR act
The bill also amends the provisions of the WR act dealing with disamalgamation of organisations.

As presently drafted, the definitions provision relating to withdrawal from an amalgamated organisation refers to only one of the two methods by which organisations could amalgamate under the act, and as a consequence, it has unintentionally excluded some organisations and branches from access to disamalgamation. The bill corrects this defect to ensure that the disamalgamation scheme will be able to operate as it was intended.
The bill also makes provision to allow an application for a disamalgamation ballot made before the amendments take effect to proceed without the need to reapply to the Federal Court.
Matters referred by Victoria —Part XV of the WR act
The bill clarifies the provision dealing with access to AWAs for Victorian employees, and clarifies the successor provisions for certified agreements and AWAs binding on Victorian employers.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Other legislation

SPEECH.PARA: Minor technical amendments to the Navigation Act 1912, Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988, Seafarers Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1992, Superannuation Act 1976 and Superannuation Act 1990 are also proposed. These amendments arise as a consequence of the removal of agreements from the definition of `award' in the Workplace Relations Act.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Consultation

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed amendments have been discussed with the ACTU and ACCI through the National Labour Consultative Council's Committee on Industrial Legislation, and the bill includes amendments suggested by the ACTU and ACCI. The ACCI has indicated its support for the amendments and for the most part, the amendments are not opposed by the ACTU.

Madam President, this bill is technical in nature. Its purpose is to make some minor clarifications and corrections to make sure that the act operates as intended. The changes will assist employers, employees and their organisations by making some minor procedural improvements and providing greater certainty about the operation of the act.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said in my speech on the second reading, we are concerned that the bill excludes parliamentary review and disallowance in certain areas. A short history is that the 1994 bill provided for parliamentary review and disallowance and excluded judicial review. The 1996 bill, this bill, removes the ability of parliamentary review decisions and makes those decisions subject to judicial review under the ADJR. We are concerned that parliament is being excluded in this way.

The report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on the 1994 bill recommended that parliamentary review should be maintained. It is worth noting that Senator O'Chee, in his capacity as chair of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, also held that view.

What we are concerned about is that parliament should have a continuing role in terms of defining the character of the instruments we are talking about here. The role of parliament is important there. Secondly, we are concerned that if the only avenue of review of a decision by the Attorney were to be a court or an ADJR process then that would be costly and inaccessible to most ordinary Australians. As a consequence, we need to have another look at parliamentary review as an opposition. We think parliamentary review provides another avenue for consideration of such decisions in a way which individual Australians or groups of Australians do not have to be forced to fork out high court fees and high legal fees.

The Attorney has argued that the parliamentary review may be inappropriate as he claims the issue is ultimately one for judicial determination. As I said earlier, most of the issues debated in this parliament, if not all of them, can ultimately be ones for judicial determination. We do not think the Attorney's argument is a strong one in respect of that. We say that there should be some capacity for judicial review, as is provided by the act. But our amendment goes to ensuring that there is also capacity for parliamentary review in the houses of parliament of decisions made by the Attorney.

(ii) notice of the content of the instrument would enable individuals to gain an advantage over other persons without that notice; or
(iii) the instrument is a proclamation that provides solely for the commencement of that enabling legislation or of any provision of that enabling legislation; and

(b) if the rule‐maker is satisfied of the matter referred to in subparagraph (a)(i) or (ii)—the regulatory review body has certified in writing that it is also satis fied of that matter and set out the reasons for being so satisfied; or
(c) the Attorney‐General has certified in writing that public interest requires that the instrument be excluded from the operation of sections 20 to 25.

PARA.TAB: (2) Instruments made in reliance on subparagraph (a)(i) cease to have effect 12 months after they are made.
(3) An instrument the same in substance as an instrument which has ceased to have effect under subsection (2) may not be made in reliance on subparagraph (a)(i).

SPEECH.PARA: What we are seeking to do here is pick up some exemptions from consultations which we think should be made and some tightening of exemptions as well. There are a number of changes between the 1994 bill and the 1996 bill on the range of matters for which exemptions from consultations may be granted. For instance, this bill does not provide for exemptions: where a legislative instrument, for instance is urgently required; where significant or comparable public consultation on the instrument has already occurred; where notice of such an instrument would give an unfair advantage to particular individuals; or where the Attorney certifies that the public consultation would not be in the public interest.

Instead of these provisions, we have specific provisions providing exemption where: the instrument is required in the interests of national security—in which case no certification by the Attorney is required—the instrument is an airworthiness directive, the instrument is a commencement proclamation, the decision maker proposes to make a 12‐month temporary legislative instrument or the regulatory review body certifies that the LIP is adequate and otherwise waives part 3 consultation requirements.

We believe that the bill, in a sense, is too restrictive in some cases and can be open to abuse in some others. What we are moving by way of these amendments are proposals which, firstly, allow for an exemption where the instrument is urgently required or where notice would give an unfair advantage to individuals. However, we think that should be balanced out by only allowing a 12-month operation in these circumstances and also ensuring that the instrument be certified by the regulatory review body as being necessary. Secondly, exemptions for prior, significant or comparable public consultation should be retained, but there should be a requirement that the regulatory review body certify that such consultation has taken place.

Thirdly, we think the public interest test should be retained, thus eliminating the need for specific national security and airworthiness exemptions. In our amendments, we have included both these matters in a list of matters included within, but not limiting, the public interest test. So we think there should be the capacity for a somewhat broader public interest test. We are concerned that, given the broad effect of this bill on legislative instruments, we do not want to prejudice matters for which the public interest would sometimes militate against consultation pursuant to the bill. As opposed to the government's proposal, in all these cases we would require the Attorney-General to certify to that fact. As I said, in respect of some cases covered by this test the government has specifically mentioned in this bill, the Attorney-General is not always required to so certify. We think he or she should be so required.

We support the exemption in respect of commencement proclamations, and we also think the exemption for 12-month temporary legislative instruments should otherwise be removed. There should not be a need, beyond those I have outlined already, for temporary legislative instruments to be created. A provision of this nature, we think, could lead to widespread abuse.

Finally, the power of the regulatory review body to limit the consultation required should be retained, we think, as outlined in the bill. They are the aspects of our amendments and I commend them to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: (12) Clause 61, page 63 (after line 11), insert:

(1A) Any reference in this Act to disallowance of a legislative instrument or a provision of a legislative instrument is deemed to include a reference to disallowance of part of a legislative instrument.

(1B) If, within 15 sitting days of a legislative instrument being laid before each House, each House by resolution amends the legislative instrument or part of the legislative instrument in identical terms, the legislative instrument as amended shall take effect according to those terms from the day of the later resolution.

I said in my second reading contribution that the ability to amend regulations by the parliament is or would be an important time saving and accountability mechanism. Not infrequently, we have found that governments of all political persuasions will include substantial improvements and much needed reforms amongst much needed regulations, but which will include less desirable public policy measures or politically contentious ones. This amendment addresses that issue by allowing this chamber to disallow part of an instrument. It seems strange to us that it is well within our daily lexicon to amend every bill that comes before us, but to be unable to do so with legislative instruments.

It would also allow the Senate to get around what I have been advised is the ambiguous legal position under section 48B of the Acts Interpretation Act. That provision of the Acts Interpretation Act makes unlawful any regulations which are made while a disallowance motion is on foot and which are the same in substance as those regulations subject to the disallowance motion. The effect of such regulations, when made in contravention of that section, is to render the new regulations as having no effect.

We have, on occasions in the past, seen some shady dealings the effect of which has been to circumvent debate in this chamber. In our view, a correct reading of section 48B may have the effect of invalidating those regulations which arise as a result of `done deals'. The courts will indeed ultimately adjudicate on this issue if asked to. However, we think that our amendment today will help to overcome that and, of course, we believe the amendment enhances accountability and the role of parliament for all the parties in this chamber.

There is an identical amendment in the name of Senator Margetts. The legislation not only limits but it substantially truncates the power of the Commonwealth parliament to review executive government actions when it comes to national schemes. Clause 61(7) says:
This section does not apply in relation to a legislative instrument, or a provision of a legislative instrument, made on or after the commencing day, if the enabling legislation for the instrument:
(a) facilitates the establishment or operation of an intergovernmental body or scheme involving the Commonwealth and one or more States; and

PARA.TAB: (i) has the effect that legislative instruments of that kind could not be disallowed before the commencing day; or
(ii) has the effect that legislative instruments of that kind cannot be disallowed.

SPEECH.PARA: This particular provision was of grave concern to the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances and really I guess I am standing here with the knowledge that that body, which we entrust to examine these matters, is most concerned about this particular provision. In fact, what happens is that the bill actually excludes instruments which provide for national schemes of legislation such as Corporations Law, the competition code, road transport reform and occupational health and safety legislation, and all of those under this bill are to be excluded from parliamentary scrutiny in the form of Commonwealth parliamentary disallowance, not necessarily state or territory—I will come to that in a minute. In fact, these national schemes are likely to become more important and more frequent.

I believe it is inappropriate that parliament should not be able to scrutinise what really is legislation. Parliament should have the same option of disallowance of instruments as it has over other legislative instruments, many of which, of course, are of far less consequence than national schemes. Really, it is incongruous that the national parliament should not have control over national schemes, or any control over national schemes, if you like, in respect of that. The amendments which I am moving provide for national legislative scheme instruments to be disallowed by either house of parliament.

I want to indicate to the committee that we are dealing with national scheme regulations made by the national executive government. I would like to point out to the committee that, without the amendments that I am moving, there would be no capacity for the Commonwealth parliament to disallow a regulation, but that that power would still lie with the state and territory legislatures. Now isn't that ironic? I ask the committee whether we should be denying ourselves that right, in fact escaping our responsibilities in the mat ter, and yet the right and the power will still lie with the state and territory legislatures.

The standards of scrutiny in the state legislatures is not as well developed as in the Senate due to their resources. I wonder whether the government has really thought this through. I know the government will say that many of these national schemes are dealing with the subject matters which are constitutionally more relevant to the powers of the state. But they are national schemes and, in so far as we have constitutional capacity to do what we have always done, we ought to still do it. I commend this amendment to the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot express the case any better than did Senator Harradine. I thank him for his words. The Australian Democrats will support that amendment.

We really do and really must rely on the cooperation of the states in this regard. That is exactly what we are looking at with this working party—working at a consensus among the states, territories and the Commonwealth government as to how we deal with the situation of an intergovernmental agreement or national scheme.

I understand that the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) met with Senator O'Chee on 26 August this year to discuss this point. He is closely monitoring the success of this working party and will be very interested in the recommendations when it delivers its report. But, for the time being, the government is unable to agree to this amendment for the reasons that I have mentioned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Murray for understanding the difficulty of my position. Without expressing a view on the particular amendment, it may help the committee if I briefly outline the history of Senate scrutiny of national scheme delegated legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1995, the previous government introduced regulations for national scheme legislation in relation to road transport which were subject to disallowance in this place. The committee took a strong view that the national scheme regulations were defective because they contained vicarious liability provisions. In particular, the vicarious liability provisions affected the driver of a combination vehicle—such as a road train—whether or not he knew of a defect of any portion of the combination.

The committee took the view that that was unsatisfactory. After negotiation with the relevant minister in the previous government, the previous government agreed that the regulations would be withdrawn and that no new regulations would be made unless they were satisfactory to the committees in all of the jurisdictions. It is a matter of record that we have not had national regulations in relation to road transport yet because of that agreement.

Senator Murray asks: where am I as a representative of this parliament in terms of negotiation with the relevant state committees? The situation is that it was the subject of a discussion in October last year in Perth at a meeting of the representatives of scrutiny of legislation committees throughout Australia. The meeting comprised representatives of both the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances and the Scrutiny of Bills Committee—the very fine committee of which you are a member, Senator Murray. So we, as a jurisdiction, had two representatives at that, and there were representatives from each of the state jurisdictions.

At that time it was agreed that there should be a uniform approach to scrutiny of national scheme delegated legislation. For the benefit of honourable senators, those proposals were contained in the discussion paper released in October 1996. It talked about the criteria which should apply to the scrutiny of national scheme delegated legislation. It was very much a lowest common denominator mechanism. We found something that all the jurisdictions agreed upon—that is what I mean by `lowest common denominator'. It is more jus gentium rather than the poorest possible law.

Since then I have had discussions with the committees. Many of the committees have expressed a desire that it should be dealt with in the federal parliament rather than being subject to disallowance in each of the state jurisdictions. However, there are caveats to that because a number of jurisdictions have not finally signed off on it because they are still considering it. In the case of South Australia and in the case of the Northern Territory, it has not been possible to get a position from the committee because of either a recent election or the forthcoming election in South Australia. But work is proceeding on it apace.

The concern that both Senator Cooney and I had in Perth was that, unless there was a clear mechanism for the disallowance of national scheme regulations in some form or another, the grave danger was that some of the state scrutiny committees might be tempted to indulge in the drafting process and be participants in the drafting process. Both Senator Cooney, who is a very erudite man on these matters, and I, in my own humble way, decided that that would not be satisfactory because we believed that scrutiny not only should occur but should be seen to occur, so that the public has confidence that these matters are being overseen by their representatives and their rights are being protected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Harradine for moving Senator Colston's amendment No. 2, which is also the same as the Greens (WA) amendment No. 4, in my absence. As I indicated in my speech during the second reading debate—and I am sure this has been mentioned—the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances commented on this aspect in its report of 21 November 1996 and expressed concern about parliament's inability to have any control over legislative instruments in such a fundamentally important area as national schemes of legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The committee stated that it believed parliament should have the same options over such instruments as it has over legislation, much of which is of less consequence than national schemes. There are many examples in recent times of new legislation which establishes an intergovernmental body or a scheme which involves the Commonwealth and one of the states. If the legislation establishing those bodies or schemes incorporates a substantial ability to implement the detail of the administrative arrangements through regulation, the parliament must have the ability to examine and, if necessary, disallow those regulations.
I do not think that is too hard. I do not think that is unreasonable. I do hope the Senate supports this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Margetts indicated that she was not here before because of the meeting of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. I am glad she has come out of that meeting. Our problem in this place is that we do not have the gift of bi‐location. In my case at least, colleagues are very happy that I do not have the gift of bi‐location. It is a problem trying to meet one's commitments to committee work and to the work of this chamber, particularly when the committee work is a joint committee that can meet whilst the Senate is meeting.

SPEECH.PARA: I am glad Senator Margetts has referred to what the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances said. That report was given to this chamber by Senator O'Chee, the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. I was very grateful to have Senator O'Chee inform the committee of the discussions that had taken place with other scrutiny bodies from other parliaments. I was also grateful for the indications he gave of the transport regulations and the vicarious liabilities that were associated with those regulations, which alerted the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances to the possibilities of individual rights being trampled upon. As I indicated this morning, it is a function of this parliament to uphold the rights of individual citizens.

I noted what the Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General (Senator Ellison) has said on this matter. The minister indicated that there needs to be in many cases the ceding of the power of the states to the Commonwealth in respect of the subject matter of a number of these national schemes. That is to say that, in a number of the national schemes, the primary responsibility lies with the states and, as the minister said, it is necessary for that power to be ceded to the Commonwealth.

The minister said it was necessary to cede power to the Commonwealth, but he really meant that it was necessary to cede power to the Commonwealth government because, unless we have some say over the regulations, it is in effect ceding the power to the Commonwealth government without any opportunity for this national parliament to protect the rights of individuals and to exercise its function of audit and control over executive government—which this parliament has a long history of doing. I am surprised that Senator Bolkus and the opposition would support this legislation which denies us that right.

As I indicated previously, that power is still with the state and territory legislatures. What you are doing under this legislation is to remove that power from us, the Commonwealth parliament, but it is still with the state and territory legislatures. What is the sense in that? Please, somebody tell me. Can Senator Bolkus tell me, on behalf of the opposition, what is the sense of withdrawing that power and right and responsibility from the Commonwealth parliament and still allowing the power to remain in the state and territory parliaments? It is in respect of national schemes we are talking about. If they are national schemes, let us treat them as national schemes, but we should have some responsibilities in respect of those particular schemes.

I am extremely disappointed about this because I have seen some of these state and Commonwealth committees working. Might I say, since the Attorney‐General's Department is here, that I also have seen how SCAGS works. Frankly, in many of those areas I am not impressed, particularly in the area of, say, censorship officers. It is often the Commonwealth bureaucrats who appear to give the advice and there is no argument about it. In fact, so much so that one wonders whether what we are doing here is to allow the sort of sloppy advice that came from the Attorney‐General's Department—whether it came from the OFLC originally, I do not know.

BREAK.PARA: I will just give you one example and that was the government decision to establish an NVE category in film and video classifications. The Attorney‐General of this Commonwealth issued a press statement on 8 April 1997 which was demonstrably false. How can the Attorney‐General of this country issue such a statement that was demonstrably false? I have said that before and nobody has denied that it was demonstrably false, and seriously so. It misled the people of Australia and would have misled this parliament had it not been exposed.

I believe that it was of such a nature that the Attorney‐General should have considered resigning. I believe it is far worse to do something like that than to inadvertently, possibly, make claims in respect of travelling allowance. I think the Attorney‐General of this nation is more culpable because he has not retracted, or even had the decency to apologise to the parliament or to the people for, that demonstrably false statement he made. I am quite happy to describe in detail how it is false; I would be happy for somebody to get up and challenge me on that, because I would give you it chapter and verse.

But I say this to the minister and to the government: I am not prepared, to be quite frank, to take anything coming from the Attorney‐General's office without thoroughly inspecting it and assessing whether it is truthful or not, in respect of major issues. It is a matter of such seriousness. You can take it or leave it.

To get back to the amendment, here we have a proposition that is coming from the government which will deny us, the Commonwealth parliament, a power which is retained by the state and territory legislatures. What is the sense in that? What really will occur is that the unelected public servants and bureaucrats, or particular ministers, will have the final say, without any effective examination by elected members of parliament in respect of legislative instruments which have hitherto been the subject of disallowance or putative disallowance in this chamber.

I am very surprised, to be quite frank, that Senator Bolkus has allowed the government to get away with this, but I should not be surprised because Senator Bolkus, I presume, and the opposition hope to be in government too. With these national schemes growing and becoming more numerous, that will, in effect, deny this parliament its right to exercise its audit and control functions over the executive government and its duty to protect the rights of individuals.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, are the Native Title Act and the Native Title Amendment Bill subject to this clause?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I might have misunderstood Senator Margetts on this point. The native title bill and the act could not be subject to this. That is primary legislation. This only deals with regulations. They are acts of parliament, or one would be an act of parliament if it was passed. Just like any other act of parliament or any other bill that became an act of parliament, they would not be subject to this because this only applies to legal instruments by regulations. That is subordinate legislation. The Native Title Act is not subordinate legislation; it is primary legislation.

—I will clarify this further. We know that there are a number of areas in the Native Title Act and, in particular, the Native Title Amendment Bill where there are proposals for regulations to be the instrument by which, if you like, this scheme will take place. I am assuming that it is working as a national scheme for the management of native title. I am not talking just about the words in the act. I am wondering whether regulations in the Native Title Act and the Native Title Amendment Bill would come under this clause.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —The regulations would certainly come within the ambit of this bill—not the Native Title Act but regulations made pursuant to that or any regulations made pursuant to the amendment bill should the bill become law. You understand that it would not apply to the act but it would apply to the regulations and they could be disallowable. That is the effect this bill would have in relation to those regulations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to say that this is a very worrying admission. I hope Senator Bolkus is listening to both the question and the answer because there may be a whole raft of what we all consider to be very important areas which will, in large part, be implemented by regulation. The impact of this has been recognised already by the many groups who are forming the coalitions to look at the issues and the outcomes involved not only in respect of the legislation but also the raft of regulations which may, for instance, bring forward mass extinguishment, even if the bill and the act itself do not mention that in some areas.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a very worrying area, an area that could have massive consequences in terms of accountability and the areas of policy which both major parties are publicly saying are important. I am not sure if Senator Bolkus is taking in what I am saying, but I do hope that he reconsiders and gets advice on this. The minister has clearly said that this would fit into this clause. Perhaps we could get a response from Senator Bolkus as to whether he believes that this is going to be acceptable—that, under such conditions, those kinds of regulations may not be disallowable.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek further clarification from the minister. Minister, the question has been raised about the Native Title Act and the regulations under it. You said it was going to be subject to this legislation. What precisely does that mean? Does it mean that it would be exempt as a national operating scheme under the provisions we are discussing at the moment? If not, why not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —The situation with the regulations made pursuant to native title legislation is no different to regulations made pursuant to other Commonwealth legislation. Those regulations, if this bill is passed, would be subject to this bill just as any other regulation—that is, there would be the provision for a disallowance. There is nothing untoward in that. What I am saying is that the regulations would be subject to this legislation, if passed.

SPEECH.PARA: Where there is some misunderstanding perhaps is that Senator Margetts might be looking at this with the native title regulations operating as a national scheme. That relates to the setting up of tribunals. But, of course, I do not think that is quite how the native title situation will work. What you have under that is either the National Native Title Tribunal or the ability for the states to set up their own native title tribunals, so that both could operate in tandem with each other. But it does not require a national scheme, as I understand it, or an intergovernmental agreement. It is much like having uniform consumer laws or uniform food regulation.

With the native title legislation, that is a situation where the amending bill would provide for states to take it or leave it—that is, if they want to have their own native title tribunal they can; if they do not they go with the Commonwealth. Any regulations made by the Commonwealth are subject to this legislation. That includes native title regulations, but it does not include regulations made by the states. They are subject to their own law. I hope that has clarified it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure it has. In your initial comment, Minister, you did refer to national schemes—it might have been Senator Harradine—or schemes with arrangements made with any state. I am trying to find the relevant provisions in the legislation to try to focus on this. My concern is that if it is within the definition of national scheme to include a loose arrangement with one or more of the states, then we may not be totally clear on arrangements like the national native title scheme being exempt from this. That is why I have raised my concerns at this stage. Could you help us with that?

SPEECH.PARA: Senator ELLISON (Western Australia—Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General) (5.39 p.m.)—I think subsection 61(7) is the appropriate part, which says:
This section does not apply in relation to a legislative instrument, or a provision of a legislative instrument, made on or after the commencing day, if the enabling legislation for the instrument:
(a) facilitates the establishment or operation of an intergovernmental body or scheme involving the Commonwealth or one or more States;
That is quite straightforward. It says that those are exempted where you have an intergovernmental agreement. It goes on:
(b) allows legislative instruments of that kind to be made by the body or for the purposes of the body or scheme; and
(c) either:

PARA.TAB: (i) had the effect that legislative instruments of that kind could not be disallowed before the commencing day; or

SPEECH.PARA: So that would mean that you could not make disallowable something which was not disallowable prior to a commencing day. It goes on:

PARA.TAB: (ii) has the effect that legislative instruments of that kind cannot be disallowed.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill excludes national schemes. The amendment wants to include national schemes. That is what I understand. The query is: if the proposed amendments to native title are to be regarded as a scheme, is it included under the bill? Of course subsection 61(7) would seem to exclude schemes.

The amendment would purport to include schemes and thereby the native title situation, if the native title situation were to be regarded as a national scheme. I am not so sure that is precisely how the amending bill operates. On that score I can take further advice. I think your primary concern is: is the proposed amendment to the Native Title Act, which is coming before the Senate, a national scheme between the Commonwealth and states?

TALK.START.PARA: —Or could it be construed by law to be so.

—Or could it be construed by law to be so. I will take advice on that. I am unable to obtain advice at hand as to whether that would constitute a national scheme. But I am advised that the pertinent subparagraph is 61(7)(c), which deals with legislative instruments that are currently disallowable. Of course any of the regulations made under the Native Title Act at present are disallowable, so they would continue to be disallowable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, I take that point. I suspect we are not going to be able to clarify this particular section this evening because all of us may need to have a closer look at it. The problem with the native title regime is that there is already in place part of the regime. We are about to consider in this place a different version of it in the next few weeks or months. Though, for instance, one could argue that there is something in place now, something new might be in place very soon.

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned that subparagraph 61(7)(a) is so broad and subparagraph 61(7)(c) is so unclear. The concerns that Senator Margetts raises really need full and detailed consideration. What I suggest we do in respect of this particular part is, realising that we will still be going through this bill later this evening, move on and see if we can get some further legal advice, not from the Chief Parliamentary Counsel but from the Solicitor-General.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would support the proposal put by Senator Bolkus at this stage. I would like to throw into the ring reference to schedule 1, clauses 43 and 43A of the Native Title Amendment Bill , and ask that that in particular be looked at because that would seem to be a good example. I am not saying it stands or falls on that, but it might be useful to look at clauses 43 and 43A to see whether or not that might be exactly what we are talking about or an example of exactly what we are talking about.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I can undertake to get that advice. Perhaps we could defer consideration of this amendment and move onto others.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say this: I want to know why the Labor Party has changed its mind about national schemes. The fact is that, under the previous administration, as Senator O'Chee had mentioned, the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances had expressed a view about the transport regulations. You heard him talking about the transport regulations and the question of vicarious liability arose, and that was the subject of consideration by the Senate regulations and ordinances committee.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that the government of the day, which was a Labor government, had given certain undertakings not to make new regulations unless they were all signed off by the members of the regulations and ordinances committee. In other words, the then government was saying that it agreed to preserve the Commonwealth's scrutiny of subordinate legislation, of legislative instruments, relating to a national scheme. We heard it today. In effect, by its actions, the then government agreed to preserve the Commonwealth's scrutiny.

I really do not know why Senator Bolkus has walked away from that position. But, as Senator Margetts has raised another matter, which is quite an important matter, if, necessary, I would be happy to move that the committee report progress.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I will just very briefly respond to Senator Harradine. Senator, if you look at the 1994 version of this legislation, you will find in clause 48(5) essentially what is now reflected in clause 61(7).
—The 1994 bill?
—Our 1994 bill, yes. That was before the election; that is right.
—I'm talking before then.

—The 1994 bill is sort of far enough back for me but, if you want to, we can go back to before then. The point that can be made is that in 1994 we adopted a position which is consistent with what is in clause 61(7) now.
—But you are older and wiser now.

—I might be a lot older, Senator Margetts, but I am not so sure about the wiser aspect. I am still in this place, for instance. But I have said today that, given the particular and specific problem raised by Senator Margetts, we may have to look at the provision that we adopted in 1994, which we have said we support now. It is something out of the blue. I think it is worthy of very careful consideration, Senator Harradine.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment postponed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —We do have an amendment—as you say, amendment No. 15—which goes to the question of the scrutiny of legislation committees throughout Australia, but the government has suggested to us an alternative proposal. I do not know if it has been circulated or not but, in case it has not, I will read it to the Senate. The suggestion that has been put to me is that, instead of moving my amendment No. 15, we move the following amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 61, page 66 (after line 7), insert:

(7A) The Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances may, from time to time, report to the Attorney General on progress made by the Working Party of Representatives of Scrutiny of Legislation Committees throughout Australia in relation to the development, and governmental acceptance, of a national scheme for the Parliamentary scrutiny of legislative instruments, or provisions of legislative instruments, to which section 61 does not apply because of the operation of subsection (7).

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bolkus, do you wish to canvass whether or not there is support and then seek leave to move this amendment instead of yours?

—What I would like to do is indicate at this stage that I am prepared to move this amendment instead of the one that I have already indicated, but I want to change one word. Instead of the words `may, from time to time, report', I would replace the word `may' with the word `shall'. I think there needs to be greater compulsion on a consultative process here.

SPEECH.PARA: I do suggest that, having considered this a bit further, this particular amendment should probably await further deliberation of the previous item that we discussed. If the government's exemption for national schemes somehow goes down, then we may need to reconsider this particular proposal. So, if it is to the satisfaction of everyone, maybe it is best to defer this particular amendment for further consideration after the preceding amendment comes back to us.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before we do, I am advised that new drafting instructions mean that the word `shall' must be replaced by the word `must'. I was not aware that there was a debate about drafting instructions, Senator, but I am told that the word should be `must'.

—I think the point made is a valid one. I suppose this is somewhat, in a way, pre-empting what might occur with the previous amendment. I do believe that the amendment that we were just discussing is somewhat weak. In any event, I would have thought that there are constant discussions going on between the Chair of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances and the Attorney-General. By and large, I suppose over the years these have been quite amicable and constructive. I do not know why we have to put it in the legislation. Still, I am happy to have the matter deferred to a later time.

—There seems to be an agreement from the senators that we now pass over the alternative amendment which was proposed by Senator Bolkus but not yet moved. We can discuss that at a later date. We will now go to amendment No. 3, listed in Senator Colston's name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —This amendment goes to proposed section 61 on page 66 of the legislation. It seeks to delete proclamations. The amendment states:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Clause 61, page 66 (lines 10 and 11), omit paragraph (a).
I wanted to ask the minister to explain why the government has chosen to include paragraph (a) in this particular section. The bill states:
(8) This section does not apply in relation to the following instruments or provisions of the following instruments:
(a) a Proclamation that provides solely for the commencement of an Act or of a provision of an Act;

I wondered why the government has chosen to put that in this bill. I know it has been generally the understanding that the government, in effect, decides when proclamations are to commence for any act. Very often, of course, in the legislation there is provision for a particular time or date for the proclamation of the legislation. No doubt the minister will be able to explain to the committee why the government has included that in this particular provision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —This relates to a situation where the date of proclamation is not contained in the act and it might be done by subordinate legislation. The exemption was to ensure that one house did not have the power to disallow the proclamation of a piece of legislation which had been passed by both houses so that one house could effectively hold up proclamation of a piece of legislation. That is why it was exempted.

SPEECH.PARA: At the present time, there are two ways you can do proclamations. You can put the time in the act and say that it will be proclaimed on that day, or it can be proclaimed by regulation, which will be gazetted. It is the latter that we are looking at. If you do leave it that way and you give the flexibility to the government of the day to proclaim where necessary—there is nothing untoward about that—it simply means that one house cannot disallow that date of proclamation, which would then effectively hold up something passed by both houses.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I will go to the next point; that is, the clause concerning the Flags Act proclamation. Before I move any of the subsequent amendments that have been circulated, proposed section 61 states:

SPEECH.PARA: (8) This section does not apply in relation to the following instruments or provisions of the following instruments:
(c) a Proclamation under section 5 of the Flags Act 1953;

Why shouldn't parliaments have the rights there? I invite other members of the committee, if they have views about this matter, to express them. I am sure the committee would be obliged to hear from the minister why the government has included in the exemptions from parliamentary scrutiny the proclamations made under section 5 of the Flags Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are jumping ahead. This is the next amendment, I take it?
—It has not been moved yet. I am sorry, Minister. I have not actually moved anything as yet.
—Senator Harradine, can you help the committee by telling us whether you are actually trawling across (3), (4) and (6) or just (3)?
—No, I am asking questions of the minister in relation to section 61 and those that relate to (3), (4) and (6) on the amendment sheet. May I ask the minister for his response to that.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney-General)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are talking about Senator Harradine's amendments (3), (4) and (6) on behalf of Senator Colston. In relation to flags, I am advised that there are currently only four proclamations under section 5 which deals with flags for the Defence services and others deal with flags of indigenous communities. The government would view this as a discriminatory action if we applied these to disallowance and not others. That is why that part of it is being exempted.
—Can the minister enlighten me as to how many proclamations have been made under section 5 of the Flags Act 1953?
—Four.

—I now go to the next matter which is on page 71. I think there has been some misnumbering here, so I will ask the minister if the government could proceed with its amendment, which is the next one on the list.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (5) Clause 61, page 66 (after line 14), after paragraph (8)(c), insert:

(ca) a legislative instrument (other than a regulation) under Part 1, 2 or 9) of the Migration Act 1958, or a legislative instrument under Part 1, 2 or 5, or Schedule 2 or 6, of the regulations made under that Act;

This amendment deals with clause 61, which is entitled `Certain Migration Instruments Not Subject to Disallowance'. This amendment inserts a new paragraph 61 (8)(ca) to provide a further exemption from the disallowance provisions of the bill. The amendment exempts from disallowance legislative instruments other than regulations made by the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs under parts 1, 2 or 9 of the Migration Act 1958 or under parts 1, 2 or 5, or schedules 2 or 6, of the regulations made under the Migration Act 1958. Such instruments are currently not subject to disallowance.

The amendment meets the government's policy objective of maintaining the status quo of allowing no disallowance of migration control instruments that might otherwise be disallowable as a consequence of the enactment of the bill, but does not extend from disallowance the range of instruments to which exemption from disallowance applies.

I could provide some background to that. Following the disallowance by the Senate in November last year of some parts of key reforms to control the migration program, the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs sought exemption from the bill for instruments made under the Migration Act.

A detailed opinion by the Chief General Counsel shows that there are very few instruments that can be made under the Migration Act which would be legislative in character. Nearly all such instruments were properly characterised as administrative in character and thus not subject to the operation of the bill. Those limited instruments which would be legislative in character do not go to the administration of the migration program.

BREAK.PARA: Cabinet agreed, on 17 May this year, that amendments should be made to the bill to exempt instruments which relate to the control and management of the migration program from disallowance. The exemption will not diminish the requirements under the bill for the proper application of the requirements of the bill, including consultation, registration, tabling and sunsetting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —What Senator Ellison has said disturbs me greatly. I have previously stood in this chamber—as both the government, when in opposition, and Senator Bolkus would know—and spoken of my concern about the powers of the minister for immigration in respect of making certain regulations.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not go over the major conflicts that occurred previously about a number of these regulations and the attempts, frankly, by various governments to put into place regulations which—to my way of thinking as I detailed on the occasion I spoke on this some time ago—conflict with the civil, political and human rights of persons, though not Australian citizens. It does concern me that we appear to be extending the powers of the minister under the Migration Act. As such, I am opposed to any such extension. I do not expect Senator Bolkus would be opposed to that, although I think he may have mellowed a little.

TALK.START.PARA: —In passing, Senator Ellison said that this does not change the current situation. Could he tell us what these particular provisions he is seeking to exempt refer to—what particular powers and functions under the Migration Act?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —What I did say was that the exemption will not diminish the requirements under the bill for proper application of other requirements of the bill, including consultation, registration, tabling and sunsetting. That was the part where I said it would not interfere with things. As for those specific aspects of the Migration Act, amendment (5) deals with:

BREAK.PARA: . . . Part 1, 2 or 9) of the Migration Act 1958, or a legislative instrument under Part 1, 2 or 5, or Schedule 2 or 6, of the regulations made under that Act—
That, I gather, is what you wanted to ascertain it relates to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Maybe you can tell us which of these provisions are currently exempt from the sort of scrutiny we are discussing now.

—I understand the sorts of things this relates to are matters dealing with the migration program, such as capping notices. They are not presently disallowable. This being exempted preserves the status quo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to say—and it might surprise Senator Harradine—that my starting point when it comes to immigration is that the last organisation in Australia I would trust with immigration policy is this government and the last person I would trust to actually get it right is this minister. I think the history over the last 15 months or so has been one of total ineptness and one of a program which has been unrealistically set and very badly administered.

SPEECH.PARA: I am persuaded by Senator Harradine's argument, which might surprise him. I think it is important for this parliament and this Senate to be able, if necessary, to play a role in some of the issues that are sought to be exempted now. The opposition will oppose this particular initiative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the Australian Democrats should put their views on the record. Migration is a very sensitive issue to all the parties, members and senators in this parliament. We think, because it is sensitive, regulations should be disallowable. We think matters should come before the parliament. It is of national interest.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats, as a party, have not been particularly enamoured of the minister's exercise of his discretion in office, and we think he and his department have lacked sufficient accountability in these matters. Absolute ministerial discretion, absolute executive function, particularly in such sensitive areas, are anathema to the Australian Democrats. Consequently, we will be opposing the government's amendment.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (16) Clause 61, page 66 (lines 15 to 17), omit paragraph (d).

This amendment relates to the government's proposal to exempt quarantine instruments from scrutiny and make them not subject to disallowance. I do not think I have to say much on this, as I spoke about it in the second reading debate. No valid argument has been put forward as to why quarantine instruments should not be subject to disallowance. We believe they should be and, as a consequence, we have drafted this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —This also coincides with the Greens (WA) amendment 5. The clause in question omits a paragraph which would have allowed certain important proclamations under the Quarantine Act 1908. As I indicated in my speech during the second reading stage, this is one area where I would agree with the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. They cannot see any rational explanation for providing this exemption from the parliament's ability to disallow the proclamations under the act.

—It is moments like these we might need some light relief. This is when I would like Senator the Rev. John Woodley to come down here and talk about all the regulations affecting chicken meat, newcastle disease and all the rural things on which he can wax eloquent, because I can see we are all getting sombre tired faces here. However, that is a digression. I record that the Australian Democrats will support the amendment that is put.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate my support for the amendment. It is similar to the amendment that has been circularised in Senator Colston's name. Of course, it was as Senator Margetts said, a matter of concern for the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, which made a number of comments. Senator Colston also made the comment that the bill excludes Quarantine Act declarations from disallowance. As he pointed out, declarations could severely disrupt the activities of individuals and businesses and provide for penalties of up to 10 years imprisonment and a fine of up to $100,000.

SPEECH.PARA: As was indicated, the reason for excluding the declarations from parliamentary scrutiny is apparently that they are important and sensitive. As Senator Colston said in this brief, this is, however, a reason in favour of disallowance rather than the opposite.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —For the record, the government opposes this amendment. It is not just that these matters are sensitive, as such; it is more that they are scientific. Quarantine is a very important part. I would say that—
—Where are all your backbenchers? They will fry you for dinner. It is political, and you know it.

—Senator Margetts, we have experts who deal with quarantine, protect Australia's boundaries and protect Australia from foreign diseases. We enjoy a situation in Australia which is remarkably disease free. It may well be that if these were disallowable it would then become political and that scientific reasoning, evidence based research and the integrity of scientific opinion might take second place to politics, as you point out. It is for that reason that the government does not consider that matters such as quarantine should be subject to discussion in this manner.

SPEECH.PARA: It is much like having regulations which relate to scientific research, let us say, subject to review by politicians who know nothing about it. That is the view. The minister has taken this up with the regulations and ordinances committee, explaining to them the problems in this regard. There are some other international concerns as well, but they are perhaps not as great as the scientific aspects of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I am provoked here. I have been on my feet many times in this chamber in relation to quarantine regulations. I have been on my feet many times because the changes to the international regime, brought in by Australia's involvement with the World Trade Organisation, mean that the difficulties in using science in Australia have become hugely more complex because Australia is subject to reversal of the onus of proof. So, in fact, it is an international political decision.

SPEECH.PARA: There is more and more reason for these decisions to be subject to parliamentary scrutiny. If necessary, debate should take place so that not only we but also the community can be involved in the whys and wherefores of decisions which have taken place. If you are saying the decision will only be made on science, I would say: if you check back on those debates again and again you will find out that science has been affected by the international politics of the World Trade Organisation.

I would like to say that I do not accept Australia being led by the nose like we were. There are things that should be questioned again and again; it is the nature of debate that they should be. If I am defeated again and again on that debate, so be it. But generally there is a growing concern, within your own ranks as well, that it is not just about science; it is the fact that science has become shackled by politics—Australian politics and the international politics of the area. I really beg to differ with your statements.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (6) Clause 66, page 71 (line 5), omit "that gives", substitute "the sole or principal purpose of which is to give".
(7) Clause 66, page 71 (line 7), omit "that confers", substitute "the sole or principal purpose of which is to confer".

These amendments make a number of drafting changes to item 14 of schedule 1 to remove unintended limitations to the range of instruments that are not legislative instruments for the purposes of this bill. It is to be noted that, although the making of such instruments does not require compliance with the provisions of the bill, the current requirements for tabling and disallowance of some such instruments under the Defence Act 1903 and the Public Service Act 1922 are respectively maintained by amendments 14 and 24 to schedule 4 of the bill.

By way of background, schedule 1 of the bill lists classes of instruments that are not legislative instruments for the purposes of the bill. The effect of item 14 of schedule 1 is to remove certain public sector employment instruments from the requirements of the bill. I will seek further advice from my advisers. There is some confusion here; these amendments relate to clause 66. I was referring to another amendment, and I will just query whether we should be moving these amendments at this stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —We were touching on clause 66, part 6, which is the sunset provision of the bill. There has been some discussion during the course of the afternoon—the last 24 hours, in fact—about the impact of this part of the bill.

SPEECH.PARA: We have some concerns, and they are of a much more fundamental nature than the amendments which have already been indicated. At the end of my short contribution, I would suggest, Minister, that we report progress on part 6 of the bill and the amendments related to it. Those amendments are: the government's amendments; Democrats' amendment No. 13; the opposition‐Democrats' amendment No. 17; and Democrats' amendment No. 14.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bolkus, rather than report progress, perhaps we should defer these two and move on to the next amendments.

—Yes. There is growing concern about the simplistic nature of what is being proposed, and some unforeseen—and maybe foreseen—consequences of it. I understand the government's desire—and the previous government's desire—to have the sunset provision. There is a need to clean up dead legislation, and dead and anachronistic instruments, and that is a noble thing to try to do. But the concern is that, by bringing in such a broad‐ranging sunset provision, and exempting only the small range which appear in schedule 1, all forms of instruments which may have some very valid social and continuing impact will not be protected. If they are not protected, there is no way to ensure that they are reactivated.

SPEECH.PARA: The parliament cannot initiate regulations, although we can, of course, amend legislation. But once instruments relating to a broad range of social policies such as consumer protection, quarantine, the environment, employment, education and so on lapse because of the sunset provisions, there is very limited scope to ensure that the protections, proposals, provisions and programs put in place under them can continue in those circumstances where there is a need for a continuing role.

We all realise that much of the legislation, instruments and regulations of social impact that we are talking about here have a very long continuing role. For instance, if we were to look at legislation such as the Racial Discrimination Act, that has had a quite fundamental and lasting effect on much of the state based legislation, and it does in fact govern much of the political debate at the moment. That is a piece of legislation, but there are all sorts of legislative instruments and regulations which also have such an important effect, and that effect does not necessarily die after five years.

We understand why the government wants to embrace a sunset provision, and it is something that was discussed by previous governments as well. But, with more reflection, I think there has to be more concern about the impact of such a sunset clause. One alternative is to say to the government, `Set the departments loose on stocktakes and report annually to us as to how they're conducting their stocktakes,' and there are other alternatives that we could look at.

I suggest that, subject to other senators wishing to speak at this point, we postpone consideration of part 6 of the legislation at this stage and revisit it when we come back to the bill sometime tomorrow in order that people may have a bit more time to consider not just the impact of part 6 but also any alternatives that we may want to move to it.
