DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Department of Health and Family Services

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I want to speak briefly on this first report of the Medical Training Review Panel. This panel was established as a result of Democrat instigation last year as part of the negotiations on the medical practitioner provider number legislation. At that time, although we agreed with the rationale of that legislation and the basic principles, we had specific concerns about the shortage of reliable data on medical training positions, about the availability of part‐time training places, and about career paths and opportunities open to hospital medical officers.

I might say here that there have been several years of questioning at estimates and I still have not been able to actually discover a lot of this information. The Medical Training Review Panel was set up to address these issues and I believe this report—the first—demonstrates the value of that panel.

Before talking about the report, I want to say once again, despite the exaggerated and downright false claims being made in some quarters, every junior doctor in this country has a guarantee of either a training place or a medical job. They will only end up driving taxis, as some of them are still claiming, if they cannot get a training place, if they will not move to take up a training place, or if they turn down a job in a hospital. They may want to make that decision; that is over to them. But the fact remains that they do have a guarantee of medical training or employment, and that is a lot more than many other young Australian graduates have.

However, the situation is not perfect and I believe the panel will play a crucial role in identifying where the problems lie and make recommendations to address them. For example, I have been particularly concerned about the situation of doctors working in our public hospitals and am pleased to see that the panel has made several recommendations about improving training opportunities and career paths in public hospitals. One clear consequence of the provider number legislation is that more medical graduates will be spending more time in public hospitals and I happen to think that that is a good outcome. What we now have to do, of course, is to make sure that we improve the training, the conditions and the career paths of those non‐specialist medical practitioners who are undertaking hospital work. The panel's recommendations in this area are sound and I believe that the minister should implement the panel's national training model. I will certainly be asking him to do so.

I am also very pleased to see the panel's proposal to engage a consultant to look at the selection process for medical trainees. One of the biggest concerns voiced to me by medical practitioners and students right across the board is that the selection processes—the review processes—are not transparent, are often biased, particularly against women, and, indeed, are open to abuse. It is well past the time that all medical colleges were dragged into the 20th century and I hope the panel's work will contribute to ensuring that that occurs.

The panel's data collection efforts to date go some way towards putting to rest the claim that some 400 graduates will miss out on training places as a consequence of the provider number legislation. The panel has identified 1,369 first‐year advanced training places that are going to be available in 1998, but has yet been unable to identify additional training opportunities within the public hospitals. As about 1,200 graduates are going to be coming out this year, ready to start next year in training places, I think we are well equipped to offer sufficient opportunities. As the numbers coming out of medical colleges are expected to stabilise at around 1,000, in the years ahead it is looking positive and promising for all of those who want training places.

BREAK.PARA: The panel will be letting a consultancy to gather information in the expectation of being in a position to report as required by the end of the year on whether the places available will be sufficient to meet the demand. That final batch of information will give us a very clear picture on the effect of the provider number legislation. Last year the Democrats successfully convinced government to put a safety net under its provider number proposals to ensure that every medical graduate had either a training place or a job.

Part of that process relies upon the monitoring and data collection work of this panel. It has clearly been successful and I congratulate Dr John Loy and Mr Robert Wells of the Department of Health and Family Services for their work in setting it up and in chairing the panel. I also congratulate all members of the panel on a job well done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising briefly to speak to the first report of the Medical Training Review Panel, I have not had a great deal of opportunity to inspect the minute detail, but this is of major concern to people following the changes that have taken place in the medical training of doctors, once they have finished their graduation. Of course, tied in with this is the need to ensure that a number of doctors do get themselves out of the city and into the country areas because there is still a shortage of doctors in country areas. But I think that if every position that is available can be filled, and if every doctor can be given post‐graduate training, that is very good.

SPEECH.PARA: I note with interest one of the tables here and that is the female advanced trainees percentages by specialty. Obviously, in some areas and in some specialties there is quite a way to go before these specialty areas in some states get access to some of these colleges for anywhere near the number of females who are graduating. It is an issue of concern that these colleges are not easily accessible to females. We now know that there is a significant number of women who are graduating from university with medical degrees, but the same number is not being reflected in the numbers in the specialty areas. I think sometimes there can be glass ceilings with respect to that.

BREAK.PARA: The hours that they are expected to work can be fairly horrific. The conditions under which they might well be expected to work are not family‐friendly, and that is certainly of some concern. I notice in something like occupational medicine in New South Wales, in 1997, that only 12.5 per cent of the advanced trainees are female, 62.5 per cent are in Victoria and there are none in Queensland, South Australia and Western Australia. I think there is still more work that needs to be done in some of these specialty areas to create accessibility for women.

I also have concerns about the preparedness of some of the specialist colleges to increase the number of people entering those specialty areas. We know that in some areas there is certainly a shortage and they are in short supply. That is something that the colleges themselves will have to address. It is almost like a closed shop. If it was a union situation, you would certainly see the government protesting most loudly about closed shop union tactics. However, in this particular area, that does not seem to be happening with the same enthusiasm and vigour we have seen elsewhere.

Training and access to medical services is certainly something that is of major concern to people in country areas because there are shortages of doctors. In fact, in areas that are not remotely distant from some of the major rural centres themselves there can be shortages. That is something that certainly has to be addressed in the future.

This review panel and the consultancy that is being undertaken is certainly a step in the right direction to get some figures and some clear definitions and clear ideas of where things are moving to. It is, as I say, an area of significant importance, because the health of this country is something that is of concern to everybody.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to clear up something that Senator West said. As a member of a specialist college and having been involved in this process for many years, I think it is fair to say that medicine has a very proud tradition in that female entry into medical courses is over 100 years old now. One of the most important things is that it was equal wages for females right from the very beginning.

SPEECH.PARA: I am afraid that Senator West is showing her age. I am not being unkind, nor would I ever be to somebody I have a very high regard for, but the reality is that Senator West was reflecting the views of her own training era. Times have changed since that era. I merely want to draw Senator West's attention to a recent study that was done questioning female medical graduates as to the reason why they did not take up various specialties. Many people who do specialise in medicine do not wish to go into particular specialties. I give you the example of neurosurgery, which is very demanding. The necessity to reoperate is frequent. The hours are terrible because they are often associated with motor vehicle accidents. This example is apposite, I suppose, in light of Wayne Goss's present position. The facts of the matter are that it is very demanding and stressful surgery for the surgeons involved.

This study has shown that many women do not wish to involve themselves in the processes of training for these particular specialties. It is not that there is any limitation, as Senator West is saying. There is a requirement for a standard to be maintained. There is very close selection for training processes. There are continual reviews. The Australasian College of Surgeons has just published a report. Manpower surveys have been done right from the very beginning to ensure that adequate numbers of specialists are available. But the facts of the matter are that many people do not wish to undergo the training for these particular specialties.

In many cases there is a shortage of specialties because, on the one hand, doctors, either male or female, do not wish to enter those specialties. Alternatively, many females do not wish to undergo the rigorous training because of the requirements of those specialties. Senator West suspected that there was a glass ceiling. I can assure her it no longer exists, if it ever did exist, in relation to females. I will attempt to get that report which updates the report that has come out and which has been tabled today.

Overall, the colleges of physicians, surgeons, anaesthetist, et cetera have been adjusting to the demands of family and the biological imperatives of being female and have made part-time training available to cope with the problem of the numbers that are available in these specialties to satisfy the demands of the Australian population. I will attempt to get hold of a copy of that report which updates the report that has just been tabled.

The colleges are to be commended for not only making training positions available on a part-time basis but also recognising the fact that over half the medical students now in our medical schools are female. Because we have an ageing population, there will be increasing demands on medical services. So there is a problem that needs to be addressed not by dint of being female but by dint of the ageing population and the inadequate total numbers that are going to be available for the treatment of patients in this country. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I want to speak briefly in relation to the Airservices Australia corporate plan. There are a number of aspects that I want to touch on tonight. Firstly, let me say that, in relation to the financial and other planning assumptions, there is a lot of good work being done by Airservices Australia. I had the opportunity to observe at close hand the work to implement the new TAAATS system which involves intense training for the new airport traffic staff. It is a whole new system and new technology, with implementation to commence in early 1998. I see from this report that, in this financial year, the plans are on track and under budget.

I also note that Airservices is transferring all its search and rescue activities to the Australian Maritime Safety Authority. In principle, that is a good thing. However, I think the jury is still out in relation to how the Maritime Safety Authority is going to handle that responsibility. We have had a number of matters of concern raised in estimates about the operation of the Maritime Safety Authority.

What I wanted to touch on tonight was the reference to the implementation of Airspace 2000 proposals, which have recently been delayed by the decision of the CASA board to undertake an investigation of the actual safety aspects of that plan in relation to the four airports that are to be affected principally by the downgrading of airspace to category E, as I understand it. That downgrading will, in the opinion of many commercial pilots who have the responsibility of flying planes with many passengers into those airports, pose grave safety dangers.

One of the concerns I have is that when it was proposed to implement this new airspace proposal the corporate plan suggested that it be implemented in December 1997. I must say that I cannot think of a worse time to implement a new safety regime for any airport in Australia. That is the period in which we come to the peak of air traffic. In this case, we had a situation where a number of pilots were suggesting that they would refuse to fly commercial planes into the airports affected. In the case of my state of Tasmania that was both Hobart and Launceston.

Had the plan gone ahead in accordance with this time line, we could have been faced with a situation where flights were not coming into the state at the peak holiday time. That would have had a disastrous effect on the state. In relation to that, Airservices should have had more regard to the timing of any radical change to the airspace management system that applied to any airport in Australia. In this case, airports of Tasmania, the Northern Territory—that is, Alice Springs—and Port Hedland in Western Australia were affected in the same way by this proposal.

I also wanted to refer to a matter which I think has been dealt with at other times—that is, the allocation of specific pricing for rescue and firefighting services in various locations around the country. I see I am not going to have time to do that in any depth tonight. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Department of Health and Family Services

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

This is never a large document but it is of some interest and not a little concern. I have read briefly the Nuclear Safety Bureau report of 1 January to 31 March 1997. It indicates there were 12 abnormal occurrences reported to the Nuclear Safety Bureau for that period. One of those occurrences was assigned level 1—that is, an anomaly beyond the authorised operating regime. They do not say what it is. There is usually very little detail in these reports. That is why they are so small. The remainder were assigned level zero—that is, of no safety significance. What it might mean is that they come under what is considered to be an acceptable limit. It does not mean to say that there might not be a release of radioactive material but somehow or other they scrape in underneath what is considered to be an acceptable level for workers' health and safety.

It also says on page 3 that an audit of radiation protection at HIFAR was performed during the previous quarters by officers. We never actually see these audits, unfortunately. They do conduct these audits but we do not necessarily see them to see what is involved. They say in this one that four items of non-compliance with audit criteria were noted; otherwise the audit found radiation protection to be satisfactory. That is really interesting. Once again, they note four items of non-compliance. They have asked for an action plan, but we do not find out what those items of non‐compliance are.

They report discharges from HIFAR of argon 41, a radioactive gas produced by neutron activation of air during reactor operations, which continued to regularly exceed the current weekly working level previously set by ANSTO. Nevertheless, they say that doses to the public resulting from these dis charges are well below radiation constraints. But I do not know whether that means they are well below those dose constraints for people working in and around where that argon was discharged. What does it mean `well below'? We are getting more and more information about the impacts of low levels or long‐lived low levels of radiation, which are giving us more information. Some of those are coming out from epidemiological studies from the United States. They provide quite new information to that which has already been available through the study of the survivors of Hiroshima and Nagasaki.

One of the problems of studying the survivors is that you are already looking at people who may not be genetically disposed to the effects of radiation in the same way as those people who actually died. The effects of long‐lived low level radiation may well be and is considered to be affected by the fact that many people died initially and that other people are more likely to have not suffered the effects of just simply low level radiation doses.

There have been modifications. Apparently it was found there was an inconsistency in the level of non‐destructive examination specified for welded joints of the pipe work which had been undertaken. There was final documentation for modification still outstanding. They are talking about the decommissioning of the MOATA reactor. This is the first nuclear reactor in Australia to enter the decommissioning phase. I think probably as a parliament we need more information about that.

Let us look at the restrictions on the operations of the nuclear plant. On two occasions during the quarter, as a result of the granting by the Nuclear Safety Bureau of a temporary exemption from an operational limit and condition, the Nuclear Safety Bureau required ANSTO to provide notification of the measured core excess radioactivity of HIFAR approximately 24 hours after start up. Advice was received to the Commonwealth that the maintenance of satisfactory standards for safety of the operation of HIFAR beyond 2003 would require a significant safety upgrading to be carried out and that the NSB would carry out the safety assessment of any upgrading.

There are some major questions on this issue. I noticed Senator Denman was in the chamber and was seeking the call on this issue and may well be able to add to this. It is an issue that should not be swept under the carpet. I really find it distressing that we are left with six pages to deal with such an important issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Denman, Sen Kay

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Department of Health and Family Services

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

It is interesting that the report says the role of the Nuclear Safety Bureau is `to monitor and review the safety of any nuclear plant owned or operated by ANSTO'. From what we heard about the last report, I hope in the end there will not be any more nuclear reactors. I hope that eventually this reactor will be phased out.
This time there were seven abnormal occurrences reported to the Nuclear Safety Bureau from 1 April to June 1997. Under the HIFAR operations as well, it indicates that:

During the quarter an action plan and schedule, requested by the NSB to address the areas of non-compliance with the audit criteria found during the audit, were submitted by ANSTO. The NSB agreed to the plan and schedule.
Once again, we do not have any access to these kinds of documents. There might well be, but I have not seen them. The report states:
HIFAR operations were found not to comply with audit criteria relating to documentation of procedures and instructions, and validation of monitoring methods.

The NSB considers the actions proposed by ANSTO to be satisfactory but do not cover all the issues raised in the audit and the bureau has requested that an amended action plan be submitted for agreement.
I mentioned about the last report, the last quarter before that, that there were reported discharges from HIFAR of argon 41. This report says they:
. . . continued to regularly exceed the current weekly working level . . .

I do not know what it indicates for the workers. I do not know whether they are trying to spread it out more like the spread effect with a shotgun by using a more regular rotation of workers or what they are actually doing. It does not actually say what they are doing in relation to the argon 41 discharges, where they are going and what effect they are having. The report states:

During the quarter, ANSTO informed the NSB that it agrees that the bureau has a role in the review of the store for new (unirradiated) HIFAR fuel. ANSTO is preparing a Safety Analysis Report for the new fuel store which will be provided to the NSB.
I hope so, but I also hope there will be wider consultation. They say that the safety report is to examine potential hazards of plutonium oxide powder. The report states:
ANSTO has also initiated action to design and manufacture double‐walled steel canisters . . . in line with current international best practice.

I hope it is at least that. There are indications that they are looking at HIFAR modifications. With regard to the replacement and inspection of the reactor secondary cooling system piping, which was carried out during the 1995 HIFAR major shutdown, they are looking at conducting an examination of above‐ground welds which have not been examined. The bureau is considering the proposed strategy.

The submission for a temporary modification to a circuit breaker drive motor to overcome repeated failure of a motor was received during the quarter and reviewed by the Nuclear Safety Bureau. So there is already a situation where there are repeated failures within the existing plant, and the last report indicated that the safety really is not up to scratch for what is considered to be best practice. They are actually having to move already to improve that. There is a lot more to say. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALKER.NAME: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Jacinta Collins)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.20 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight in this adjournment debate I want to showcase some very positive developments for the Tamworth Country Music Festival and for regional northern New South Wales. Tamworth is country music in this country. There is an immediate link and theme when most people in Australia put these two things together: the city of Tamworth and country music.

SPEECH.PARA: Increasingly, Tamworth and country music are also being linked internationally with places like Nashville in the United States. This growing status here at home and overseas is helping to provide a critical mass for the region in developing a tourism industry. Indeed, New South Wales tourism says that the Tamworth event and the Bathurst 1000 car race are the two largest tourism events in New South Wales outside of Sydney.

The festival is crucial to the economic development of the Tamworth region. It offers the critical mass to create high quality and well‐trained jobs in the tourism and hospitality industries. It is a unique event which attracts tourists to a region that has no special geographic or physical attraction like the coast. The region, indeed, is suffering depopulation, and tourism has been identified as the strongest economic option to grow employment opportunities in this region.

However, the Tamworth council is concerned that the Country Music Association of Australia might take the festival to another location. It is now critical that a more appropriate performance venue is developed in Tamworth.

Australian and international artists are putting up with very primitive and dusty conditions in a covered horse sale ring at the Tamworth showgrounds. There are portable dressing sheds for artists. There are poor visuals and acoustics for national and international radio and TV audiences. Despite this, the Tamworth Country Music Festival attracts an enormous crowd. Over 300,000 people come to the Tamworth region over the 10 days of the festival. That is 30,000 extra visitors in town each day of the festival. The total of 300,000 visitors across the 10 days is equivalent to the number of visitors that are estimated to be at the Sydney Olympics for one day.

Because of the scale of this and its importance to the region, I welcome the initiative to construct a new facility in this city, the Tamworth Region Entertainment Centre, which will become the permanent home of the festival held in January each year. What is proposed is a 5,000-seat multipurpose centre. It will be the focal point of the country music awards presentation. It will also incorporate a museum and hall of memory to Australian country music icons such as Tex Morton and Slim Dusty. The entertainment centre will have many uses for this region apart from the January festival. There will be trade shows, concerts, agricultural field days and vehicle promotions, to name just a few.

The regional community is right behind this project. It is not just a matter of government money for this $5½ million project. The Tamworth council has provided the land on a prime site very close to the city, and it will commit further funds to guarantee that this project is finalised. New South Wales tourism has put in $1¼ million and, to show the commitment of the local community, $800,000 has been pledged by local businesses. The council currently has a plan to raise another $500,000 from the local community. The Country Music Association of Australia is also providing $75,000 to this event over the next four years. To complete the funding, federal money is required in addition to this.

Today I led a delegation together with the Mayor of Tamworth, Councillor James Treloar, in conjunction with the member for New England, the Rt Hon. Ian Sinclair. The case is being put to the government that, under the national tourism development program, we should be putting federal funding into this very worthwhile project for northern New South Wales. This will not only develop tourism in this region but help boost the economic growth of a region that is depopulating, as I indicated earlier.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you have an answer yet?

—We do not have an answer yet. We made the submission today. I think, Senator, from the reaction we got,there are high hopes that such a worthwhile project will be supported. I am sure there is bipartisan support for that.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Condolences: Hon. Lance Herbert Barnard AO

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy, Sen Shayne

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to pay tribute to the Hon. Lance Barnard, who passed away. Due to the fact that I was away from parliament, I was not able to do this at the appropriate time. Many great tributes have been paid to Lance. I do not want to repeat what has been said with regard to a lot of things that he achieved and has done over a long period of time. I would like to speak more about the time that I knew Lance, when he worked from my office for some two years. He provided a great service to the community. In fact, he did so voluntarily. It would be very rare that days would go by when somebody from within the community was not coming in to see Lance.

SPEECH.PARA: As we all know, Lance won the seat of Bass in 1954, winning the seat that his father had held from 1934 to 1949. He then contested nine elections—all of which he won on primary vote. He never had to go to preferences, which was something he was always proud of. Of course, we know that he became Deputy Prime Minister on 5 December 1972. He held that position until 12 June 1974. On the same day, he also become the minister for 14 separate departments—something that I do not think has ever been equalled or is ever likely to be equalled again—when he and the then Prime Minister Gough Whitlam held all the ministries. One thing Lance had often said to me, with regard to the very great friendship that he had with Gough, was that Gough was never really keen to see the Deputy Prime Minister become Acting Prime Minister, although Lance did do that on a number of occasions.

BREAK.PARA: Over many years, Lance worked for so many organisations. I would like to put on the record some of the board memberships that he had in Tasmania. He was a board member for the Ainslie House Association, an elderly home service provider, and for Eskleigh, another elderly and disabled peoples home. He was a board member of the Railway Silver Band, the Masonic Society, and the Police and Citizens Youth Club. In so far as the Police and Citizens Youth Club is concerned, they recently completed new basketball court facilities. That was, in many ways, due to the efforts of Lance. The funding for that and the assistance that they received was due to a lot of his effort.

He was also a member of the Northern Tasmanian Regional Development Board. He was a board member of the Launceston City Council's Australia Day Committee, the Keep Our Post Office Committee, the Northern Group Training and Group Training Australia. Lance first became involved in Group Training back in 1987 when Northern Group Training was established in Launceston. He was elected their inaugural Chairman, holding that position until he retired in 1996. He remained a board member until the time he died. Indeed, he was made a life member of Group Training. In fact, he was the first life member.

He was a board member of the Launceston Returned Services League and was involved in the Royal United Services Institute, the Artillery Association, the Artillery Historical Association, Northern Tasmania, and the Australian Cat Federation. As cat lovers and cat show entrants around Australia we often used to have some discussions with him. He was known, I think, to the Assistant Clerk with regard to that.

The list of Lance's involvement in various community efforts goes on. That involvement was recognised in part when the Launceston community and Launceston City Council held a community reception for him on 31 July. Bob Campbell, the city manager, whom I know quite well, often said that Lance was one of the best door openers and purse string looseners around—and he was. It really must not go unnoticed that the effort he put in for the community was tremendous, particularly as somebody who was not being paid for it and somebody who was going on for 78 years of age.
Lance was involved in getting the funding for the Inveresk Railway Yards redevelopment, the Earl Arts Centre—

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought that was Silvia Smith.

—Of course, Lance Barnard was very significantly involved in achieving the funding for the AMC hydrodynamic facility in Launceston. Your government actually took away that $14½ million; we lost that. I hope that some day the government will see fit to reinstate that funding, because it is a very important facility, not only for Launceston. You now have the member for Bass in Warwick Smith, and I wish Warwick would actually stand up for Bass as much as Lance Barnard did. Of course, if he did, we probably would not have lost that funding.

BREAK.PARA: As a former defence minister, Lance Barnard was the Director of the Office of Australian War Graves. Many people probably would not know that it was really through his efforts and the effort of Mr Everard Baillieu CBE that the El Alamein memorial of participation was erected and dedicated to the soldiers that fought there.

He did many things to assist the RSL in Launceston—right up until the time he left to go to Melbourne. He was helping the RSL look for new premises, and they are now hoping to moving into that new building. Lance Barnard did all those things over a long period of time as a politician in retirement. As I said, Lance was really the member for Bass for 22 years in an official way, and he was probably the member for a further 22 years in an unofficial capacity.
In fact, when Lance used to come and do work for the community in my office he probably had more people see him than I did.

TALK.START.PARA: —I could well believe that!
—I do not say that lightly.
—I accept that.
—His involvement in the community was very significant. It is not to say, Senator Macdonald, that I do not see a number of people; I actually see a lot of people now that you are in government.
—After Lance left, the rot really set in in the Labor Party.
—Senator Macdonald, people are actually referred to me by the office of your member for Bass, Mr Warwick Smith. I am not quite sure why, but they are.

BREAK.PARA: Lance Barnard should be held in great esteem and I know that he is at home. A lot of people would not know the great contribution that he made and continued to make in retirement. I think it is fantastic for somebody who was almost 78 years of age to actually work four to five days a week for nothing. I know his wife Jill very well. I just say that Lance will be sadly missed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn
SPEECH.PARA: On the 17th of January 1990 Benjamin came into our lives. He was our second child and was received with much joy. I should add that it was a relief to see that Ben was `normal'. I had been diagnosed in 1988 with a virus which can affect the foetus if contracted for the first time while pregnant, that is what was said at the time. I did all the correct things and did not try to conceive until I had the all clear. When Ben was a few weeks old I received the news that Ben had in fact been born with the virus. I began the cycle of seeing the virologist and paediatrician and again was told that I had a completely normal, healthy child. I must say that I could not agree as I was living with the Baby From Hell. He constantly cried, rarely slept and was never happy.

The weeks went by of living with the Baby From Hell with no-one in the medical profession believing me that something was wrong with him . . . I made an appointment with the paediatrician. She examined Ben and told us that he had increased tone and he would probably just be a bit clumsy . . . I should add at this stage that if Ben was a little bit clumsy I would be delighted. Ben had spastic quadriplegia, he cannot do anything without assistance. He cannot sit by himself, he has no speech, he is in nappies, he has to be fed. In other words, Ben has to have everything done for him.
And so began the nightmare of trying to find out what help was available. This should be an easy process but it is not.

Our whole lives had to change because of Ben. I soon realised that the idea of ever returning to the paid work force was a far off dream and we had to face reality that our house was not suitable for a child like Ben. So in between all the running around of treatment for Ben we had to look for a new house, and not just any house, but one that would meet his requirements.

The contributions of carers like Ben's mother have become very necessary to the success of a great deal of government programs, particularly those that have been established to assist older Australians and children and adults with disability. There is an increasing general acceptance in Australia that the state has a role to play in assisting carers and the recipients of their care, but there is far less agreement on what level and form that support should take.

Many still see the family as the primary carer, with the role of the state being to supplement and complement family support rather than to replace it. A minority view is that, in the long term, there will be so few family carers that the state will have no option but to assume that role. The government decision in 1995 to pay a parenting allowance to those parents remaining at home to care for their children has very significant implications for carers because, along with the carer pension, it gives a level of legitimacy and recognition to the value of unpaid care performed at home.

A fundamental role of carers is to assist their child to live independently in the community with minimal recourse to government funded programs. However, tonight I want to point out that carers of severely disabled younger people are very, very vulnerable, given the intensity of the care which is often required and the extended periods over which it is provided. For many, that is a lifetime.

The overwhelming feeling among carers is that supporting a child or a young adult with a disability is very hard work but with a little help they could actually do it. Unfortunately, that help is becoming harder and harder to obtain. The words of Ben's mother summarise the feelings of many other carers, too. She says:

Life with Ben . . . is like living with a time bomb. We wake up each day not knowing what to expect, and can't think too far into the future. Little did I realise that my life would change so dramatically. As Michael says, Ben can only see the world through us showing him, and we want to give him the best opportunities we can. Ben will never walk or talk; Ben can never say, "Thanks mum and dad, you do a great job and I love you for it". Ben can't tell us how he feels, he can't tell us if he is in pain. Ben can never put his arms around my neck and give me a hug and say, "Thanks mum".

Policies to assist carers can only be considered in conjunction with the broader social and political context in which they are developed. The costs associated with institutional care and its unsuitability for residents and their families have driven the closure of such places.

Most people would agree that people should be entitled to live as independently as possible within the community, but it is very well known that there are huge unmet needs out there for supported accommodation, particularly for those who are profoundly disabled. For many of those who are in such accommodation, there is often no such thing as `the community'. More commonly, there is increased isolation and increased vulnerability. So it should come as no surprise to us that many families are looking for other models of care.

Parents of children and young adults with disabilities do not doubt that institutions are unsatisfactory. Institutions such as Kew Cottages in Melbourne are not only unsatisfactory; the state government has so restricted staffing and access to day programs and other services—such as recreation—that residents find themselves locked up for many hours at a time each day. This is not so much a problem of the institutions as a problem of commitment and adequate resources.

So-called community integration began as an understandable and very necessary reaction to institutionalisation, but we are now seeing this policy hardened into what has become a very discriminating orthodoxy, whereby every person with a disability has been deemed to be better off out there in the community. Government policies of community care and family based care have been driven primarily by the financial expense of institutions, with very little consideration given to the concerns of the people directly affected by those policies. Whilst nobody is arguing for the return of institutions, many parents want to move away from a blanket approach of community care, to more enlightened policies which recognise the wide spectrum of disabilities and the vastly different care requirements along that spectrum. They want to see options made available which can involve families.

Today, undoubtedly, there are very many excellent services run by excellent people who bring dignity, achievement and self-esteem to many disabled people. However, I think these services have been set up primarily for people with mild or at the most moderate disability, and very little for people who need and will continue to need specialised services, specialised accommodation and 24-hour care. Those are very commonly in our too-hard basket. As one mother pointed out recently at a public meeting in Melbourne:
My greatest concern is for all those old parents with their ageing disabled person still at home and for all those younger parents with their disabled child now at home for indefinite years to come.

Another carer supported this notion by pointing out that policies have failed to understand that `not all disabled students, especially those with intellectual disabilities, will complete their education and become adults at the chronological age of 18'. Thus they require extended care.

Community and family based care may at first appear to be cost-effective. It does reduce the number of people requiring residential care, but we also need to understand that it may prove very much more costly in the long term by increasing that burden on carers to the extent that many are unable or unwilling to continue their caring role, thus placing those in their care at risk of institutionalisation. Carers point out that the options for disabled people are very, very limited. Another carer said:
. . . we fail to understand why it is that everyone can choose to live in an accommodation complex of units, small houses or whatever, but not so our children.

Later in life, we can mostly expect to live in a charming retirement village with our peers, if that is our need or our wish, but not so our children. By denying children and young adults with disabilities a choice which we take for granted because it is not policy or because of long‐held ideologies is, I think, discriminatory and demands action as an infringement of the equal rights of such people. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in the adjournment debate this evening to talk about an event that occurred some weeks ago here in Canberra at Old Parliament House. The event was the Australian Youth Forum. It was organised by a remarkable young man—J.J. Kahla.

SPEECH.PARA: J.J. travelled overseas last year and came back with a vision that related quite specifically to activating Australia's youth to be more concerned and able to take their concerns to the leaders of this country. The result of this initiative was the forum. I am not the first person in this chamber to speak about the forum and the work that was done there by over 300 young Australians from around the country. They ranged in age from 11 to 21. They covered a broad range of issues—everything from the pressing youth suicide issue to unemployment and the housing crisis.

This evening I would like to read a number of messages from this particular youth forum. The young people came up with so many ideas and canvassed so many issues. They produced a paper of broad recommendations. This paper has been circulated amongst federal parliamentarians. I take this opportunity to say to them that, if you have not already read the document, please do so. You will get an insight into the talents, skills and energy of the young people that we have in our midst.

As part of their work on the weekend of the forum they prepared messages; messages to politicians, messages to business people and messages to their own—to the young people of Australia. I would like to place on the public record some of these messages. I am the conduit for the messages of the young people at this forum. The first message reads:

Politicians—leaders of Australia, you hold the positions of power in this country today. Use that power wisely, respect it, and remember that you are representing us. The decisions you make today will affect our tomorrow.
Another one:
Take a constructive approach to social issues in consultation with a cross section of society, especially youth.
The next message reads:

To all political leaders—we want Australia to be a strong, accepted, respected and equitable nation, leading the world in human rights, with strong people and a strong Australian identify that celebrates its diversity and encourages optimism in all its youth.
Another message to politicians reads:
We envisage Australia to be a united multicultural nation. We want to have less racial conflict and higher social standards in a society in which discrimination is non‐existent.
Another reads:
Australia's youth are motivated, willing and able to contribute to Australia's future.
Another message reads:
It is your responsibility to listen and adhere to our opinions for we are the Australians of today , as well as tomorrow.
They also prepared some messages to business people. The first reads:
Be fair and equal employers in all workplaces through non‐discriminatory practices, and make a commitment to the well‐being of the community to assist in social stability.
Another one reads:
Think of us as an economic gain, not an economic strain. We are motivated, enthusiastic and committed—we just need an opportunity.
The next message reads:
Youth are the workforce of the future, give us a chance now.
Another one reads:
Recognise the wealth and potential in young people. Work together in the spirit of cooperation.
The next reads:

BREAK.PARA: As holders of influence and power in our society your responsibility extends beyond profit margins to the social outcomes of your decisions.
Another message from young people to business people reads:
To make a better tomorrow we have to look beyond materialism; let us join together to provide a prosperous future for all.

The messages to business people continue, showing that young people recognise that everybody has a critical role to play in this country's future. This is what the young people at the Australian Youth Forum had to say to their own, to other young people:
Never give up hope in the future of tomorrow; it spawns from the action of today.
Another message reads:
Have understanding, dream and be hopeful, aim high and be proud of who you are—make a difference, don't ever be afraid to speak up for what you believe in.
The next message reads:
We all have a destiny. We all have a place in Australia's future. Let yourself be heard.
Another message reads:
This country is ours, help it realise its potential.
Another message reads:
Enrich, read, lead and change. Be people who make things happen.

There are many more messages from the young people at this forum, but I wanted to place those on the record because I believe that they are all significant and representative of the incredibly rich and diverse talents we have in what is our most important resource.

I would like to take the opportunity to congratulate all the organisers of the Australian Youth Forum. It was a terrific initiative. I hope that, through regional organisations and those delegates who participated, the energy that flowed from that gathering will continue to gain momentum both on a regional and a state basis, and that once again the group will come together, share their ideas amongst themselves and send us what I think are quite pertinent messages.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 27 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Government made the services of the Federal Privacy Commissioner available to the private sector to assist in the development of voluntary codes of practice.
(2) How many times, or on how many occasions, has the Federal Privacy Commissioner provided services to the private sector to assist in the development of voluntary codes of practice.

(3) (a) Have assurances been received from the States and Territories that they will not introduce privacy legislation that will regulate privacy in the private sector: (b) which States and Territories have provided such assurances: and (c) which States and Territories have not provided those assurances.
(4) What compliance costs would have been increased by the introduction of a privacy regime for the private sector?
(5) What data or research did the Government have to confirm its decision that compliance costs would have been increased by introducing a privacy regime for the private sector.
(6) Did the Government consider the compliance savings generated through improved record management and consumer satisfaction that their personal information was adequately protected.

(7) Did the Government undertake any analysis that examined, or rely on any data, that showed the costs to Australian business in lost trade opportunities as a result of there being no privacy regime applying to the private sector.

(8) If there was no data or analysis to support the Government' s decision not to extend the privacy regime to the private sector, what reasons did the Government have for its decision not to extend the privacy regime to the private sector.
(9) What are the projected compliance costs to Australian business if there is a patchwork of privacy regimes across the States and Territories.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. At the Premier's Conference on 21 March 1997, the Prime Minister announced that the services of the Privacy Commissioner would be available to assist business in the development of voluntary codes of conduct and to meet privacy standards.

Assisting the private sector on matters concerning the handling of personal information is a statutory function of the Privacy Commissioner. Under section 27(n) of the Privacy Act 1988 the Privacy Commissioner is to encourage corporations to develop programs for the handling of records of personal information that are consistent with the Guidelines on the Protection of Privacy and Transborder Flows of Personal Data issued in 1980 by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (the OECD Privacy Guidelines).

(2) I am advised that the Privacy Commissioner receives numerous requests from the private sector for advice and assistance. In 1995/96, for instance, more than 800 telephone requests were received from private sector organisations other than credit providers. The Commissioner's office has frequently also given written advice on the application of privacy principles and a range of materials has been developed. There have been at least 18 occasions on which the Commissioner has become involved in substantive work on codes of practice that were being either reviewed or created by an individual company or an industry body. In most cases, these codes have covered broad ethical and service delivery issues and, while making a reference to privacy, they did not aim to address all aspects of the OECD Privacy Guidelines.

I am advised that since taking up duties in February 1997, the current Privacy Commissioner has met with companies and industry representatives on approximately 15 occasions to discuss the development of appropriate practices and policies within the private sector. Since the Government's offer in March that the Privacy Commissioner would be available to assist business in the development of voluntary codes of conduct, discussions with the private sector have been focused on seeking cooperation in the development of a consistent national framework.

On 18 August 1997 the Privacy Commissioner released a consultation paper, Information Privacy in Australia: A National Scheme for Fair Information Practices in the Private Sector, which presents a proposal for a self-regulatory information privacy scheme and invites public debate on the issues raised and feedback by 15 September 1997. In October 1997 the Privacy Commissioner proposes to hold a series of forums around Australia for the full range of stakeholders to discuss the issues and to gauge the level of interest in, and commitment to the proposed national scheme.

(3) Discussions between the Commonwealth and the various States and Territories about extending privacy protection to the private sector are ongoing. The aim of these discussions is to reach an agreed national approach. Accordingly, it would be inappropriate for the Commonwealth to outline the respective positions of the States and Territories at this time
(4) The compliance costs of a privacy regime for the private sector would depend on the particular elements of the regime put into place.
In general, there would be costs associated with:
. assessing existing record-keeping practices and procedures against the particular information privacy standards required by the regime;
. making any necessary changes to those practices and procedures to ensure that they complied with the requisite standards;
. educating management and employees on the information privacy standards and what these would mean in terms of everyday work;
. maintaining systems to comply with the standards; and

(5) The Government's decision not to legislate on private sector privacy followed extensive consultation based on the discussion paper, Privacy Protection in the Private Sector, released in September last year by the Attorney-General's Department. That discussion paper outlined a possible approach to privacy protection in the private sector. Its purpose was to enable business and the community generally to provide concrete comments.

The Attorney-General's Department received more than 100 submissions in response to its discussion paper, many of which provided detailed comments. As well as formal submissions, a number of organisations took the opportunity to meet with the Attorney-General's advisers and relevant officers of the Attorney-General's Department to discuss areas of specific concern.

There was particular concern expressed in submissions about how a legislative regime would impact upon small and medium enterprises. Some submissions argued strongly that there was no clear need for legislation in order to ensure privacy protection and that privacy concerns could be adequately addressed by business on a voluntary basis.

The Small Business Summit in June last year recognised the cost and frustration from unnecessary or overly complex regulation which falls on small business. A specially commissioned survey, `Working Overtime' has found that, on average, small businesses spend 4 hours a week on `compliance matters'. Over the course of a year this costs the average small business $7000.

The Government acknowledges that complying with current regulatory requirements already imposes a significant burden on Australian businesses and is committed to reducing the regulatory burden on all business. In opting for an approach to encourage the adoption of voluntary codes of conduct to enhance privacy protection in the private sector, the Government aimed to identify the right balance between ensuring adequate privacy protection and advancing the competitive interests of Australian business.

(6) The Government is aware that many benefits, including those of improved record management and consumer satisfaction can flow from the application of information privacy principles. These benefits, and the savings that can flow from them, can also be achieved through a voluntary approach to privacy protection in the private sector.

(7) The Government has decided to support a voluntary approach to ensuring privacy protection in the private sector involving the development of voluntary codes of practice. The Privacy Commissioner has already commenced consultations with the private sector preparatory to assisting the private sector implement information privacy standards. Therefore, the Government does not agree that there will be no privacy regime applying to the private sector.

There were concerns expressed in some of the submissions made in response to the Attorney-General's September 1996 discussion paper concerning the potential impact on Australia of the European Union Directive on the Protection of Individuals with regard to the Processing of Personal Data and on the Free Movement of Such Data (the EU Directive). This issue has also received attention in the media.
The Government has followed closely the development of the EU Directive.
The Government has considered this question of the possible impact of the Directive on Australian trade opportunities with EU countries and will continue to monitor this issue closely.

(8) See answer to Question (5). The decision not to implement a legislative privacy regime for the private sector was based on an analysis of the submissions received in response to the Attorney-General's Department's discussion paper, Privacy Protection in the Private Sector. and other consultations within Government.

(9) If any of the States and Territories were to introduce privacy legislation affecting the private sector within their own jurisdictions there would be a need to assess the potential impact on projected compliance costs to Australian business, particularly those businesses with interstate operations.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Health and Family Services: Programs

(2) Is there an explanation as to why the details of the individual elements were not in the original budget papers.

(3) With reference to the Family Resource Centre (FRC) Program and the Youth Activities Services (YAS) Program: (a) is the department aware that these 2 programs are completely different; (b) is it not true that claims of refocusing are misleading; and (c) is it not true that family resource centres are being completely defunded.

(6) Is the department aware of initiatives of the FRC national network to expand the FRC model and the nature and national significance of its activities.

(8) What consultations and negotiations took place with the FRC and YAS and people affected by this decision.
(9) What strategies will the Commonwealth use to ensure a coordinated approach to providing family support services.

(10) (a) Where is the evidence that it was a 5‐year program; (b) were the centres ever informed of this; and (c) why were FRCs required by the Minister as part of this funding agreement to consult and prepare a 3‐year strategic plan that ends in 1999.
(11) How does this decision sit the Prime Minister's election promise to maintain funding to the FRC program.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Family Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1 and 2) Decisions on where the savings will be achieved are being taken on a progressive basis. Decisions have already been taken to terminate funding for eleven (11) Family Resource Centres and to redirect funding to provide direct support for families with adolescent children in over 90 disadvantaged areas supported by Youth Activities Services; to discontinue funding for the Work and Childcare Advisory Agencies; and to rationalise funding for resource and advisory agencies funded under Childcare Special Services and Childcare Program Support.
(3) (a) Yes.
(b) and (c) Funds will be refocused to provide direct support to families with adolescent children in over ninety (90) areas currently supported by Youth Activities Services.

(4) (a) The sponsoring body of each Youth Activities Service will be offered funding to employ a part‐time family support worker. These workers will work with families of troubled or disadvantaged young people to help them deal with difficulties, such as family conflict, lack of communication or other issues which impact on their well‐being as families. The family support workers will be required to work together with existing support services in their communities, to achieve the best possible outcome for young people and their families in a cost effective manner.
(b) No.

(5) The eleven (11) Family Resource Centres were established in 1991 as time‐limited projects, to facilitate co‐ordination and to transfer skills to local services to help them better serve their local communities.
(7) This initiative further increases support for families with adolescent children.
(8) Family Resource Centres were advised of the Budget‐related decision as soon as possible after the decision was taken.

(9) The family support workers employed by Youth Activities Services sponsor bodies will be required to work closely with existing support services, to achieve the best possible outcomes for young people and their families in a cost effective manner.

(10) (a) Family Resource Centres were initially established for a three‐year period subject to ongoing evaluation. Initial discussions with State and Territory Governments on the establishment of Family Resource Centres addressed how long it would take to develop and transfer skills to services in the area and the concept of a limited time period in each area.
(b) Each Centre entered into a yearly service agreement with the Commonwealth.
(c) This was a decision of the previous Minister.

(11) The Prime Minister promised only to maintain current levels of funding in the Human Services area which included Family Resource Centres. Funding levels for the Family and Children's Services Program have increased from $1.170 billion in 1995‐96 to $1.239 billion in 1996‐97 and $1.338 billion in the 1997‐98 Budget.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 19 August 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can the Minister confirm that, according to a new law in Victoria, Victorian postal delivery officers employed with Australia Post are no longer exempt from having to wear helmets while on the job, if so, can the justifications behind this decision reversal be explained.
(2) (a) Why have postal delivery officers not been kept informed as to the progress of deliberations regarding the wearing of helmets;
and (b) why have their opinions not been sought.
(3) In the interests of safety of postal delivery officers, why is comprehensive training in riding and maintaining bicycles not provided.
(4) To what administrative body is the Occupational Health and Safety Department of Australia Post accountable.
(5) Have any investigations been made into alternative helmet models which would meet health and safety requirements but would also offer comfort and sun protection to postal delivery officers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice from Australia Post, is as follows:

BREAK.PARA: (1) Under current Victorian traffic law, postal delivery staff who deliver mail by bicycle are required to wear approved bicycle safety helmets—this requirement now applies to all bicycle riders in Victoria. Prior to 30 May 1997, an exemption was provided under Road Safety (Traffic) Regulations 1988 in the case of postal delivery staff during the course of a postal round.

Following the December 1996 meeting of the Australia Post National Occupational Health, Safety and Environment Committee (APNOHSEC), management, in consultation with delivery staff and the CEPU, undertook a detailed assessment of the level of OHS risks associated with the mail delivery task. As a result, Australia Post has since required all bicycle delivery staff in the States to wear approved bicycle safety helmets.

(2) Australia Post's decision to require bicycle delivery staff to wear approved bicycle safety helmets was made in consultation with the CEPU at the national level. As mentioned above, the risk assessment process undertaken involved delivery staff representatives.

In Victoria, the decision was discussed at the Australia Post's State OHS `Committee (SOHSC) and Delivery Business Unit OHS Committee (DOHSC), as well as at the Victorian Delivery Joint Consultative Council in March 1997. All those fora are consultative and have representation from the CEPU. In the case of SOHSC and DOHSC, staff health and safety representatives, elected in accordance with the requirements of the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Act, are included.

(3) In Australia Post's Victorian administration, the maintenance of bicycles is undertaken either by a staff member at the workplace with specific skills in this area or through an arrangement with a local bicycle repair specialist.

Training is provided on an ongoing basis on both the use and loading of a mail delivery bicycle. This training is provided by a team of specialist delivery staff, nominated by the CEPU and staff from the Delivery Business Unit.

(4) Australia Post employs OHS advisers in its National Headquarters and in each State administration. They are accountable to management and are required to provide advice to enable Australia Post to, among other things, comply with its obligations under the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Act and implement reasonably practical actions to minimise the risk of injury.

(5) For many years, bicycle helmets which meet the relevant Australian Standards have been made available to bicycle delivery staff. In addition, a `legionnaire' style cover with peak is available to provide sun protection.

In conjunction with CEPU and delivery staff representatives, Australia Post's management is currently conducting a review of bicycle safety helmets and other personal protective equipment to ensure that staff are provided with equipment which optimises health, safety and personal comfort factors, including temperature/sun protection.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 20 August 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware that some 1800 phone numbers cannot be accessed from the Northern Territory
(2) (a) How extensive is the problem; (b) what is the cause; and (c) when will it be fixed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, I am aware that some 1800 numbers cannot be accessed from the Northern Territory or from other States.

(2) (a) The lack of access to 1800 numbers from interstate is not due to any technical problem. (b) 1800 services are free calls to the calling party, with the costs of the call being paid for by the receiver. It is therefore the receiver who decides how far reaching the service should be by instructing their carrier accordingly and paying the corresponding charges. (c) The geographic areas in which the 1800 number can be accessed is a commercial matter between the customer and the carrier.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: Senator Hill —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (3), (4), (5) (b), (6), (7) and (10) (b) With the formation of the inquiry into the sinking of HMAS Sydney by the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I consider it appropriate for the matters referred to by the honourable senator, including papers provided to me by the honourable senator in a letter dated 21 August 1997, to be examined by that committee. (8) and (11) I refer the honourable senator to my answer to Senate Question No. 673 (Hansard, 25 August 1997, page 5614).
